INTRODUCTORY NOTES. The object of the "Iron Roads Dictionary and Illustrated Route Chart " is to provide a useful hand-book for all classes of the travelling public, and, it is hoped, will prove equally serviceable to men of business as to tourists and pleasure-seekei-3. The plan upon which it has been prepared facilitates reference to objects and places of interest in a manner not previously attempted. Tlie valuable assistauce rendered by the Chief Officials of the Railway com mands grateful acknowledgment. Much time and labour have been expended on the following pages, but the aid so cheerfully accorded by the servants of the Company has materially lightened the task of the Compiler, who has several times travelled over the main line and its branches, and collected personally from every creditable source most of the information contained iu the book. It is possible (hat slight errors will be found, despite the care taken to prevent their intrusion ; but its contents, as a whc\e, give grounds for the belief that it will afford the means of agreeably whiling away the monotonous hours of a railway journey. With this volume, those for the London Chatham and Dover and London Brighton and South Coast Railways are simultaneously published. The books for the other principal Lines are in course of preparation for early publication. Communications and corrections will be thankfully received by WATERLOW <fc SONS Limited. March, 1881.

IX AN HISTORICAL SKETCH OF THE SOUTH EASTERN RAILWAY, AND USEFUL INFORMATION RESPECTING IT. The South Eastern Railway Company was incorporated by 6 William IV., c. 75 (21st June, 1836), as the South Eastern and Dover. The original scheme commenced at Red Hill Junction, and terminated near Dover. In 1839 the Com- pany obtained power to run over the Croydon Line (from Croydon to Red Hill in the parish of Reigate). This section of tire railway was originally constructed by the Brighton Company, but the South Eastern Company afterwards purchased for £340,000 (with interest on the cost up to the date of purchase) one-half of the length, and also contributed a share of the expense of erecting the joint station at London Bridge. In 1843 the extension to Dover (making the length of the main line 88 miles), the branch to Maidstone, and the purchase of the Bricklayers' Arms Station were authorized. Powers were secured for the Canterbury, Ramsgate and Margate, and Folkestone Harbour Branches in 1844 ; the Tunbridge Wells (in the following year supplemented by authority to extend to Hastings), Minster and Deal, and Ashford and Hastings Branches in 1845 ; and the North Kent (with its exten- sions) in 1^46. The Reigate, Guildford and Reading Railway was purchased in 1852, and the Whitstable Branch and Continental Steam Packet Service iu 1853. On the 30th of June, 1863, the South Eastern Company obtained Parliamentary sanction for new lines to Tunbridge and Dartford. Tlie first-named line was pro- jected with the object of shortening the journey to Dover. It was opened as far as Chislehurst in June, 1865 ; to Sevenoaks in March, 1868 ; and to Tunbridge (then becoming the direct main line — the section to Tunbridge via Croydon and Red Hill being described as the old main liue) iu May, 1868. The Dartford Branch was . .rst used for public traffic on the 1st of September, 1866. The City (Cannon Street) and West End (Charing Cross) extensions were originally undertakeu by a district company. By the terms of an Act passed on the 8th of August, ] 859, the South Eastern Company subscribed £300,000 to the Charing Cross undertaking, and agreed to participate in its management and work the line when opened. The Cannon Street extension was authorized on the 25th of June, 1861, the South Eastern contributing a further sum of £250,000. These amounts were supplemented by a third contribution of £350,000 — making in all £900,000— in May, 1861. In 1863 the Company obtained an Act to amalgamate the Charing Cross scheme, fusion being effected shortly after. The line from Charing Cross to London Bridge was opened for traffic in August, 1864; and that into Cannon Street on the 1st of September, 1866.

XII Eastern Mail Service is undoubtedly tho most important and responsible in the world. Five hotels are owned by the Company — namely, Charing Cross Terminus ; Cannou Street Terminus; the Pavilion, Folkestone Harbour; the Lord Warden, Dover; and the Seabrook, Hythe. All are magnificent establishments, replete with the most recent facilities of hotel accommodation, but not lackiug the comforts of English home life. The two first named form the entrances to the statious from which they take their designation, and are a combination of Italian and Gothic styles of archi tecture — principally the former. That of Charing Cross contains 250 sleeping-apart ments and about as many private and other rooms ; it gives employment to more than 200 persons; and there are complete provisions for guarding against fire. Cannon Street Hotel is, in most of its features, a reproduction of the Charing Cross building. Both were built from the designs of Mr. E. M. Barry, and completed for use shortly after the opening of the sections of the liue with which they are imme diately connected. A reminiscence of the Eleanor Cross, which in ancient times stood near the site of the terminus at Charing Cross, is perpetuated by a beautiful facsimile in the centre of the open space fronting the hotel. The Pavilion at Folkestone is a somewhat old-fashioned but luxurious hotel (built by tho Company), with which few in the provinces eau compete for size, splendour, and convenience ; it is specially suitable for winter residence. The Lord Warden Hotel, at Dover, is a structure which, from its massive yet elegant style, unrivalled position, and excellent internal arrangements, has attained a reputation enviable as it is deserved. The Seabrook Hotel, at Hythe, opened in 1880, and under the direct management of the Compau)'-, possesses an unparalleled situation, and possesses every advantage which can aid in ensuring its acceptance as a favourite residence both in summer and winter. There is no railway in the kingdom — and, it may be added, with little room for contradiction, " in the world" — of the same extent which presents such varied and striking examples of engineering skill and scientific construction as the South Eastern. On the journey between Charing Cross and Dover, by the main line, feats of human genius can be observed which are not to be surpassed anywhere in talent of design and ability of accomplishment : they inelude the Charing Cross Hotel, Station, and Bridge ; the Cannon Street Hotel, Station, and Bridge ; the continuous viaduct from Lambeth to Spa Road, 3 miles in length ; the Sevenoaks Tunnel, 3,453 yards or nearly two miles in length (its lineal dimensions are exceeded in the United Kingdom by only three other tunnels); the "straight road" between Paddock Wood and Ashford — a section of the line which would be mathematically precise in its course for 25 miles but for an almost imperceptible curve at Staplehurst ; the Ford Valley Viaduct near Folkestone ; and the tunnels and sea walls between Folkestone and Dover. The Charing Cross Terminus and Bridge were commenced in 1860. The latter is 1,350 feet long, and comprises nine spans — six of 154 feet and three of 100 feet. It is mainly supported by cylinders sunk into the bed of the river ; but the brick piers of the old Hungerford Bridge, wliich it supplanted, were incorporated in its design •md execution. The greatest depth of water between these piers is 13 feet below low water spriug tides, and the average depth about 10 feet. The level of tlie rails is 31 feet above Trinity high-water mark, and the clear minimum headway 25 feet above the same level. No less than 4,950 tons of wrought iron (including steel pins) and 1,950 tons of cast iron were used in the building of the bridge. The station-shed is 450 feet long by 170 wide, aud covered by an arched glas3 and iron roof as bold in its dimensions as that of tho Islington Agricultural Hall. It stands upon a series of wide and massive arches, which have be?n utilized for a variety of purposes, and_ produce a large revenue to the Company. The-cost of the bridge was £160,000. It was designed by Mr. Hawkshaw, President of the Institution of Civil Engineers. The cost of the hotel and station was £320,' '00. The Cannon Street Bridge and Station very closely resemble those at Charing- Cross. The bridge is 700 feet long between the abutments. The piers, from tho bottom of tho cylinders to the bed-plate girdt rs, contain about 2,500 tons of cast and wrought iron ; the superstructure contains s.bout 4,200 tons of wrought iron.in

XIII girders, floor plates, (fee, and about 1,100 tons of ornamental castings in cantilevers, railings, pillars, cfcc. The roadway carries five lines of rails, and the cost of the works, with the exception of the permanent way and signals and signal apparatus, amounted to £193,000. The dimensions of the station-shed slightly exceed those of the Charing Cross shed. The elevation of the London Bridge Station (the headquarters of the Company) is in the Italian style, but rather unpretending. It consists of three stories, terminating with an ornament \\ cornice, and surmounted by a clock. The station buildings, which are jointly owned by the South Eastern and Brighton Companies, stands upon an artificial terrace or platform reared upon a massive superstructure of piers and arches which extends to a depth of 40 feet below the railway. In this stupendous work moro than eight millions of bricks were consumed. The train platforms are covered with wood aud glass roofs. There aro no less than 38 tunnels on the railway, eleven alone being on the main line. First iu importance and costliness is the wonderfu 1 passage through the North Downs at Sevenoaks, which is only 69 yards short of being two miles in length. The Polhill Tunnel, north of Sevenoaks, is 2,609 yards long ; Abbotts Cliff Tunnel, between Folkestone and Dover, is 1,933 yards ; Merstham Tunnel, near Red Hill, pierced throughout its whole length by the blasting process, 1,832 yards; and the Shakspeare Cliff Tunnel, at Dover, 1,392 yards. The portion of the line between Folkestone and Dover excites greater attention and secures more interest than any other, not only on account of the fine marine view which it furnishes, but also by reason of the immense difficulties that were overcome in its formation. From the moment the train leaves Folkestone Station it proceeds alternately through chalk cliffs andover artificial embankments of the. same material, so strong as to have successfully resisted the storms of the Channel since the day they were made. The tunnels are four in number : — the Martello (530 yards) ; the Abbott's Cliff (1,933 yards) ; the Shakspeaie Cliff— so named from the dramatist's supposed description of it in the tragedy of "King Lear " — (1,392 yards) ; and the Arch Cliff (66 yards) ; — a total length of 3,921 yards of tunnel in the distance of 8,800 lineal yards of road between the two stations. The Shakspeare Cliff Tunnel is of peculiar construction ■ it consists of two separate flutes, each thirty feet high, and of Saracenic architecture, faced throughout with brickwork — except in such places where the hardness of the chalk rendered such precautions unnecessary — the whole being ventilated by seven shafts sunk perpendicularly from the surface of the cliff, and the same number of lateral outlets towards its face, originally made for throwing the excavated matter into the sea. The sea-wall on the Folkestone side is one of the largest works of its kind in England ; it is nearly thr-ou-quarters of a mile long, and elevated from sixty to seventy feet above the beach, being composed en tirely of flint and shingles, consolidated into a compact mass witli lime, thrown down to form the seatings ofthe cliff. Most of this chalk was obtained by the blasting of Roundown Cliff, which was effected by the use of 1,900 lbs. of gunpowder, causing the disintegration of no less than 400,000 cubic yards of rock, which in ten seconds was distributed over eighteen acres of beach. The Company saved about £7,000 in labour v, ages by this skilful and peculiar plan of forming a solid road. The viaduct on the Dover side, between Shakspeare and Arch Cliff Tunnels, though of a different and smaller character, is no less interesting as a result of engineering science ; it is about half a mile long, and formed of heavy beams of timber securely framed and bolted together, but left open so as to offer less resistance to the waves, which fre- quently expend their tremendous force along the whole length of the shore covered by the staging. The lofty viaduct which spans the Ford Valley, south of Folkestone Station, consists of nineteen slender brick arches varying from 40 to 100 feet iu height, surmounted by plain parapets. The town of Folkestone has extended to the village of "Ford, and the viaduct is now surrounded by houses, &c. As the ground on either side slopes rapidly towards the valley, the lofty embankments which were here necessary to maintain the level of the railway add to the apparent depth of the piers and arches, and give them an air of grandeur they would not otherwise posse ss. The viaduct

XIV was built from the plans of Sir William Cubitt, who also designed the sea-walls and tunnels between Folkestone and Dover. The Locomotive and Carriage works* of the Company are at Ashford Junction, a little to the south-west of the station. Between a thousand and twelvo hundred artisans and labourers are employed therein. The natural attractions afforded by the routes of the South Eastern Railway and its branches areas numerous as they are diversified. The precipitous and lock bound coast line — from the North Foreland to Hastings — varied here aud there with bustling ports, picturesque fishing-villages, fashionable marine resorts, ancient strongholds and fortifications, and enchanting inland prospects ; the verdant slopes and wooded knolls of the north Downs, extending from Guildford to Tunbridge ; and the sylvan vales and undulating parklauds — embosoming rustic hamlets — historic cities and mansions, aud venerable ruins of the Wealds of Kent and Sussex, all make up an enticing programme for the tourist aud pleasure-seeker, and aro material factors, with unsurpassed Continental communications and valuable commercial connections, in ensuring a continuanco of that successful career, which from the date of its opening, nearly half a century ago, has distinguished this popular " Iron Road." XV THE SOUTH EASTERN RAILWAY. GENERAL REGULATIONS AND INFORMATION. London Time is observed at all the Stations. Tickets and Change. — Passengers should Examino their Tickets and Change before leaving the Booking-Ostice counter, as errors cannot afterwards be rec tified. Re-booking. — Passengers cannot be re-booked at an intermediate Station by the samo Train from which they have alighted. Passengers are not allowed to break their journey with the same Ticket at an intermediate Station. No Money Returned.— No Money is returned or allowance made for any Ticket lost, mislaid, or not used. Travelling in Private Carriage?. — Passengers travelling iii Private Carriages (not being Servants) are required to take First Class Tickets. Such Passengers may remove during the journey to the Company's First Class Carriages, if there be room in them. Servants travelling with Private Carriages will be charged Second Class Fares, and may iemove to Second Class Carriages provided there be room. Children under three years op age travel free; above three, and under twelve, half-price. Junctions where Change of Carriage.— Passengers travelling between Stations on the Main and Branch Lines should observe that they may have to change Caniages at the respective Junctions, viz. : — To or from the Caterham Branch, at Caterham Junction— Reading Branch, at Red Hill — Tunbridge Wells and Hastings Branch, at Tunbridge — Maidstoue Branch, at Paddock Wood— Ramsgate Branch, at Ashford — Ashford and Hastings Branch, at Ashford — Deal Branch, at Ashford and Minster — Whitstable Branch, at Canterbury — Margate Branch, at Ramsgate — Folkestone Harbour, at Folkestone. Befreshment Rooms are provided at the following Stations : — Chariug Cross, Cannon Street, London Bridge Station (High and Low Level), Red Hill, Tunbridge, Paddock Wood, Ashford, Dover, Folkestone Harbour, Strood, Canterbury, Minster, Bamsgate and Margate. Ladies' Waiting Rooms. — Females are in attendance at the following Stations : — Charing Cross, Cannon Street, London Bridge, Greenwich, Red Hill, Sevenoaks, Tunbridge, Tunbridge Wells, Ashford, Folkestone, Folkestone Harbour, Dover, Reading, Maidstone, Canterbury, Margate and Ramsgate. Passengers' Luggage. — First Class Passengers are allowed 120 lbs. of Luggage, Second Class 100 lbs., aud Third Class 60 lbs., Free of Charge, such Lugaage being of the description mentioned in the Company's Acts of Parliament. The Company are in no way responsible for any articles other than of the descrip tion mentioned, unless booked and paid for separately. Children who pay half fare are allowed half the foregoing quantity. Overweight is charged Is. 6d. per cwt, locally between the London Stations : Charing Cross, Waterloo, Cannon

XVI Street, and London Bridge ; -Jd. per ib. for any distance under 40 miles, and Jd. per lb. for conveyance by the boat between Folkestone and Boulogne, and Dover and Calais ; _d- per lb. for 40 miles, and any distance exceeding 40 miles. Commercial Travellers' Excess Luggage, if Conveyed at their own risk. — Commercial Travellers are allowed free of charge double the weight of Luggage allowed to other passengers according to class. The excess weight is charged half the Ordinary Excess Luggage Rates, but no charge is made unless amounting to One Shilling and upwards. If at the Company's risk the Ordinary Rates. Commercial Travellers are allowed to book their Luggage from the Station whence they start to the Station to which their day's journey is to extend, whether it be a return journey or otherwise, although they may have occasion to stop during their day's business at intermediate Stations, provided the destination be declared at the commencement of the day's journey, and the Luggage Ticket given up at the termination. The Fares for Extra Luggage should in every case be prepaid ; but in the event of its being overlooked at the starting Station, the Luggage is liable to be charged at the end of the journey-. Luggage to be Claimed and Labelled. — Passengers are required, after taking their tickets, to claim their Luggage on the platform, and to see it marked with the Company's labels, at least five minutes before the departure of the Train for which it is intended ; and no Luggage will be placed in the Train until it is so marked. The Company is not responsible for the loss or detention of any article of Luggage that is not marked with their label, and properly addressed. All Passengers' Luggage is conveyed subject to the conditions upon which goods are carried by the Company. Old Labels. — Passengers should be careful to clear their Luggage of all old Railway or other labels before commencing each journey, and have their existing address plainly and securely placed on each Package. They are recommended to take carpet bags and small articles into the carriage with them. All Unclaimed Property found on the Company's premises, or iu their Car riages, is deposited in the Lost Property Office, at the Cannon Street Terminus. If there be an address on the articles found, notice is sent to that address that the property is in the Company's possession ; and if there be no address thereon, the packages are opened at the expiration of one week, with a view to ascertain the address of the owner, when notice is forwarded to him, and the property in either case restored to the owner on payment of a fee of 6d. for each article, or forwarded, if desired, at the usual Parcels' Rates. An additional charge of 6d. per week is made after the expiration of the first week on each article left for a longer period. Cloak Room. — The Company is not responsible for articles left by Passengers at the Station unless the same be duly registered, for which a charge of 2d. per article is made. Carriages, Horses, Dogs, and Loaded Carriages must be at the Station half an hour before the time specified for the departure of the Train. All Dogs travelling with Passengers, or sent booked alone, must be provided with collars and chains. The rates for the conveyance of Private Carriages do not include luggage contaiued therein ; such luggage is subject to an additional charge. Carriages loaded with luggage are charged a rate and a half. Horse clothing and private carriage covers, when returned, after being used in covering consignments by South Eastern Railway, are charged as returned empties. The Mail Boats and Mail Trains do not wait for Passengers or Baggage after the Mails are loaded. The other Trains and Boats do not await each other when detained by stress of weather or casualty. Information and Enquiries. — The Company is not responsible for information given by any other person than tho Officers in charge at the different Stations. AU enquiries relative to the service of the Line, addressed to the Manager, London Bridge Terminus, receive immediate attention. ' Ladies' Carriage. — A Carriage is reserved for ladies when required.

2 "Ct'lt On Christmas Day and Good Friday the Trains run as on Sundays, with tho exception of the Mail Trains, and the addition of Special Excursion Trains. Change of Carriage avoided. — Families, or any number of First Class Pas sengers above six, proceeding from any Station on the Branch Lines to the sea-side, or vice versa, are allowed the accommodation of keeping the same carriage for them selves and Baggage throughout the journey. Previous notice should be given to the Station Master. Delivery of Luggage. — Luggage is collected or delivered to or from any part of London within a radius of three miles from Somerset House, at a moderate charge. Also delivered or collected at the principal country Stations, viz., Hastings, St. Leonards, Ramsgate, Margate, Maidstone, Dover, Folkestone, Tunbridge Wells, Canterbury, Chatham, Woolwich, Reading, Aldershot Camp, (fee. Application to be made to the respective Station Masters. Passengers Booked between Hastings and any Station below Ashford, on the Dover and Margate Lines, also the Main Line Stations between Tunbridge and Ahhford, are allowed to travel either way, viz. , via Tunbridge or Ashford, as the Trains may best suit, the Tickets being available only for the Station for which issued. To avoid Delay and Confusion at Stations, Passengers with much luggage should be at the Station in good time. This particularly applies to the country Stations. The Company's arrangements are much facilitated if a day's notice be given to the respective country Station Masters by families or parties intending to travel with large quantities of Luggage by any particular Train. USEFUL HINTS TO CONTINENTAL TRAVELLERS Conversation. — English is spoken in most of the Continental Hotels, and there are interpreters at all the principal stations. Passports are not required by travellers of British nationality, except in Portugal, Russia^ and Turkey, but they are always useful to establish identity, and are recommended. The Registration of Baggage saves the passenger from all trouble and expense of landing and shit ping the baggage and conveying it between the train and boat, harbour clues, and other imposts hitherto made ; secures an allowance (25 kilos, or 50 lbs.) of baggage free of charge ; also tho privilege of paying before departure the oharge for the conveyance of excess baggage, according to a fixed through rate. This registration may be made as under : — Destination. By way of Baggage examined at Destination. By way of Baggage examined at Paris Brussels, Antwerp,Liege, Spa and Verviers ... Brussels, Antwerp ,Liege, Spa, Verviers, Ghent, Bruges, Ostend and Louvain Aix-la-Chapelle Ditto Amiens, LiUe, Ghent, Roubaix & Tonrcoing Cologne, Bonn,Coblence, Muyence & Frankfort (O.M.) Bitto ditto Boulogne or Calais | Calais |- Ostend Paris. Blandain Rotterdam — Any German Station, including Au str i a (Via Herbesthal) Calais ... Any German Station (Via Bleyherg) Aix-la- Chapelle. J Calais... Ostend Boulogne or Calais Y Calais Ostend Aix-la-ChpU. Ditto. Boulogne or Calais. Any Russian Station... Any Swiss Station ... XVIII In travelling from Brussels to Cologne by express train, if the luggage is regis tered it is examined by the German Customs at Cologne, if unregistered at Verviers. In travelling from Cologne lo Brussels or Antwerp, luggage is examined at Verviers. In travelling between Cologne and Rotterdam or Amsterdam, luggage is examined at Zevenaar. Luggage registered through from London to Paris is examined on arrival at Paris ; if not registered through it is examined at tho landing port. Lug gage cannot be registered from London beyond Paris; Luggage coming from Switz erlaud is examined at the frontiers of the neighbouring States. Luggage may ba registered through from Paris to Turin or Milan and examined at Modane, and coming from Turin it is examined at Modane, or in some eases it is examined on arrival at Paris. In returning from the Continent to London the luggage is examined at Boulogne and Dover on Sundays whenever the arrival at those places occurs between the Saturday and Sunday afternoon ordinary services. Where the passenger in tends to stop short of the final destination shown by his through ticket, he should register only to the first point at which he desires to break the journey. Baggage is registered by all through services, but only on the production of the passenger's through ticket at the registration office ten minutes before the time fixed for the departure of the train. Passengers are recommended to register their baggage in all cases by the mail trains, otherwise it may be detained at the landing port for the following train. The Railway Company does not undertake to register baggage unless the passenger, with the baggage and through ticket, be on tho platform of the station ten minutes in advance of the time fixed for the departure of the train. The baggage ticket must be given up before the baggage can be delivered at destination. Each package should have the name and address of the owner distinctly marked thereon, and all old luggage labels should be removed. Merchandise registered as baggage is liable to detention and seizure by the Customs ; and passengers are cautioned against registering articles of the description of mer chandise, or that are not for personal use. Passengers should personally claim their baggage on arriving at the point to which registered, and give notice immediately to the station master if anything is wrong, giving a description and list of the contents of aDy packages missing. Customs Examination. — Passengers are required to be present at the examina tion of their baggage by the Customs officers at the different frontiers. The com panies do not undertake any duty in connection with such examination on the Continent, nor to be responsible fur same, nor for any delay or loss arising from passengers not having been present at the examination at any of the Custom House towns named herein. Passengers should especially note that baggage registered for the German stations will not be forwarded beyond Aix-la-Chapelle or Cologne until examined by the Customs there, ivhich can only be done in the presence of the owner or person acting for him. The owner is liable in Belgium and Germany to a duty of about ls. 6d. per 100 lbs. weight. Passengers who register their baggage for Cologne, and who subsequently desire to have it at Brussels, should claim it at Blandain or Mous cron, where, as a favour, it may be given up by the station master. At Lille, pas sengers are required to say by what route they wish to proceed — either via Ghent or Tournay — in order that the baggage may be put in the proper wagon. Baggage registered from Paris to London by the night services is examined at the landing port. Baggage being conveyed from the east weshoard, destined for Belgium, is examined at Verviers. Baggage passing through Belgium for either France or England, is not examined at all by the Belgian Customs. Baggage registered to Dover must be de clared at starting for one or the other of the Custom houses there, whether the South Eastern or the London Chatham and Dover. Baggage registered at Cologne for London is examined at Verviers, should the traveller subsequently determine on stopping in Belgium. If desirous to stop in France, his baggage is examined there, and not in Belgium. Baggage from Belgium booked direct "to England via, Calais, by Ghent and Mouscron, or by Tournay and Blandain, is free from examina tion at the French frontiers. It is examined at London in all cases when regis tered thereto, except where conveyed by the boat leaving Ostend at 8.0 p.m., when it is examined at Dover ; unless the passenger elects to have it forwarded by

XIX the 4.15 a.m. train from Dover, in which case it is examined at London, if registered thereto. Where there is time, the baggage can be examined at Dover, if so desired by the owners. When the arrival in England takes place on Sundays, the Customs' examination is made at the port of arrival, except baggage registered to Charing Cross arriving on Sunday afternoon, which is examined the same as on week daj s at London. Notwithstanding the above regulations, all trunks or parcels which have to pass a frontier, must be given up at starting, and are conveyed in the Customs' truck. This regulation applies even to hat boses and necessaries. Any luggage Tcept in the carriages up to any frontier town — for instance, Verviers — must be re-booked there, and is sent on by an after train, as express goods. Some French Goods — as New Clothes, Millinery, Printed or Dyed Cotton, Woollen and Linen Fabrics, Silk, <fcc. — are charged at a reduced rate of duty on entering Belgium. But to obtain this reduction, it is necessary to have a certificate, termed " certificat d'origine'' from the French Customs, and to present this with the goods at the Belgian Customs. On this system, Silk, for instance, pays 4 francs instead of 10 for each kilogramme. Travellers can obtain the necessary paper at the Bureau de la Douane, at Paris. All packages of luggage registered from abroad, if not cleared from the Custom House on the day of arrival, are deposited in the Customs baggage warehouse, and charged for at the rate of Id. per package per day. The Mail Boats and Mail Trains do not wait for Passengers or Baggage after the Mails are loaded. The other Trains and Boats do not await each other when detained by stress of weather or casualty. Passengers to Paris or Brussels by the Mail Services should be careful to ascertain that they enter the right train at Calais. The Paris night mail train leaves first, and the Brussels train a few minutes later ; but the day mail for Brussels leaves first. French Money Exchanges can be obtained in exchange for English Money, at the rate of 25 fr. for one sovereign, on application at the Harbour Station, Dover. There is also an Exchange Office in the Station at Calais. Tickets to be kept in Readiness. — Passengers should have their Tickets ready to show at the Stair-landing at the Steam Boats, before going on board, and to deliver on leaving the Boats. English Customs. — Foreign Goods, subject to duty, -packed within articles of apparel, or otherwise concealed, are, as well as the articles in which they may be placed, liable to forfeiture, and Passengers are therefore apprised that the forfeiture in all such cases will be strictly enforced, unless the attention of the examining officer be called thereto, and the Goods duly declared previously to the opening of the Packages. Smoking is prohibited in the carriages, except in the compartments set apart for the purpose. A Carriage for the exclusive use of Ladies is reserved both on the South Eastern and Northern of France Railways. Coupe Carriages. — On the Northern of France Railway Passengers travelling in Coup<5 Carriages are required to pay extra Fare for the accommodation, according to distance. Invalid Carriages. — On the Northern of France, and also the Lyons Railway, there are " Coupes lits " for sick travellers. The Ordinary Carriage on the Northern lias places for eight passengers. Passengers should be at the Station fifteen minutes before the time of starting, and be provided with the exact amount of their fare, to avoid the delay caused by receiving change. Luggage should be taken to the station a quarter of an hour before the time of starting. It can be insured by payment of an additional sum of ten centimes on 100 francs worth. Travellers should remove all old addresses, and have their own

XX very legibly written. They may not take any luggage into the carriage weighing more than 50 lbs., and only such as can be placed under the seate without inconve nience. SUGGESTIONS FOR VISITORS TO THE FRENCH CAPITAL. Demeanour. — To insure that world-renowned civility from French servants, officials and others, the visitor should be thoroughly courteous when making a request, or even when ordering refreshments at a cafe or restaurant. It is customary to address even persons of the lower classes as Monsieur, Madame, or Mademoiselle. The policemen, who are to be met with in every street and place of public resort, are always ready tc furnish strangers with every information in their power. Cabs and Public Carriages, — Paris is well supplied with public carriages of all kinds. The omnibuses are numerous and well-conducted, but slow. The price is. 30 c. (3d.) for the inside places, and 15 c. for the outside (imperiale). Almost all are in correspondence, and the passengers may claim a ticket of correspondence to go on by another omnibus if the one he gets into does not reach his destination. Care should be taken to tell the conductor on entering what part of Paris it is desired to reach. The omnibuses of the various lines are all indicated by letters of the alphabet, and colours. These different colours are used in the various quarters or divisions of Paris for all public purposes. "For fiacres or cabs, the fares are about one shilling for the course, as it is called, if not exceeding a quarter of an hour, and a little more for the longer courses. The price per hour is 2 frs. Full statements of the fares will be found suspended in all the carriages, and the driver must give the passenger a printed ticket of particulars, <fcc. The prices are nearly double between midnight and 6 a.m. in summer, or 7 a.m. in winter. Besides the fiacres (or voitures de place), there are a somewhat superior class of vehicles, belonging to private individuals, and known as voitures de remise. They are better fitted and travel more quickly. The fare for the short course is 1 fr. 50 c, for the longer 2 frs. By the hour 2 fr. 25 c. The visitor to Paris should learn the colour that belongs to the lanterns of the quarter of the city he resides in, and select cabs with lanterns of this colour on returning home. Places of Amusement. — The following establishments are the most frequented : — Conservatoire de Musique (classical music) ; Herz, Sainte-Ce'cile, Pre Catelan, Erard, Pleyel and Sox concert halls. The concerts of the Cafes Chantants are of an inferior description. Those in the Champ-Elysees attract numerous visitors in summer. The foUowing are among the best establishments : Eldorado, Alcazar, Cafe-Concert Bataclan, and Gi-and Concert Parisien. Of Soirees Musicales et Dansantes, the most frequented in summer are Jardin Mabille (balls on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays, and Sundays ; admission, 3 and 5 francs) ; Closerie des Lilas, {Jardin Bullier) ; the Chateau Rouge. In winter : Salle Valentino Casino, rua Cadet; Elysee-Montniai-tre. The Cascade Cafe', in tho Bois de Boulogne, and the Casino d'Asnieres are favourite summer resorts. The Masked Balls of the Grand Opera last from the middle of December till Lent, and take place every Saturday evening (admission 10 fr.). Theatres. — There are nearly 50 in Paris. The performances commence at various hours between 6 and 8 o'clock, and last till midnight. The best places are the stalls in. front of the orchestra (fauteuils d'orchestre), behind which are the stalles d'orchestre ; those behind the pit (stalles d'amphithe'dtre), and those in front of the first tier of boxes (fauteuils de balcon, de la premiere galerie). Ladies are not admitted in some theatres to the orchestra stalls. In the case of popular performances, seats should be secured by purchasing billets de location beforehand at the location office des theatres. These billets cost 1 or 2 francs more than those bought at the door, but the purchaser thereby reserves his seat. Hotels, Cafes, and Restaurants. — Although attendance is always an item in the hotel-bill, it is usual to give the head-waiter and the concierge a fee of 1 or 2

XXI frs. per week, and the under-waiter by whom the traveller has been served, about 2 frs. In a few instances the payment for service is left to the discretion of the traveller, who is expected to give J or 1 fr. daily. Au occasional extra gratuity will greatly tend to ensure civility. Visitors should avoid keeping articles of value in the drawers or cupboards of their rooms. They should be entrusted to the care of the landlord, or sent to a banker. The cafe's of Paris are one of the characteristic features of the city. They are to be found in all quarters of the town, and some are fitted up with great splendour. They are adapted for the entertainment of all classes of society. Billiards, cribbage and dominoes are allowed in Parisian cafe's. The traveller should select restaurants of the best class, at which a simple repast of 2 or 3 courses may be obtained for a reasonable sum. The visitor is not expected to drink expensive wines. The waiter expects about 1 sou on each franc spent. Ladies •can dine at restaurants without attracting the observation which is so noticeable in London establishments. Money, Weights, and Measures. — The French coinage is very simple, and easily understood; it is divided into tenths, on the decimal system. The coins ■consist of centimes (a " sous " is equal to 5 centimes) and francs. 100 centimes •(or 20 sous) make a franc. 20 franc gold pieces were formerly styled Napoleons. For all ordinary dealings the visitor may calculate the franc as worth led. in English money. As the franc is actually worth only 9-Jd., if a halfpenny be taken off the value of each franc in making a calculation, the exact British equivalent will be found. The coinage system of Belgium, Italy, and Switzerland are similar to those of France, and equivalent in value. Tbe franc becomes lira (singular), and lire (plural) ; the centime, centesimi, in Italian. In Holland 5 cents are about equivalent to ld. ; 1 florin or guilder (100 cents) to about Is. 7d. ; 1 gold ducat to about 9s. 4d.; and 1 gold 10- florin piece to about 16s. 6d. In Germany 12 pfennige are about equivalent to ld. ; 1 mark (100 pfennige) to ls. ; 20-mark piece (gold) to £1. The kilogramme, or kilo, as it is generally called, is the French ordinary weight by which goods sold by weight are quoted. It is equal to 2 lb3. 3\ ozs. avoirdupois ; a pound of any article is nearly equivalent to about a demi-kilo, which is 1 lb. IJ oz. avoirdupois. The unit of length is the metre, which is about 39 inches English ; 5-J metres, nearly 6 yards ; 10 metres, 11 yards. The metre is divided into 100 centimetres. The kilometre is the road measure — 3 miles are equal nearly to 5 kilometres ; 8 kilometres are 5 miles ; 10 kilometres are 6 J miles ; 100 kilometres, 63 miles. The ■same measurement is also used in Belgium, Italy, Portugal and Spain. Liquid and dry measures are calculated by the litre, about 1| pint. An ordinary .French wine bottle contains about a litre.

æ-m LONDON HACKNEY CARRIAGE REGULATIONS, AND LIST OF FARES, TO AND FROM THE PRINCIPAL RAILWAY STATIONS' TO THE POINTS NAMED. The driver shall deliver a ticket to the hirer on entering th,e carriage when demanded. Fares for hackney carriages are according to distance or time, at the option of the hirer, expressed at the commencement of the hiring ; if not otherwise expressed, the fare to be paid according to distance. No driver is compellable to hire his carriage for a fare according to time, at any time after eight o'clock in the evening and before six o'clock in the morning. Agreement with driver to pay more than legal fare not binding — sum paid beyond fare may be recovered. Driver not to charge more than the sum agreed on for driving a distance, although such dis tance be exceeded by the driver. If proprietor or driver agreed beforehand to take for any job any sum less than the proper fare, penalty for exacting or demanding more than the sum agreed on 40s. Driver may demand a reasonable sum as a deposit, from persons hiring and requiring him to wait, over and above the fare to which driver is entitled for driving thither. Penalty 40s. if driver refuse to wait, or go away before expiration of time for which deposit shall be sufficient compensation ; or if driver shall refuse to account for such deposit. Hirer refusing to pay fare, or for any damage and compensation for loss of time, may be committed to prison. A diiver, if hired by distance, shall not be compelled to drive more than six miles ; and if hired by time, shall not be compelled to drive for more than one hour. Fares by Time for Two Persons. If hired and discharged within the 4-mile circle : — For any time not exceeding one hour, if a 4-wheel carriage, 2s. ; if a 2-wheel carriage, 2s. 6d. Sixpence for every fifteen minutes, or any part of fifteen minutes not completed, above one hour, if a 4-wheel carriage ; 8d. if a 2-wheel carriage. If hired without the 4-mile circle, whether discharged within or loithout the 4-mile circle' — Whether a 2-wheel or a 4-wheel carriage : For any time not exceeding one hour, 2s. 6d. ; if the time exceeds one hour, 8d. for every 15 minutes or part of 15 minutes. If hired within, but discharged without, the 4-mile circle, same fares as in preceding paragraph. No driver shall demand or receive any sum by way of Back Fare, for the return of the carriage from the place at which discharged. Fares by Distance. If hired and discharged within the 4-mile circle (i.e. four miles any way from Charing Cross) : — One Shilling for any distance not exceeding two miles. For any distance exceed- ing two miles, at the rate of sixpence for every mile and for every part of a mile not completed. If hired without the 4-mile circle, whether discharged within or without the 4-mile circle :— One Shilling for every mile, or part of a mile. If hired within, but discharged without the 4-mile circle : — If the distance does not exceed one mile, Is. If the distance exceeds one mile : For each mile ended within the 4-mile circle, 6d. ; for each mile ended without the 4-mile circle, Is. ; for any part of a mile ended without the- 4-mile circle over and above any number of miles completed, ls. When the driver, to be paid according to distance, shall be required hy the hirer to stop for fifteen minutes, or for any longer time, the driver may demand and receive a further sum (above the fare to which he shall be entitled, calculated according to distance), of sixpence for every fifteen minutes completed, either in one or more stoppages, that he shall have been so stopped. Fares by Distance or Time for more than Two Persons. — When more than two persons are carried by any hackney carriage, the sum of 6d. is to be paid for each person above the number of two, for the whole hiring, in addition to the fares by distance or time for two persons. Two children under ten years of age to be considered as one adult. One child under ten years to be charged 3d. Luggage.— A sum of 2d. for every package carried outside the carriage is to be paid. The Down Journey is arranged with a rearward view, and the Up Journey with a forward view, to facilitate instant reference. If the passenger be sitting in an opposite direc- tion to that indicated in the Companion, it must be remembered that the objects named are on the side of the Eailway whereon the train is travelling. The Eeferences to Objects and Places of Interest are indicated in the Companion as approximately as is possible to their exact situations on the routes. The Trunk Line or Lines [the South Eastern Eailway may be said to have two trunk lines from Tunbridge Junction upwards — one to London via Sevenoaks— now the recognized main line — and one to London via Eed Hill and Croydon — the old main line] are first described, and then the various branches from junction to junction or junction to terminus. The Figures parallel with the names of stations on the Down Lines show the distance from the starting point of the trunk, branch, or junction, and the same explanation applies to the figures on the Up Lines. The figures in parentheses indicate tha nearest distance from London by the Eailway. The Junctions of the South Eastern Ss'stem are signified by thick rules above and below the references ; and the Junctions of other Eailways by thin rules above and below the references.

THE SOUTH EASTERN RAILWAY. 90 THE JOINT LIME (S. E. AND L. C. & D. RAILWAYS) FROM AND TO DOVER AND DEAL. This Railway — completed in 1880 — debouches from the South Eastern Railway at the Pier at Great Street, Dover, passing over Council House and other streets, r and from thence runs on to the London Chatham and Dover Railway to Bucldand (north of Dover Priory Station), where it curves off at a junction in Crabble Meadow, makes a detour round the hill at the back of Barton, and enters Guston Tunnel (1,412 yards long), at the rear of Charlton Cemetery. It emerges again in a deep cutting between Guston and Langdon, and proceeds thence to Martin, where there is a Station (5^ miles from Dover ; 4£ miles from Deal), convenient for St. Margaret's, West Cliffe, Ringwould, Sutton, West and East Langdon, and Guston. Beyond Martin Station to Walmer the line passes through another cutting. At Walmeris another station (8J miles from Dover; 1} from Deal), and from thence the line passes into the South Eastern Railway at Deal. There is a loop line at Minster to facilitate the direct traffic between this line and Ramsgate and Margate. THE HUNDRED OF HOO (ISLE OF GRAIN) RAILWAY. The Railway Company was incorporated by an Act of 21st July, 1879 — extended by Act ot 2nu August, 1880 — to construct a line from Shorne, near Higham, in the county of Kent, to St. James's in the Isle of Grain — total length, nearly 13 miles. The raUway is in course of construction (1881), and is to be completed within five years from the date of incorpora- tion. At St. James's there will be a deep-sea pier, with which a direct Belgian, Dutch, and German steam-ship service will be connected. The new pier and harbour will be named Port Victoria. (See also page 87). THE BRANCH LINE FROM AND TO CATERHAM JUNCTION AND CATERHAM. „ „, . ABBEY WOOD— (STATION.)— This place is a hamlet within the civil parish of Erith and the ecclesiastical district of Belvedere, in the county of Kent (see under both these heads). It comprises a portion of Lesness Heath, (which gives name to the hundred), and is renowned for the monastery which once existed here. Some extensive frag ments of boundary wall comprise the sole remains of this once thriving estab lishment. Lesness Abbey was founded ia the year 1178, by Richard de Lucy, Lord Chief Justice of England in the reign of Henry IL, and during the king's absence in France, regent of the kingdom. It was one of the first religious houses swept off at the Reformation, and its revenues of nearly £200 per annum went to endow Wolsey's new college at Oxford. Oa the fall of the cardinal, however, the abbey estates were given to William Brereton, a gentleman of the Privy Chamber, and eventually, in the reign of Charles I., came into the possession of Sir John Hippesley. At this time an inte resting discovery was made by some workmen, who, in digging, found " a goodly funerall monument" of a man in coat armour, supposed by Wee ver to be the monument of Richard de Lucy, founder of Lesness. This, with other curious relics found at the same time, was, it is said, buried again, but all traces of them have been lost, From certain indications in the boundary wall, it would appear that the church was originally about 40 feet wide and 97 feet in length, and that the tower, a structure only about 17 feet square, abutted against the northern side of the church, between the nave and the chancel, of which it formed a compouent part. A doorway, apparently of the time of Edward I., still exists at the south-western corner of the garden, and seems to have been the principal en trance into the abbey, opening into the cloisters beneath the refectory, which stood on the southern side of tho quad rangle, opposite the church, the kitchen adjoining. The dormitory surmounted the cloisters, and the rest of the buildings contained the chapter-house and the conventual offices. The convent garden still remains enclosed within its ancient boundary wall. The abbey and manor now belong to Christ's Hospital. The southern outfall of the Metropolitan sewer is situate about a mile and a half from this station, on the river bank ; the reservoir and engine-house were constructed in 1863. Average Train Service : Ten trains each way on week days, and about the same num ber on Sundays. Fares from London : 2/- /, 1/4 s, 1/- t. Return Tickets (4 days), 3/3/, 2/3 s, 1/9/, ALBUR Y.— (Station — CHIL- W0RTH--2 miles.)--A parish and village iu thecounty of Surrey (western division); in Guildford union, petty sessional divi sion and county court district. The village is beautifully situated amidst the North Downs. Albury Park is one of the seats of the Duke of Northumber land. The parish church is a gothic brick building, recently restored by the duke. Area : 3,470 acres. Population: 1,164. ALLINGTON.—(Station-MAID STONE—2 miles.)— A parish of tho county of Kent (mid division) ; Mailing union, and Maidstone county court dis trict and petty sessional division. Tlie ruins of Arlington Castle, the residence of Sir Thomas Wyatt, temp. Henry Vis., attract visitors ; they are now the pro perty of the Earl of Romney. Area: 601 acres. Population: 93. APPLEDpRE.— (STATION.)-A village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in Tenterden union aud county court district and Ashford petty sessional division. The parish is included in Romney Marsh (which see), and the Royal Military Canal passes through it. The church is ancient, and possesses traces of interesting architecture. From its elevated position an extensive view of the marsh is obtained. Atea: 3,009 acres. Population : 671. Average Train Service ; Four each way on week days ; five each way on Sundays. ASH.— (STATION.)— A viUage and parish of the county of Surrey (western division) ; in Farnham union and county court district, and Guildford petty ses sional division. The largo hamlet of Normandy and the ecclesiastical district of Frimley are included in the parish. which is served by four stations, two on the South Eastern line, and the others on the South Western line. The manor of Ash formerly belonged to the Abbey of Chertsey, and at the dissolution it was given to St. Mary's College, at Win chester. The parish church is ancient. Area: 12,434 acres. Population (in cluding Normandy and Frimley) : 4,828. Average Train Service .- Eight each way on week days ; two each way on Sun days. Fares from London : 5/- /, 3/6 s, 2/6 t. Return Tickets (8 days), 7/6 /, ASHFORD.— (JUNCTION STA TION.) — A market town, parish, and urban sanitary district of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in West Ashford union and Ashford county court district and petty sessional division. The name Aldershot and Fareham county court district, and Odiham petty sessional division. In 1854, when the camp was formed, the population numbered less than 900 ; now (1880) it is estimated at 13,000. Aldershot is the fourth largest. town in Hampshire, and is well built, drained, and lighted. The parish church of St. Michael is an unpretending edifice, dating in parts from the twelfth century ; it contains memorials of the Tichborne family, who were formerly lords of oDe of the manors in the parish. All Saints' military church was built in 1863, at a cost of -£10,000, aud is a fine structure. Holy Trinity Church was erected in 1878. There aro numerous chapels in the place. The i amp occupies the site of the Common, which was pur chased by the Government in 1854. There are three sets of cavalry barracks for the cavalry regiments which form the cavalry brigade ; three blocks of bar racks for three infantry regiments, which form the 2ud Infantry Biigade; a large block of barrack and stabling, which is occupied by the Royal Horse and Royal Artillery ; and these, with the ne cessary riding-schools, guard-houses, and one building, form the permanent bar racks. The 1st Infantry Brigade, con sists.g of four regiments, are housed in wooden huts, which are now being re placed as they decay by brick buildings. The 3rd Infantry Brigade, of four regi ments, are quartered in similar huts, which are known as the North Camp. Besides the above, there are barracks and huts for the Royal Engineers, Army Service Corps, and Army Hospital Corps. The winter strength of this division, which is under the command of a Lieu tenaut-General, is from 10,000 to 15,C00. There is a large hospital which cost £40,000 ; and on the Farnham Road tbe Government has erected a large Lock Hospital. The Queen has a pavilion, which she occupies when she visits the camp. During the summer months the division is increased to 20,000, by the regulars and reserves assembling for summer drill. Area : 4,173 acres. Population : About 25,000 (including military). Newspapers : Camp Gazette (i.), Friday, Jd. Aldershot Gazette (n.), Saturday, ld. Principal Hotel : Royal. Average Train Service : Ten each way on week days ; three on Sundays. Fares

■2,', of the place is derived from the stream on which it is situated — the Esshet, a tributary of the river Stour. The town has much increased of late years, owing to the fact of its being the chief depot and locomotive and carriage factory of the South Eastern Railway. The works are situate in what is called the new town (or Alfred, as originally named by the Com- pany as owners), which is a populous hamlet, partly in the parish of Ashford, partly in Willesborough. It is about a mile from Ashford. A large and hand- some building is provided for educating the children of the Company's servants, and a new church to accommodate 600 worshippers was erected in 1867, to a con- siderable extent by the subscriptions of South Eastern shareholders. Between 1,003 and 1,200 persons are employed at the works. (See page xiv.) The parish church, dedicated to St. Mary, is a hand some structure, restored and beautified with much skill aud judgment, and a new and most magnificent stained-glass west window introduced. It illustrates a series of events in the life of ou_ blessed Lord. The church is cross-shaped, in the per- pendicular style, and consists of a nave and two aisles, with transepts, three chancels, and a lofty tower, with four pinnacles, built by Sir John Fogge, lord of Repton, in this parish, in the reign of Edward IV. Sir John was Comptroller of the Household to that monarch, and obtained leave to make the church colle- giate, consisting of a prebendary, with priests and choristers. His tomb, with that of his two wives, is in the high chancel, and bears the date of 1490. Among the ancient monuments in this church is one over 500 years old. It represents the figure of a woman in brass, holding iu her hand a bauner, and commemorates a Countess .of Athol. There are also several monu- parish that the late Rev. R. H. Barhani, author of the " Ingoldsby Legends," ob- tained his first curacy. There are also a national school, a mechanics' institution containing nine hundred volumes, and a South Eastern Railway Mechanics' In- stitute with a good library. A new corn exchange was opened in 1861. There are several places of worship for dissenters. The old market-house is situated in the centre of tho town. Robert Glover, a laborious antiquary, was born here ; also, Dr. Wallis.the celebrated mathematician . The family of Osborne, Duke of Leeds, were of this town. The old custom of gavelkindyetprevailsin themanor. Shak- speare mention** Ashford in his beautiful play of Henry VI., as the birthplace of Cade, "the lusty Kentish captain." Market Days: Every Tuesday (corn); first, third, and fifth (cattle). Fairs : May 17 and 18 ; September 9 ; and Oc- tober 12, 13, and 24. Area : 2,829 acres. Population : 8,458. AYLESFORD.— (STATION.)— A large village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in Mailing union, Maidstone county court district, aDd Lathe of Aylesford (Maidstone) petty sessional division. The river Medway flows through the village, and is navi- gable at this point. Aylesford was for- merly a town of some note, and derives its name from the ford which here crossed the river. It is mentioned in Domesday Book. The church, built in the 14th century, was restored in 1878. The remains of a monastery of Carme- lite friars are to be seen at Conington within the parish. The Britons under Catigern, defeated the Saxons under Horsa at this place in 455, both leaders being slain. It was also the scene of a conflict between Canute and Edmund Ironsides. There are numerous ancient British and Roman relics scattered over the parish, and these form a source of attraction to antiquarians. Many articles of historical interest discovered here are to be seen in the Maidstone Museum. Area : 4,372. Population : 2,100. Average ments to the family of Smythe, with which Viscount Strangford is con nected. The tower of the church con tains eight fine-toned bells, on which airs are performed by chimes every three hours. Within a quarter of a mile, upon the north side, is a large cemetery ; it is laid out with much taste, and contains two chapels and a lodge. There is a Free Grammar School at Ashford, founded by Sir Norton Knatchbull, in the reign of Charles I. It was in this
