BATTLE.— (STATION.)— A mar ket town, parish and urban sanitary dis trict of the county of Sussex (eastern division) ; in Battle union and petty ses sional division, and Hastings county court district. The ancient name of the place was Epiton, but it takes its present one from the celebrated Battle of Senlac (more generally called Hast ings), fought in the year 1066, between William of Normandy and Harold, the last of the Saxon kings. Battle Abbey, now the seat of the Duke of Cleveland, K.G., was founded by William, and dedicated to St. Martin, in commemora tion of the struggle, the high altar occupying the spot where the Saxon royp.l standard was placed. In the Abbey was preserved the celebrated Battle Abbey Roll, which formed a list of those families which came over with William. The great hall is remarkable for its timber roof ; it is 57 feet in length, the same in height, and 31 feet wide. The gate-house, or entrance from the town, directly fronts the street from the London-road : it is a tower, about 35 feet square and 54 feet high, comprising three stories, with an oc tagon turret at each angle, and is thought to have been erected some- • where about the time of Edward III., when the Abbey was enclosed and for tified ; it is one of the most perfect specimens of monastic gate-houses in the kingdom. The ruins of the Abbey cover three sides of a square. There are nine elegant arches remaining of the Abbey church : tho public are admitted to view the Abbey on Tuesdays. The church of St. Mary was founded by Ralph, Abbot of Battle from 1107 to 1124. The font is a good specimen of the Norman style. Beneath the chancel is a spacious vault, in which the remains of the Webster family are deposited, and there are some ancient brasses, fine painted glass, and several monumeuts, one to Sir Anthony Browne, k.g., Master of the Horse to Henry VIII., who died in 1558. There aro gunpowder mills in the neighbourhood. Market Day : Second Tuesday in each month. Area : 8,152 acres. Popidation : 3,495. Prin- cipal Hotel: The George. Averqge Train Service : Eight each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 15/6/, 12/- s, express; 13/6 /, 9/9 s, 4/8£ /, ordinary. Return Tickets (8 days), 25/- /, 18/6 s, express ; 21/-/, 15/6 s, 9/5 /, ordinary. Netherfleld is a large hamlet within the parish of Battle, aud is noted for its gypsum mine. BECKENHAM. — (Stations— NEW BECKENHAM (Junction) and BECKENHAM (on the L. C. and D. Railway). — A parish and urban sanitary and school board district of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Bromley union, county court district and petty sessional division. The parish is within the metropolitan area. The S. E. Railway and the L. C. and D. Railway exercise joint running powers over the line from Beckenham to Bickley. There are five churches, of which only one, St. George's, is of ancient date ; it was erected in the 15th century. The Nonconformists have several chapels, and there are numerous local charities. Area : 3.856 acres. Population : 6,090. Princi pal Hotel : The Railway. Average Train Service : About twenty each way daily. The Fares from London are small, return tickets being available for four days. BELVEDERE.— (STATION.)— An ecclesiastical district — comprising the ancient limits of Lesness Heath — formed out of the civil parish of Erith (which see) in 1861. The woods about Belvedere are exceedingly pretty. All Saints' Church was opened in 1861. Bostall Heath, one of the open places under the control of the Metropolitan Board of Works, is in the district. There is a handsome pub lic hall in the Erith Road. Average. Train Service ; Ten each way on week days, and about the sameonumber ou Sundays. Fares from London : 2/3 f. 1/7 s, 1/2 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 3/6/,2/0s, 2/-/. BERKS (County of).— An in land county, belonging to the south eastern division. Its shape is very irregular. On the north are the coun ties of Oxford and Buckinghamshire, the Thames being the boundary ; on the east Surrey and Middlesex ; on the south Hampshire ; and on the west Wiltshire and Gloucestershire. Length, about 50 miles ; breadth, 2 1 miles, and circumference, 120 miles. Watered by

37 the rivers Kennet, Lambourne, Loddon, Oke, Emborn, and the Thames. Berk- shire is well supplied with railway communication. The chief railway is the Great Western, the main line of which enters this county at Maiden- head and proceeds by Twyford to Reading, thence to Pangbourne, Steven- ton, and so near Wantage andFaringdon to Swindon ; it has branch lines open from Didcot by Abingdon to Oxford, from Maidenhead to High Wycombe through Cookham, from Twyford to Henley, from Slough to Windsor, from Reading to Basingstoke on the South Western, and from Reading to Hunger- ford and Devizes, by the Berks and Hants Extension ; the Reading, Guild- ford and Reigate line, connecting the towns from which it is named, crosses the South Western at Guildford, and joins the South Eastern and Brighton lines near Reigate, thus uniting Reading with the whole of the southern system of railways ; the lines from Oxford to the north also place Reading in direct communication with the northern parts of the kingdom. The eocene tract on the south-east border, called Bagshot Heath, has been from time immemorial an unprofitable waste, scarcely producing a single blade of grass. Latterly an extensive portion of this district has been planted with fir, which is proving of considerable value in reclaiming this truly desolate spot. Owing to the great variety of its soils, Berkshire exhibits almost every form of agriculture. Ex- cellent corn crops are raised on the oolitic formation. The south-east and eastern parts of this county are occupied by Windsor Forest and Park. There is much woodland, in which grow hazel, oak, ash, jeech. and alder. At White Horse Hill the Berkshire Downs rise to a height of 893 feet. Berkshire returns three members to Parliament, and con- stitutes an archdeaconry in the diocese -of Oxford and province of Canterbury. It is in the Oxford circuit, and the assizes are held at Reading. The borough representation comprises five members ; namely, Reading, 2 ; Abing- don, 1 ; Wallingford, 1 ; and Windsor, 1. The shire has 20 hundreds, 12 registry districts, and 12 poor-law unions, and contains 192 civil parishes, 6 municipal boroughs [Abingdon, Maidenhead, New- bury, Reading, Wallingford, and New Windsor J, in addition to a part of the city of Oxford ; 8 urban sanitary authorities, 12 rural sanitary authori- ties, and 8 turnpike trusts, lt has also one court of quarter sessions, and is divided into 11 petty sessional divisions, and 7 lieutenancy subdivisions ; the boroughs of Abingdon, Newbury, Read- ing, and New Windsor have separate commissions of the peace and courts of quarter sessions ; the boroughs of Maidenhead and Wallingford have com- missions of tbe peace only. The boroughs of Abingdon, Newbury, Read- ing, and Windsor have their own police. The geology of Berkshire comprises the lower eocene (London clay, &c), which extends across the whole of the southern portion, with the exception of a narrow strip on the south-east border, where tho middle eocene (Barton and Bagshot series) makes its appearance. A ridge of chalk hills, running east and west, divides the vale of the Thames, or of the White Horse, as it is called, from the vale of Kennet. North of these chalk downs a narrow strip of greensand occurs, and beyond this the upper and middle oolite. This county was anciently called Barocscire or Berocscire, softened in process of time into Barkshire and Berkshire, and probably derived its name from a thick wood, called Barroc, which occupied an extended tract be- tween Lambourne and Wantage. The English held this shire as part of the kingdom of Wessex, but it was some- times under the Mid-English. Berk- shire was attacked by the Danes, with whom several battles were fought, a very famous one at Asdown, in which Ethelred and Alfred the Great defeated the invaders. During the middle ages, frequent forays took place in this county, and in the Parliamentary war most of the towns were the scenes of conflict. On the chalk hills near Lam- bourne are some remarkable piles of large stones, one of which is called Wayland Smith's Cave. At Kingston Lisle, near Lambourne, is a curious stone, called a blowing stone. It con- tains an aperture, on blowing into which a sound is "iven forth which can be heard six miles ofl'. The White Horse, which is the figure of a horse cut ojit of the turf on the side of the chalk

38 hills, and left white, is by most thought to have been done by the old English. It moy be seen from a distauce of fifteen miles, and gives name to the hill in which it is cut. At Silchester are re mains of an important Roman station, and old castle ruins exist at Donnington and Wallingford. Iron works, railway engineering works, and a large biscuit factory, have been established at Read ing. There are paper and silk mills on the river Kennet, and a factory for copper goods at Bisham. The other manufacturing industries are connected with sacking, mats, wool, and articles constructed of osiers. Principal Markets, Fairs, <&c. — Abingdon : Mondays — first Monday in Lent ; May 6, June 20, September 19 (lamb) ; December 11 (lamb) ; July 1 (wool) ; September 30 (hiring). Hungers ord: Wednesdays — April 24 (cattle) ; June 26 (wool) ; August 17 (sheep) ; Wednesdays before and Wednesdays after October 11 (hiring). Maidenhead: Wednesdays — Whit- Wednesday and November 30 (cattle) ; September 29 (cattle and hiring). Newbury : Thursday — Holy Thursday, July 5, September 4, No vember 8, October 10. Reading : Wed nesdays and Saturdays— February 2, May 1, July 25, September 21. Wal lingford : Fridays — April 25, September 28 (hiring). Wokingham: Tuesdays — November 2 (general). Area .- 450.132 acres. Popidation : Males, 97,078 ; females, 99,397 ; total, 196,475. Num ber of parliamentary electors in 1880 (excluding boroughs) : 8,061. BETCHWORTH. —(STATION.) --A village and parish of the county of Surrey (mid division) ; in Reigate union, county court district and petty sessional division. The station is at the foot of the North Downs range, and immediately below the hill locally known as " Betchworth Clump." The village is on the river Mole. The parish church of St. Michael is ancient, and contains two or three fine brasses. from London: 4/- /, 3/- s, 2/1 t. Re turn Tickets (4 days), 6/- /, 4/6 s, 3/3 /. BEXLEY.— (STATION.)— A largo parish and village of the county of Kent (western division) ; it is in the union, county court district, and petty sessional division of Dartford. The river Cray crosses the centre of the village in its course to Crayford. Tho church of St. Mary consists of nave and north aisle, and contains some ancient and curious monuments and sedilia in three divisions ; also some fine brasses. There are almshouses for twelve poor persons, founded in 1755, and endowed with a rent-charge of £100. The town was given by King Kenulf to the See of Canterbury, and in " Domesday Book " it is recorded as having a church and three mills. Cam den, the celebrated antiquary and historian, was owner of this manor : he devised it for the endowment of a pro fessorship in history to the University of Oxford, who still hold it. Area: 5,278 acres. Population (including Bexley Heath) : 6,448. Average Train Service : Sixteen each way on week days; eight each way on Sundays. The Fares from London are small, return tickets being available for four days. BICKLEY. — (STATION.) — A hamlet and ecclesiastical parish within the parish of Bromley and county of Kent. The station is jointly used by the S. E. Railway and the L. C. and D. Railway. The church is a commodious edifice with a spire. Area : 718 acres. Population : 623. Average Train Service: Twenty each way on week days ; six on Sun days. Fares from London : 2/- /, 1/6 s, 9d. /. Return Tickets (4 days), 2/6 /, 2/- s, 1/6 /. BLACKHEATH. —(STATION.) — This district gives its name to one of the hundreds of the county of Kent (western division) ; and extends into the parishes of Charlton, Greenwich, Kidbrooke, Lee and Lewisham. It is in Lewisham union, and the Central Criminal Court and Metropolitan Police districts. The principal attraction of the place is its well-known Heath, con taining altogether within its bounds about 300 acres of recreation ground, now under the control of the Metro politan Board of Works. The Heath is Brockham Green, in this parish, is a picturesque spot. Betchworth Park contains some ruins, known as the " Castle," and is renowned for its magnificent chesnut trees. Area : 8,714 acres. Population: 1,558. Average Train Servke: Twelve each way on week days ; four on Sundays. Fares

39 full of historical associations. Accord- ing to tradition, Julius Cæsar encamped here. In 1001, the Danes had a camp, where they held the Archbishop of Canterbury a prisoner, after sacking his city and cathedral. In the reign of Richard II., Wat Tyler assembled an immense force of Kentish men here. In 1400, Henry IV. received the Emperor of Constantinople at this place. Fifteen years afterwards, Henry V. was received here after the battle of Agincourt. His son, Henry VI., in 1541, came to Black- heath to witness the submission of a number of Jack Cade's followers. The views from this spot are magnifi- cent, the east side terminating in Shooter' s-hill, and the northern bounded by Charlton. The Common is bor- dered by numerous villas, and on it are two episcopal churches and a proprie- tary chapel, and Morden's College for decayed merchants, founded in 1695 by Sir John Morden. It has an annual revenue of more than five thousand pounds. Blackheath is crossed by the Roman Watling-street, and various se- pulchres and other remains of the middle ages have also been discovered. Ascend- ing the hill from Greenwich to the Green Man Tavern on the Heath, there is a remarkable cavern, discovered in 1780. It consists of seven apartments, and is entered by fifty steps, the whole cut out of the chalk rock, with a bottom of sand, and a well of water twenty- seven feet deep. The lodge or ranger's house, near the wall of Greenwich Park, was formerly the residence of the Princess Sophia. That part of the Heath near Lee is called Blackheath Park. Park-road is a line of comfort- able residences. The surface of the district is undulating, and broken with gravel-pits. The town of Blackheath, formerly called Tranquil-vale, has been much increased in size, and is called Park-town. The Population of the district in 1871 was about 5,500. There are more than CO trains each way on week-days; and on Sundays — except during morning hours of Divine service — they run hourly in each direction. The Fares from the London terminii are small. tithing of Hawley, and county of Hants (northern division). A large number of residential mansions and parks are in the vicinity. The place takes its name from the Blackwater stream, and is the station for Sandhurst Military College. The College is about a mile from the station, and is situated in beautiful grounds. The building consists of a centre, with Doric portico, two wings, and a very handsome chapel. A well - furnished library contains portraits of George III. and his. Queen, and previous governors. The number of students is betweeu 300 and 500, and they are trained in strict military discipline. Average Train Ser- vice : Eight each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from Lon- don : 5/0 /, 4/- s, 2/6 t. Return Tickets (8 days), 9/-/, 6/6 s. BOX HILL.— (STATION.)— This station takes its name from the magnifi- cently wooded hill which overlooks the town of Dorking, and is thickly clothed with plantations of yew trees, from which "box wood" is obtained. From its summit a view of the country for many miles can be secured, and, commanding as it does, some of the most beautiful scenery to be found in the United King dom, it is much frequented in summer by visitors from the metropolis. The river Mole flows underneath the hill, and it is from this circumstance that the stream takes its name. The mansion on the brow of the elevation, opposite the north-west slope of Box Hill, is Denbies, the seat of the Right Hon. Geo. Cubitt, M.P. A short distance from it is Ran more Common, with its graceful church and spire, built by Mr. Cubitt at his sole expense. The gorge, or defile, between Box Hill and Denbies is the only natural opening through the North Downs along an extent of many miles. The station is in the parish of Dorking, and close to Burford Bridge, a favourite halting-place for travellers. Average Train Service .• Fourteen each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from Lon don : 4/- /, 3/- s, 2/1 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 6/-/, 4/6 s, 3/3 1. BROADSTAIR S.— (Station — RAMSGATE— 2J miles.)— A town, urban sanitary district, and watering place of the county of Kent (eastern division); in the parish of St. Peter's, Isle of Thanet union, and Margate county BLACKWATER.— (STATION.) — A village within the parish of Yately, 5

40 within the Metropolitan Police limits and tbe jurisdiction of the Central Criminal Court. Bromley is the ter minus of a branch line of railway from Grove Park, and has a station on the branch line from Lewisham and Becken ham to Bickley. The town is situated on the banks of the small stream known as the Ravensbourne. The Bishop of Rochester, to whom the manor was given by Ethelbert, king of Kent, formerly had a palace here, which was rebuilt court district and petty sessional divi sion, and prettily situated on the shores of the small Bay of Bradston (whence the name is derived). The church was built iu 1831, and is in the Early English style. There are gas and waterworks belonging to companies, and the usual establish ments of a quiet bathing resort. The place is considerably patronised by families. The coast defences here com prise Northfleet and Chandos Batteries. The remains of the Chapel of Our Lady VIEW FROM BOX HILL. of Brads ton, near the site of an ancient harbour fortification, known as York Gate, serve to remind us of one of the most honoured of the patron saints of mariners. Area of the district : 299 acres. Population ; 1,926. Principal Hotels : Albion ; Balmoral ; Railway ; and Northern. about a hundred years ago as a residential mansion. The parish church is an ancient building, which was thoroughly restored in 1873 ; Park Road Church (St. Jol n's) is a chapel-of-ease, opened in 1872, and there are churches in the ecclesiastical districts of Bickley, Brom ley Common, and Plaistow, all within the parish. The Nonconformists have several places of worship here, and there is a capital literary institute, well sup plied with books, papers, and periodicals. The town hall is a handsome Elizabethan edifice. Bromley has some valuable BROMLEY.— (TWO STATIONS.) — A market town, parish, and urban sanitary district of the county of Kent (western division) ; and in the union, county court district, and petty ses sional division of Bromley. It is

41 charities, foremost among them being Bromley College, founded by Bishop Warner, in 1666, for twenty poor widows of clergymen ; subsequent benefactors have much increased the usefulness of this institution. There is a cemetery for the district on the London Road. Brom ley races and steeplechases take place on the Common. Market day : Monday. Area : 4,687 acres. Population : 10,674. Newspapers : Bromley Journal (i.), Fri day, Id. Bromley Telegraph (l.), Satur day, ld. Principal Hotels: Bell and White Hart. Average Train Sei-vice to each station : Twenty each way on week days ; eight on Sundays. Fares from London: 1/9 /, 1/4 s, 8.Jd. /. Return Tickets (4 days), 2/3 f, 1/9 s, 1/5 t. CANNON STREET.— (CITY TERMINAL STATION.)-Full par ticulars of this station, with the Bridge, will be found in the Introduction (see page xii.) CANTERBURY. — (STATION.) — A parliamentary (returning two mem bers) and municipal borough in the eastern division of the county of Kent ; the metropolitan see of all England, capi tal of the county, a city and county in itself, market town and poor law union of fourteen parishes, in the hundreds of Bridge and Petham, deanery, arch deaconry, and diocese of Canterbury ; it is a principal station on the main line of the London Chatham and Dover Rail way ; 55 miles from London by road, 15 miles from Margate, 15 from Dover, and 7 from Whitstable, which is its port on the river side, and with which it has com munication by means of a branch line of the South Eastern Railway. The quarter sessions for the eastern division of the county are held here. The origin of the city of Canterbury is far beyond the era of authentic British history. Most pro bably it was a seat of superstition, and a principal scene of Druidic barbarity, long before the Christian era. Under the Roman rule it increased its importance from the circumstance of its being on the great high-road to the continent. By them it was called "Durovernum," and at the time of the Heptarchy became the capital of the county, under the name of " Cant-wara-byrig," or " Kentish men's borough." Hengist and Horsa were en tertained here by Vortigern, who after wards took possession of the city ; and Hengist kept his court here, as did his successors of the kingdom of Kent, amongst whom was Ethelbert, the first royal convert of Saxon England to Christianity. The city was burnt and rebuilt several times during the conflicts with the Danes, who, it is believed, threw up the mound called " The Dane John," for military purposes. During the Plan tagenet era the city derived considerable benefit from the concourse of pilgrims to the shrine of Thomas a Becket. Charles I. was married here to Henrietta Marie ; and Charles II. , after his resto ration, held court here for three days. Canterbury gives the title Viscount to the Manners Sutton family, the first Viscount having been created a peer in 1834, after holding the office of Speaker of the House of Commons from 1817 to 1834. Among the eminent men who have flourished here may be noticed — the Primate Stephen Langton, who first divided the Old and New Testaments into chapters; Osbern, a monk in the eleventh century, who wrote in Latin the life of St. Dunstan, and who, from his skill in music, was called the English Jubal ; John Bale, Prebendary of Canterbury and Bishop of Ossory, the Protestant historian biographer ; Isaac Casaubon, whom, on account of his learning, James I. invited over from France, and Meric, his son, who were both installed prebendaries. Among the eminent men who received the rudiments of their education in the King's Free Grammar School may be noticed — Dr. Harvey, who discovered the circulation of the blood ; Dr. Marsh, Bishop of Peterborough ; and Lord Tenterden. Among the names of actual natives of the city we may enumerate those of — Dr. Thomas Ltnacre, founder of the Royal College of Physicians in London ; Dr. Thomas Neville, Master of Magdalene College, and afterwards Master of Trinity College, Cambridge, who was sent by A rch bishop Whitgift to tender the English crown to King James ; Boyle, the great Earl of Cork ; William Somner, author of the "Antiquities of Canterbury" and of a Saxon Glossary ; and W. Frend, M.A., author of the "Ephemeris." Can terbury has been the cradle of Saxon and modern English Christianity. Ethel bert's palace was converted into a church and monastery, and an abbey built, dedi-

42 pilgrims lodged, some old gabled houses with overhanging stories, and many ruinn of ecclesiastical edifices. The distin guishing feature of Canterbury is the magnificent cathedral commenced by Lanfranc, and added to by subsequent prelates. It is cruciform in shape, 530 feet in length, with a central and two western towers, a beautiful chapter house and some splendid chapels, of which the finest are those of Henry cated to St. Peter and St. Paul, which title Dunstan changed to that of St. Augustine. The abbey became a place of great magnificence, being endowed with 12,000 acres of land. Henry VIII. converted it into a palace for himself. Philip and Mary granted it to Cardinal Pole : and Elizabeth kept court here. Its beautiful gateway still remains. Soon after the conversion of Ethelbert, this city was made a bishopric, and Augustine WEST GATE OF CANTERBURY. the first bishop. Many Roman relics have been discovered in Canterbury. The castle appears to have fallen to decay at a very early date, as no mention is made of it in connection therewith ; but another castle was built, the donjon of which still exists, which is mentioned in Domesday Book. The city abounds with remains of old architecture, amongst which are — the house of Sir Thomas More, tlie Old Chequers Inn, where the IV., the Lady chapel, and that of the Holy Trinity, in which stood the shrine of a Becket. The crypt has been used since the time of Elizabeth as a French Protestant church. The library con tains some rare MSS., and in the pre cincts are the residential houses of the clergy. The archbishops had, at one time, a palace here, but it became dilapi dated, and has been superseded by Lam beth Palace. Besides the cathedral, D.

43 there are fourteen parish churches, some of them very ancient, and chapels for several dissenting sects ; other public buildings are — the guildhall, the court house, the county hall, the house of cor rection, the barracks, the military infir mary, the Kent and Canterbury hospital, the dispensary, the market housQ, the corn and hop exchange, the theatre, the assembly rooms, St. Augustine's college, the philosophical institute and museum, the free library, cfec. Canterbury formerly abounded withmonasteries and nunneries, for monks and nuns of every order, chantries, hospitals, almshouses, and other religious and charitable institu tions, founded by the piety of our fore fathers. Amongst those which have sur vived to the present time are — the hospital of St. John, founded bj' Lanfranc in 1086, and now supporting a prior and eighteen brethren, who are appointed by the archbishop ; Cogan's hospital for clergymen's widows, founded in 1657 ; King's Bridge hospital, established by Thomas a Becket for educational pur poses and for the maintenance of poor persons; Maynard's and Cotton's hos pitals ; Smith's and Hern's almshouses. &c. ; all of which institutions are under the management of trustees appointed by the Lord Chancellor. There is a free grammar school, founded by Henry VIII., and endowed with twenty-four scholarships. Also blue-coat school for educating sixteen poor boys belonging to the city, the elections to which are made by the council. The revenue of this school is derived from lands, Arc, in the city and in Kent, formerly belonging to the hospital of poor priests ; the surplus funds are appropriated to the reduction of the poor rates. St. Augustine's mis sionary college, founded by Mr. Beres ford Hope, is situated on the site of the old abbey in which the saint was buried, and of which the north gate still remains. Under the Romans, the government of Canterbury was similar to that of other Roman towns ; under the Saxons, the chief magistrate was called the prefect, and afterwards the " port gerefa," or keeper of the walls ; this title was after wards changed into that of king's pro vost, when the king and archbishop held some sort of joint jurisdiction, and although the latter had the power of coining, he was, nevertheless, subordinate to the king. But it would seem that there was a municipal government also, since Edward the Confessor had fifty-one burgesses or freemen, who paid a rent for tbe privilege of trading in the city. At the time of the Conquest, the chief government was in the hands of the " præpositus," or prefect, appointed by the king. From Henry II. the city re ceived a charter conferring peculiar pri vileges, in addition to those previously enjoyed. Henry III. granted the city to the inhabitants at fee-farm rent of £60, and empowered the citizens to elect two bailiffs, superseded by a mayor in the reign of Henry VI. (1449), who con ferred tbe privilege of choosing a coroner. Ednard IV. confirmed the preceding charters, remitted more than one-fourth of the fee-farm rent, and constituted the city a county in itself. Henry VI. fixed the number of aldermen at twelve, and of the common - councilmen at twenty - four. Henry VIII., by Act of Parliament, in 1544, empowered the mayor and alder men to levy a fine of 6s. 8d. per day upon all strangers who should keep shops or exercise any trade in the city. James I. confirmed all the former charters and privileges and re-incorporated the citi zens, under the title of the mayor and commonalty of the city of Canterbury. The freedom of the city is inherited by birth, or acquired by servitude, gift, mar riage with a freeman's daughter, or by purchase. Charles II. , in 1676, granted a charter of incorporation to the refugee silk weavers established here. As con stituted under the Municipal Act, the city is divided into three wards, with a mayor, recorder, sheriff, six aldermen, and eighteen councillors ; and it has it3 town commission of the peace, quarter sessions, and police force distinct from the county. The corporation is the urban sanitary authority. Works of main drainage were executed under the superseded pavement commissioners, and sewage works are in operation. The gasworks and waterworks are vested in a private company. The corpora tion lately obtained a General Im provement Act, wliich empowered them, among other things, to establish a burial board and cemetery. In ancient times the city had a reputation for sUk manufactures, but they have given place to a superior kind of damask linen.

44 Worsted is also made here, and there are several large malting and brewing estab- lishments. The district is, however, chiefly agricultural. Area : 3,774 acres. I and fourth Tuesdays in each Month. Fairs (for pleasure, <fec.) : October 11 and three following market days. Municipal | Electors: 3,205. Principal Hotels ; Fleur-de lis ; Guildhall ; Rose ; Royal Fountain ; Station ; and Victoria. Average Train Service : Five each way on week-days, and two on Sundays. CATERHAM.— (STATION.)— A village and parish of Surrey (eastern division) ; in Godstone union and petty sessional division and Reigate county court district. The church of St. Mary, in the Early English style, is a small, plain and very old building. A new church was consecrated in 1866 ; it is in the Early English style, occupies a site opposite the old church, and consists of chancel, north and south aisl es, naves, porch and tower. The Metropolitan District Asylum, for chronic insane persons and imbeciles, is situated in the upper part of the parish, adjoining Chal don and Coulsdon, and is surrounded by a farm of 76 acres. The building is of white brick, with red brick facings, aud consists of 13 blocks and a chapel, with a detached block for infectious cases, six for males and seven for females ; there is a recrea- western end of the Caterham Valley, in the parish of Coulsdon, and county of Surrey (mid division) On the west (or up-line) side of the station the schools of the Warehousemen and Clerks' Provident Society are a prominent feature. On the east side a short distance southwards, a dip in the hills allows the traveller to see the Asylum for Fatherless Children. This institution was founded in 1845 by Dr. Andrew Reed (father of Sir Charles Reed), who was also the projector of the Royal Hospitable for Incurables, and whose estate adjoined that of Reedham, so called in honour of the founder. In this orphan asylum 400 fatherless children are maintained and educated. They are received at any age, and kept until they are fourteen years old. The manage ment cf the asylum is admirable, and the liberal characterof the education, andfree dom from all sectarian influences, render rt a most popular and successful institution. Average Train Se-rvice : Thirteen each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 2/9 /, 21- s, 1/1 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 4/9/, 3)3 s, 2/- t. CATFORD BRIDGE.—(STA TION.)—A hamlet of the parish of Lewisham, in the county of Kent (western division), and situate one mile south of the parish church. The station is on the Lewisham and Addiscombe Road branch line. Jiverage Train Service: Twenty-six each way on week days, and six on Sundays. The Fares from the London terminii are small. tion hall to seat 800 people, with a permanent stage. Adjoining the asylum are the barracks for the recruits of the regiments of Foot Guards ; they were finished in 1877, and correspond in style with the asylum- They hold 400 men and 4 officers, but are to be enlarged. The Caterham Spring Water Company obtain their water from wells 500 feet deep, and supply Caterham, Godstone, Bletching ley, Nutfield, Redhill, and a portion of Reigate. The district known as Caterham Valley has sprung up round the railway station, which is nearly a mile distant from the village ; there are two small churches — St. John's and St. Luke's. Ai ea (of the parish) : 2,437 acres. Popu lation (including asylum) : 3,577. Aver age Train Service : Ten each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 3/2/, 2/6 s, 1/3 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 5/- f, 4/- s, 216 t. CATERHAM JUNCTION.
