CHARLTON.-(JUNOTION STA TION.) — Old and New Charlton form a parish andsuburban districtof theMetro polis, in the county of Kent (eastern divi sion), Woolwich union and county court district, and the jurisdictions of the Cen tral Criminal Court and Metropolitan Police. The district lies intermediate between Greenwich, Blackheath, and Woolwich, and overlooks the Thames. It is pleasantly situated and contains many picturesque residences. Shooters' Hill, an insulated mass of London clay, about 446 feet in height, is a conspicuous object, covered with dense luxuriant vegetation

46 surrounding numerous handsome houses. The parish church, dedicated to St. Luke, is ancient, and contains several tombs, among others a monumental tablet to Sir Adam Newton ; one dedicated to Brigadier- General Richards, who lived in the reign of George I. ; another to Postmaster-General Craggs, implicated in the South Sea Bubble. There is also a monumental bust of Spenser Perceval, who was shot by Bellingham in the lobby of the House of Commons. His remains were interred in the churchyard ; and near him lies another victim of assassination, but on this occasion by the hand of a madman, who had mistaken Mr. Drummond for Sir Robert Peel. In the chancel window may be seen a few armorial bearings in stained glass. Charlton House was one of tbe buildings erected in the reign of James 1., when the old English domestic architec ture was about to be supplanted by what was then thought to be a purer style. The architect is said to have been Inigo Jones. It was begun in 1602, by Sir Adam Newton, and completed about 1612. It is built with red brick, faced here and there with stone quoins and dress ings. In form it is an oblong, with large advanced wings, and a central porch projecting in a somewhat less degree than the w^ngs ; the ground plan being nearly that of a capital E. At each end there is a small square turret. The style is the extremely florid one then in vogue. The chief labour is expended upon the centre, which is elaborately ornamented. The arched doorway has plain double columns on each side ; over it is a niche, in which there is a female bust. The first story has quaintly-carved columns, and above them a series of grotesque sculptured brackets. To this succeeds another story and another row of similar brackets. Along the entire summit is carried a rather singular balustrade. The interior of the mansion is somewhat bizarre, but many of the rooms are very handsome. The richly ornamented roof of the entrance hall, with a deep central pendant hanging from the ceiling, com mands attention. The family arms of the proprietor of Charlton, Sir Thomas Maryon Wilson, supported by a wolf, sur mount the principal baluster at the foot of the stairs. Through two massive oaken doors, ornamented with bright steel hinges, a splendid dining-hall is entered. Communicating with this apartment ia a small chapel, furnished in keeping with other portions of the building. On the first floor, a magnificent room on the right extends the whole depth of the mansion, with large bay windows on either side. In the roof of that which faces the west are seen the arms of James I., and in the opposite recess the device and arms of his eldest son, Henry, Prince of Wales, who spent here a con siderable portion of bis short life under the care of Sir Adam Newton, his tutor. This room is richly decorated and fur nished. Amongst other objects of rare beauty is a variegated marble fireplace, supported by statues of white marble. To one apartment a well-known legend is attached ; a very remarkable fireplace of highly polished black marble stood here, in which, it is asserted, Lord Downes,\vho was seated opposite to it, saw the reflec tion of several figures passing across the distant heath, whose attitudes led him to imagine that they were engaged in the perpetration of some robbery. He in stantly despatched his servants to the spot, and the same dubious tradition declares tbat the thieves were captured and punished. In the next room is a full-length portrait of Prince Henry ; and throughout the mansion is a small but choice collection of paintings, with numerous specimens of art, such as antique cabinets, vases, (fee. The magni ficent saloon, extending the whole length of the south front, is full of precious ob j ects. The park and pleasure grounds, whence a fine view is obtained of the ancient mansion, are of great extent and beauty. In the former are some of the largest and finest trees that this county can boast of. Area : 1,231 acres. Popu lation : 7,699. The Train Service, on week days and Sundays, is very frequent, and the Fares from the London terminii small. C HART HAM— (STATION.)— A parish and village of the county of Kent ; in Bridge union and Canterbury county court district and petty sessional division. The parish is known as Chart ham-with-Horton and lies in a fertile vale on the river Stour, three miles north-west of Canterbury. It is built round a green with the parsonage and church ou the south side of it. On the

47 Stour, which is crossed near the village by an ancient bridge of five arches, is a paper-mill. The church, dedicated to St. Mary, is of early decorated architec ture, with very fine windows, and some remains of richly-stained glass; the roof is of wood, and the embattled tower of flint, both being of later date than the stone work ; in the chancel lie the remains of Dr. John Reading, chaplain to Charles I. and author of some religious tracts. There is also among other in teresting mortuary memorials, a large slab, inlaid with brass, of a knight, large as life, cross-legged, in mail armour, with a surcoat above, a shield on his left arm, a lion at his heels, and a long sword hanging pendant from a very rich girdle. It perpetuates the memory of Sir Robert Septrand, who was with Richard I. at the siege of Acre. There is also a monument to the French refugee, Dr. Delangle, dated 1724 ; and iu the south transept may be observed a beautiful monument by Rysbrach to Sir William Young and his wife. Mystole House and Park is the family estate of the Fagges, from the time of Charles II. The present mansion was built in the reign of Queen Elizabeth, It is a moderate-sized house, pleasantly situated in a small park. Not far distant from this place, in 1868, some workmen, while digging a well, turned up, at the depth of 19 feet, a parcel of strange and monstrous bones, some whole, some broken, together with four teeth of an unusual size, perfect and sound, but turned into stone, each tooth weighing about half a pound. There are numerous other handsome mansions in the neigh bourhood of Chartham, some of which are visible from the railway. The popu lation is largely composed of the work men employed at Mr. W. Howard's paper mills, and their families. The East Kent Lunatic Asylum — erected in 1875 at a cost of £200,000 — is at Chartham Downs, which have at various times yielded Anglo - Saxon relics. Area : 5,530 acres. Population: 1,251. Aver age Train Service : Five each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 15/- /, 10/6 s, 5/2 /. Return Tickets (8 days), 22/6/, 16/- s, 10/- t. CHATHAM. — (Station— STROOD— 2 miles; but connected by a short branch with the Chatham station of the London Chatham and Dover Railway.) — A parliamentary (returning one member) borough, urban sanitary district, town and parish in the county of Kent (mid division) ; in Medway union, and Rochester county court district. Chatham forms a special police dis trict, and, in conjunction with Sheer ness, engages a stipendiary magistrate. The town is on the south bank of the Medway, and adjoins both Roches ter and Strood. Its royal dockyard and repository for naval stores and ordnance are protected by a system of fortifications — the "Chatham lines" — unequalled in the world ; in fact, both shores of the river, from the Nore to the harbour, and the land approaches in every direction, display a seemingly interminable series of batteries and forts. Chatham seems to have been a place of little importance prior to the establish ment of the dockyard. The town was originally built by Charles II., after the Dutch war. It consists chiefly of one long, bustling 3treet, with smaller ones branching out of it eastward, in continuation of Rochester, on the road to Canterbury. The naval station was formed in the reign of Queen Elizabeth. Chatham old church, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, was almost entirely rebuilt in 1788. The shrine of Our Lady at Chatham used to be famous for working miracles. In the church is the tomb of Stephen Borough, who discovered the passage to Archangel. St. John's was erected in 1821, by the Parliamentary Commissioners, at a cost of fifteen thou sand pounds. St. Bartholomew's Chapel stands on the site of an ancient hospital for lepers. Behind the " Sun Inn," is a pier erected by Colonel Best at a cost of three thousand pounds. On account of the fortifications in the neighbourhood, a military school was founded here in 1812. In the course of the practice in each year, siege operations are sometimes carried on upon a large scale, and attract many strangers. A large invalid esta blishment is kept up at Chatham. Mel ville Hospital contains 134 patients. The hospital for decayed mariners was founded by Sir John Hawkins in 1592, and provides for twelve pensioners. An old house in the High Street, let out in tenements and decorated with carvings,

48 was once the residence of the celebrated shipbuilders, the Petts, who may be con sidered as having modelled the English navy in the sixteenth and seventeenth chaplains. At Chatham is the Medway Union Workhouse,which comprises seven parishes. The Literary institution pos sesses a good library. The Convict CHATHAM IN THE SEVENTEENTH CENTURY, centuries. The Lepers' Hospital, founded in 1108, and under the patronage of the dean, is now an almshouse, with four inmates, two of whom are officiating Prison accommodates 1,000 inmates. The arsenal and barracks extend more than two miles along the Medway. The former contains storehouses and a large

49 park of artillery. The Marine Hospital has accommodation for 340 patients. The Artillery Barrack is a great station for artillery. It was erected in 1804, and forms three sides of a square, and has accommodation for a large number of invalids. The Artillery Hospital is attached to the barrack. The Infantry Barracks are very large. There are also Engineering Barracks. The Jubilee Memorial in Chatham was erected in 1859. The hospital dedicated to St. Bartholomew contains one hundred beds. In 1861 was completed the Royal Engineers' Memorial, the first stone hav- ing been laid by the Duke of Cambridge on March 1st, 1860. The names of every officer and every sapper alike who fell in the Crimea are inscribed in white marble slabs let into the stonework of the arch, so that the memorial is truly, as its inscription implies, a memorial by " The Corps of Royal Engineers to their Comrades who fell in the war with Russia, 1854, 1855 and 1856." The Dockyard at Chatham was founded in Queen Elizabeth's time on a small scale. This establishment was where the Ordnance Wharf or Old Dock now stands. In 1667, the Dutch Admiral, Van Ghent, burnt several ships here ; and from that time it was strongly fortified and extended, and is now one of the four grand naval stations of the empire, ranking with Portsmouth, Plymouth, and Woolwich. Sheerness is connected with it. The Dockyard is nearly a mile in length, extending down the river. The public are admitted under certain regulations daily, except Sundays. The yard contains wet docks, magazines, storehouses, a church, and residences for the naval officers. A large establishment of arti- zans and labourers is kept up here. The ,4 rea of the parliamentary borough is 2,707 acres. Population : 45,792. Par- liamentary Electors : 5,548. Newspapers : Chatham and Rochester News (i. L.), Friday and Saturday, ld. Chatham and Rochester Observer (l.), Saturday, ld. Principal Hotels : Clarence; Globe ; Im perial; and Sun. CHELSFIELD— (STATION.) — A parish and village of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Bromley union, county court district, and petty sessional division. The village is prettily situated in a rural district. The parish church of St. Mary is an ancient flint and stone building. Area : 3,218 acres. Population : 903. Average Train Service : Eight each way on week days ; three each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 3/6 /, 2/6 s, 1/4 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 4/9/, 3/9 s, 2/3 t. CHERITON.— (Stations— SAND- GATE and FOLKESTONE HARBOUR — 1 mile each.) — A parish and village of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Elham union and petty sessional divi- sion, and Folkestone county court district. Cheriton is in the parliamentary borough of Hythe, midway between that place and Folkestone, and about one mile north of Sandgate. The camp at Shorncliffe and part of the Seabrook estate is within the Cheriton boundary. The situation of the village, <fec, is very pleasant and agreeable. In olden times it was called Cherington, and tbe manor was formerly the property of the noble family of Aver- anche3. St. Martin's church is an ancient edifice, a portion of the tower show- ing unmistakable Saxon workmanship ; there is a chapel on the north side, and a handsome arcaded chancel. The build- ing once contained fine monuments of crusaders, and there are still three recum- bent figures dating from the fourteenth century. Several brasses, including one of the year 1474, commemorate the Brockman family. The main fabric of the church was restored in 187 3, and the tower in 1877. Underbill House, in this parish, is noted as being the Duke of Richmond's place of concealment in the earlier part of the Commonwealth. Writter, who befriended the duke, was rewarded by Charles II. with the gover- norship of Upnor Castle. Area: 1,617 acres. Population (exclusive of the camp) : 3,403. CHILHAM. — (STATION.) — A parish and village of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in East Ashford union and petty sessional division, and Canterbury county court district. Cbilham Castle is a Norman building of octagonal form, surrounded by a large and widely famed park. . Chilbam is re- ported to have been the scene of nu- merous conflicts between the Britons and Romans, and Roman remains have been from time to time discovered. When the Romans gained a permanent settlement in Britain, they made thiB

50 CAMDEN HOUSE, CHISLEHURST (LATE THE RESIDENCE OF THE EX-EMPRESS El'G KNIE") place one of their " Castra stativa," or permanent encampments. Withred, king of Kent, who resigned at the latter end of the seventh century, resided at Chil- north-west, is Old Lees, a handsome mansion. Two miles and a half further, at Selling, is Belmont, the residence of Lord Harris. A short distance beyond, ham, and made it a place of great strength. The church of St. Mary is an old and handsome building, and was re stored in 1863. One mile from Chilham, at Sheldwich, is Leos Court, the seat of Earl Sondes. This splendid mansion was erected by Sir George Sondes, K.B., Ump. Charles I., from a design

51 by Inigo Jones, upon the site of the old mansion at Lees Court. The front is adorned with fourteen Grecian-Ionic pilasters, which divide the windows. Above the ground floor, the building is raised one story, and covered with a cottage roof, supported by brackets ; it is altogether a very stately edifice, sur rounded by beautiful grounds. A little more than a mile north of Selling, on the road to Faversham, is Nash Court, the demesne of the Hawkins family since the reign of Edward III. The mansion is of imposing appearance, situated on an eminence in the midst of _ spacious, well-planted park, and com manding extensive views over the sur rounding country. Area : 4,343 acres. Population: 1,476. Average Train Ser vice : Five each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 15/- /, 10/6 s, 5/2 /. Return Tickets (8 days), 22/6 /, 16/- s, 10/- t. CHIL WORTH.— (STATION.)-A hamlet in the parish of St. Martha-on the-Hill, in the county of Surrey (west ern division) ; in Hamblcdon union, Guildford and Godalming county court district, and Guildford petty sessional division. The most noteworthy object in the place is the ancient chapel of St. Martha on the summit of a hill ; it is built of very rough materials in the form of a cross. Near the railway station isagunpowder factory. Area; 1,070 acres. Population : 181. Average Train Service : Six each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 5/- /, 3/6 s, 2/6 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 7/6/, 5/- s, 4/-/. CHISLEHURST.— (STATION.) — -A village and parish of the county of Kent(western division); inBromley union, county court district, and petty sessional division. The neighbourhood abounds in beautiful scenery, and boasts some splen did mansions and picturesque parks. Camden Place, late the residence of the ex-Empress Eugenie — close to which is St. Mary's Catholic Church, containing the tombs of Napoleon III. and his ill fated son— takes its name from Camden, the celebrated historian and antiquarian. Frognal is the seat of the Lord Lieu tenant of the county of Kent, Earl Sydney. Scadbury Park is a well-timbered and attractive estate. Chislehurst pos sesses three churches, in addition to chapels for Nonconformists. St. Nicholas is the parish church, and is an interesting building, dating from about the year 1450, but some parts of it are alleged to be of even earlier date. It comprises the tomb-house of the Sydney family. The other two churches (Christ Church and Church of the Annunciation) have been erected since 1870. Area : 2,742 acres. Population : 3,313. Average Train Service : Seventeen each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 2\- /, 1/6 s, 9d. t. Return Tickets (4 days), 2/6/, 2/- s, 1/6 t. CLIFFE. —(Station— HIGHAM— 3 miles.) — A small village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division), notable for its bold promontory, stretch ing forth beyond the Mdton Marshes, and overlooking the Thames. The vil lage and church occupy the summit, and the winding of the river at this point is very interesting. This commanding height was in former times rendered available for " watch and ward " to the river. In the reign of Richard II. beacons were erected here, and there is now a large fort, which forms one of the river defences. Area: 7,756 acres. Population: 1,290. COBHAM.— (Station— HIGHAM — 4 miles.) — A village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in North Aylesford union and petty sessional division, and Gravesend county court district. The village of Cobham is a quiet unpretending place. The church, dedicated to St. Mary Magdalen, at the entrance to the village, discloses by a survey of the architectural features of its exterior the great ageof themainportions of the fabric ; and this is corroborated by the inscription among the most ancient of the brass effigies to be seen within, bear ing date 1354, being upwards of five centuries old ; the church itself may claim one hundred years in advance of this. The general appearance of the interior, like that of most village churches, presents a curious sample of modern whitewash renovation, contrasted with the remains of an ancient decora tive character. The rich oak screens and carved stalls, crumbling now into the very dust of age, accord but doubt fully with the coloured roof and painted pews. The magnificent series of brasses, thirteen in number, memorials of the Cobhams and Brookes, are the first

52 objects to be observed ; for these, above i all else, have made this little church celebrated far and wide. Theso brass effigies, all, with two exceptions, of the size of life, are mostly in a good state of preservation. Commencing at thesouth "east corner, the first of the lower raDge is that of Sir John de Cobham, known as "the young Constable," from having held, early in life, the government of the neighbouring castle of Rochester. The next effigy is Margerie, said to be wife to Reynold de Cobham, Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports in the reign of Edward III. The third figure is Maud, wife of Sir Henry de Cobham, son of the pre- ceding. Beside Maud is placed the effigy of Sir Reginald Braybrooke, her second husband ; ou her right is Sir Nicholas Hawberke, her third spouse : these two latter brasses are, perhaps, tbe most elegantly engraved of the whole series. The two exterior monuments of the upper row, the figures in which are less than lifo-size, are those to John and Thomas Brooke, Barons of Cobham, their wives and families. Against the chancel walls are hung some rust-eaten pieces of armour, apparently remain*! of tilt-armour of the reign of Henry V. A helmet, surmounted with a represen tation of a human head, belonged, according to village tradition, to one of the Lords of Cobham, who settled CLIFfE CHURCH AND PROMONTORY. a pending dispute with some neighbour ing noble in a trial by battle. His lady is at his side, and several children are around them in a kneeling position. The ancient College was founded by John, Lord Cobham, whose monument we have mentioned. Lambarde, the Kentish perambulator, was one of its first trus tees. The quaint old dining-hall is now a chapel, for the use of the pensioners who reside here. The building was founded for the support of five priests. At the dissolution it was resounded, and the funds were employed in providing a residence for twenty poor persons, with a quarter of an acre of land to each , and a small monthly stipend. It is an easy figure of Margaret, wife of John, Lord Cobham, whose memorial succeeds next. This nobleman built abridge at Roches ter, converted the family mansion at Cowling into a fortified castle, and founded tlie original College adjoining the churchyard. He was one of the council of Regency duriug the youth of Richard II. Thomas, whose memorial ranges next, was uncle of the pre ceding. Joan, daughter of Lord Cob ham, succeeds. She died during the lifetime of her father, leaving her daughter, Joan, who had five successive husbands, the fourth among them being the venerable martyr, Sir John Old castle. Placed on her left hand is the

53 walk hence to the Hall, which is seen, reposing beneath the shelter of a thickly and well-planted range of stately trees. In a brick gateway near the stabling a curious carved carriage is shown, said to be the vehicle in which Mary, Queen of Scots, rode after her marriage with the Earl of Darnley. Another account con nects it with the time of Charles II. A door on the left hand of a Tudor archway discloses the exterior of this stately old English mansion, which is entirely domestic in character ; the main building — of brick — cousisting of two extensive wings with lofty octagonal turrets in the middle and at the ex tremities. These wings are inscribed with their respective dates of erection, being 1582 and 1594. They are united by a central building, designed by Inigo Jones ; the ground plan of the edifice being thus in the form of a capital H. As a whole, it is both striking and picturesque. The rooms which are shown at Cobham have little of the air of antiquity. In the early part of the present century the whole house under went chauges deteriorating to its original character, but, doubtless, more adapted to modern convenience. Many of the rooms are very elegant, and they are furnished with considerable splendour. The dining room is chastely decorated, by which the effect of the pictures is con siderably enhanced. The next, the music-room, is the most magnificent in the house, and is said to have been pro nounced by George IV. " the finest room in England." This is one of the apartments erected by Inigo Jones. It is large, lofty, and well-proportioned ; the walls are, to somo height, of polished white marble, with pilasters of Sienna marble. The floor is of polished oak ; one end of the room is a music gallery, containing an organ. In the music-hall there is a very tine full-length picture, by Vandyke, of the two sons of the Earl of Lennox, who were killed while fighting for Charles I. against the Parliament. In the dining-room are several other portraits by Vandyke. There are also in this room portraits by Lely and Kneller. On the staircase are several large paintings, but the chief and most valuable are collected in tbe Picture Gallery. Here is Rubens' grand picture, " The Head of Cyrus brought to Queen Tomyris." This picture was purchased from the Orleans collection. There is also another good painting by Rubens, "The Boar Hunt," very ani mated and vigorous. The Guidos, of which there are several, are generally considered among the choicest pictures in the gallery. There are also two or three paintings by Titian, also two historical subjects by Salvator Rosa, much admired. In this gallery is a large antique bath of the finest red oriental granite, which the Italians call coralliuo. The most valuable paintings belong to the Venetian and the Neerlandish schools ; but there are many interesting specimens of the Neapolitan and Bolognese, French, and English schools ; nor are the Spanish and German quite unrepresented. The chief part of the collection was formed by the purchase of a number of pictures from the Orleans Gallery, and also by that of the Vetturi Gallery from Venice. The park, which is well stocked with deer, extends over an area of nearly two thousand acres, and is seven miles in circumference. It is well diversified with hill and valley, and broad smooth glades and bosky dells. Some parts of it afford the most beauti ful woody scenery tbat can be desired ; others present wide and noble prospects. The park contains some very large trees, the chestnuts being especially famous. One is known as the " Four Sisters," from the four large arms into which its stem, thirty-two feet in circumference, divides itself. Area : 3,056 acres. Population : 998. CRAYFORD. — (STATION.)-A parish and village of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Dartford Union, couDty court district, and petty ses sional division. Crayford is a very ancient place and derives its name from its situ ation on the river Cray, upon which stream, contiguous to the village, are several silk and calico printing establish ments. In the year 457 Hengist defeated the Britons under Vortigern at this place. In Domesday Book the village is men tioned as having a church and three mills. There are several caves in the parish which are supposed to have been formed by the Cyrari as places of security for their families during their wars. The church, dedicated to St. Paulinus, stands on an eminence at the upper end of the

54 town. It contains several interesting monuments, and many more were de stroyed by a fire which burnt down a part of the fabric. Hops are largely grown in this district. Area: 2,433 acres. Population : 3,887. Average Train Ser vice : Fourteen each way on week days ; eight each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 2/9 /, 2/3 s, 1/3 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 4/6/, 3/4 s, 2/4 /. CROYDON. — (Two Stations — EAST CROYDON and ADDISCOMBE ROAD.) — A large market town, parish, and urban sanitary district of the county of Surrey (eastern division) ; in Croydon union, county court district, and petty sessional division, and the Metro politan Police district. The East Croy don Railway Station is jointly used by the South Eastern and London Brighton and South Coast Railway Companies. Addiscombe Road is the terminal station of the branch from Lewisham. Croydon, although a place of great antiquity, is seldom mentioned in history. It is situ ated on the Roman road of Ermine street. The town is about amile in length. The part now called High-street was formerly only a bridle -road through fields. The old, or lower town, called Old Croydon, was situated further from London, towards Beddington. Croydon is the capital of East Surrey, and assizes are held here alternately with Guildford. Churches, t&c. : St. John the Baptist, parish church ; St. James's, St. Peter's, Christ Church, St. Andrew's, and St. Mary's. Nonconformist Chapels : Inde pendent chapel, Friends' meeting-house, Wesleyan chapel, Baptist chapel, and Roman Catholic chapel. There are School Board and National schools in Croydon, also Freemasons' almshouses, public hall, town hall and gaol, market house, lecture hall, gas company, banks, and a literar}' and scientific institution. Tho church, dedicated to St. John the Baptist, and considered one of the finest examples of ecclesiastical architecture in the coun ty, is supposed to have been commenced by Archbishop Courtney, who became primate in 1381, and died in 1396 ; but it does not appear to have been completed until tbe days of Archbishop Chicheley. It is situated at the bottom of the town, near the source of the Wandle, and is built of stone and flint, in the Pointed style. It consists of a nave, three aisles, and two chancels. At the west end is a handsome square tower, rising to the height of four stories, and supported by strong buttresses, and adorned at the summit by battlements and crocketed pinnacles issuing from octagonal turrets. It contains a good ring of eight bells, cast in 1738, with chimes which play a psalm tune every sixth hour. An old marble font, at the west end of the south aisle, is said to be of the time of Arch- bishop Chicheley ; it is octagonal, with quatrefoil panels on its sides, ornamented with roses and grotesque heads. In the middle chancel are some ancient wooden stalls. There is an unusually rich col- lection of monumental brasses and in- scriptions in this church, and even on the exterior ; and in the churchyard are many interesting memorials of the dead. In the middle chancel, on a sarcophagus within an arched recess, lies the painted effigy of Archbishop Grindall, in his scarlet robes. This venerable prelate died in 1583, aged eighty-three years. In the south-east corner of St. Nicholas's chantry is a splendid monument to the memory of Archbishop SheldoD, who died iu 1677, representing the recumbent effigies of this dignitary in his archiepis- copal robes and mitre. The figure is of statuary marble, beautifully sculptured. On the northside of the altar, within sepa- rate recessed arches, are the sculptured effigies of a man and woman kneeling before desks. This monument dates from the sixteenth century, and commemo- rates a worthy citizen and grocer of "Lon- don famous cittie," Maister Henry Mill. In St. Nicholas's chantry are also the tombs of the Archbishops Wake, Potter, and Herring, who succeeded each other, and died, respectively, in the years 1736, 1747, and 1757. On the cast wall of St. Mary's chancel is a beautiful monument of white marble to the memory of Mrs. Bowling, aud representing an angel bearing up a female. The sculpture is by Flaxman. On the north wall of the same chancel is a large white tomb for the Heron family and of the sixteenth century. It is ascended by three steps, and bears the figures of a man in armour, in alto-relievo, attended by his five sons, and a woman, attended by eight daugh- ters. Here, rlso, is Archbishop Whit- gift's monument, a sarcophagus, sup- ported by Corinthian columns of black

55 marble. It represents the recumbent effigies of the prelate in sable robes, with his hands raised in the act of prayer. He died in 1604. It appears by the parish registers (which are complete from tbe year 1538) that Alexander Barkley, or Barclay, author of " The Ship of Fools," was buried in Crojdon churchyard in 1552. On the restoration of the church, in 1844, some ancient paintings were discovered, some of large size, and one of them representing St. Christopher. Besides the churches named, there are in the suburbs several chapels-of-ease and chapelsand meeting-housesfor several de nominations of dissenters. The Church of St. Peter at Southend will accommodate one thousand persons. Whitgift's Hos pital,thenoblest benefaction thatCroydon nas ever enjoyed, was founded by Arch hishop Whitgift, in the reign of Elizabeth, for the maintenance of a warden, school master, and twenty-eight men and women, or as many more under forty as the revenues would admit. The building is an unpretending brick edifice, of the Elizabethan style of architecture, and of a quadrangular form. It has under gone a renovation, both internally and externally. Over the entrance are armorial bearings of the See of Canter bury, surmounting this inscription : " Qui dat pauperi, non indigebit." The chapel of the hospital, a small apartment forming the south-east angle of the building, was consecrated in 1599, by the name of " The Chapel of the Holy Tri nity." In this chapel are some inte resting remains ; amongst them is a por trait of Archbishop Whitgift, painted on a board, with an inscription in Latin above, which may be thus rendered : " My all I did ; the all allowed by heaven : Envy, do more ; if more to thee be given." Below:— rspo very pleasing and substantial appear ance, and the main street is long and spacious. Some of the houses are hand some. The parish includes eight hamlets within its limits, and a con siderable part of Norwood, which was formerly a forest. Tho neighbourhood of Croydon (particularly the west part of it, called Duppa's Hill, adjoining to and open from the range of hills called Banstead and Epsom Downs) is much frequented by invalids from the metro polis on account of the purity of the air. Croydon is supposed to have been the ancient Novromagus. At the Conquest it was bestowed on Lanfranc, Archbishop of Canterbury, whose successors in the See have been lords of the manor ever since ; and here was an archiepiscopal palace, where the primates usually resided from 1278 to 1757. In this palace James I. of Scotland was imprisoned. In 1573 Archbishop Parker entertained Queen Elizabeth and all her retinue here for seven days ; an expensive manifes tation of loyalty in those times. Having fallen into decay, the palace was sold in 1780, under the authority of an Act of Parliament, for £2,520. The palace was then turned into an establishment for printing linens, and the garden was made a bleaching-ground ; but the demesne having been subsequently resold in lots, the buildings were converted into sepa rate dwellings. Of this ancient archi episcopal palace, only a few fragments remain : an arch is especially worth notice. The extensive drainage opera tions at Croydon have contributed much to the healthiness and prosperity of the town. Market Day ; Thursday (cattle and corn). Population : 55,652 — esti mated in 1880 to be 70,000). Area : 9,868 acres. Newspapers : Croydon Ad vertiser (l. L.), Saturday, Id. Croydon Chronicle (n .), Saturday, IJd. Croydon Guardian (i.), Saturday, ld. Croydon Journal (c), Thursday, ld. Croydon Observer^.), Friday, ld. Croydon Times (l.), Wednesday, id. Principal Hotels ; Greyhound; King's Arms. A i-irage Train Service to East Croydon : Thirteen each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 2/- /, 1/6 s, lOd. t. Return Tickets (4 days), 3/6/, 2/6 s, 1/6 t. Average Train Service to Addiscombe Road ; Twenty each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. ±Selow:_ [see) "The Primate's breathing image here you Who built this structure to the Holy Three.' ' Croydon is rich in charities. There are a number cf almshouses endowed ; also Archbishop Tenison's School for poor boys and girls, founded in 1714; and Ellis Davy's Almshouse " for seven poor people, men and women," the creation of which charity dates from 1447. The principal town buildings consist of the Court-house, the Public Hall, and the Market. The town, generally, wears a 0

56 Fares from London : 1/6 /, 1/2 s, lOd. t. Return Tickets (4 days), 2/6 f, 1/9 s, 1/3 t. C U X T O N. — (STATION.) — A parish and village of the county of Kent (mid division); in North Aylesford union and Rochester county court district and petty sessional division. The village is on the banks ofthe navigable river Medway. The church, dedicated to St. Michael, is ancient. Area : 1,761 acres. Population : 421. Average Train Service : Six each way on week days ; five each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 5/6 /, 3/10 s, 2/8 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 8/6/, 6/- s, 4/6 t. DARTFORD.— (STATION.) —A town, parish, and urban sanitary district of tbe county of Kent (western division) ; in Dartford union, county court district, and petty sessional division. A fine view of the town is obtained on the right just before entering the station from the di rection of London ; on the left beneath is a pretty lake-like pond, studded with little islands. The latter adjoin the ground of the Phœnix paper mill, a most conspicuous object from the line. The town is seated on a narrow valley on the river Dart or Darent, from which its name is derived. It has been a place of consideration from the time of the Ro- very nearly joins on to Crayford and Wil mington. The church, dedicated to the Holy Trinity, is a venerable and spacious Gothic structure, with an embattled tower at the north-west sides. It contains several ancient monuments, among which is one in commemoration of Sir John Spielman, who introduced the process of paper-making to Dartford. In the pavement near tbis monument is a slate inlaid with brasses, of Richard Martyn and his wife, under a rich canopy. There are several other inlaid slabs in different parts of the church, and some of them are very curious. In the old churchyard was anciently a chapel to St. Edmund the Martyr, on the site of which a very handsome and costly monument has been erected, by subscription, to the memory of Christopher Ward, who was burnt at the stake on Dartford Brent, July 7th, 1 555. The old burial-ground is on the hill adjoining. Here is interred the great engineer, Richard Trevithick, the inventor of the railway locomotive, the high-pressure engine, the steam ballast engine, <fec. There are also places of worship for several denominations of Christians ; also charities, almshouses, &c. ; endowed grammar school, board schools, literary institution, &c. Near the town are the ruins of a nunnery, founded in 1355, by Edward III., after the victory of Crecy and surrender of Calais, for Augustine nuns, but after wards occupied by Dominican nuns. At the Dissolution the prioress and several of the nuns were of some of the best and most ancient families in the country. The buildings were occupied by Henry VIII., and, during her progress in Kent, by Queen Elizabeth, as a royal residence. The present remains are of brick, and consist of a large embattled gateway, with some adjacent buildings, now occupied as a farmhouse. The gardens and orchards occupied twelve acres aud were surrounded by a stone wall. The corn and cattle market for Dartford is contiguous to the Bull yard. The building accommodates about 300 oxen and 1,500 sheep. During tbe Celtic period there was a great town on the heights between the rivers Darent and Cray : great remains are still existent in the woods ; mention is made of them by Hasted, and the destruction of the town is attributed to the Wars of the Roses ; mans, occupying an important station at the crossing of the river by the Great Watling Street from London to Dover. Domesday Book refers to it as having a church and three chapels. Isabella, sister of Henry III., was married here in 1235 to the Emperor Frederick III. Edward III. held a tournament at Dartford on his return from France in 1331. The great insurrection under Wat Tyler, in the reign of Richard IL, broke out here, in consequence of an insult offered to his daughter by a tax-gatherer, on the occasion of collecting a poll-tax, an obnoxious levy on the inhabitants. The incidents in this struggle are well known, and the results were that an immense force was coll ected with which Tyler marched to Blackheath. The first mill established in England for rolling and slitting iron was erected at Dartford in 1590, by Godfrey Box, a native of Brabant. Dartford Creek exports the manufactured and agricul tural produce ; also chalk, lime, and whiting ; and imports coal and timber for the neighbouring district. The town

57 but the decay (says Dunkin) was owing to the construction on the Watling-street of the Roman station Novromagus, — i. e., the New Town, — now Dartford, at the ford at the foot of the hill. The great Brit ish town was the city of Cassivelaunus, which Cæsarmarched to, and then received that check which forced him to retreat to the coast at Lymne, and there embark, in two ships, the wasted remnant of that mighty force which had been brought from Gaul in nearly a thousand vessels. The Priory Farm was formerly a priory, afterwards King Henry VIII.'s palace. There is some beautiful brick-wrork here, especially an arch : the garden wall is also in fair preservation. On the right of the town is the Royal Flour Mill, also silk-printing works, and the gun powder mills of Messrs. Pigou and Wilks. There are also many other flour and paper mills on the banks of the river Darent. On the Brent is the City of London Lunatic Asylum, a beautiful building, with a frontage of about 900 feet. About two and a half miles from the station is the ancient hospital of St. John's, now a farm. HortonCourt Lodge, five miles from Dartford, formerly was a castle. The ruins are still there. Frank s, four miles, is very ancient, and has undergone re storation. Eynsford Castle, now in ruins, is six miles from Dartford. Lullingstone Castle is seven miles from the town : here is a very fine archway. The ruins of Otford Castle, eleven miles from the station, are worth a visit. The scenery in the neighbourhood of Dartford is highly interesting. There are numerous handsome residences. About one mile and a half south from the railway station is Wilmington, the manor-house of which, beautifully situated, was, in the reign of Edward IV., the residence of the king-making Earl of Warwick. The village is exceedingly picturesque, and is surrounded by gardens and cherry orchards. South-east of Dartford, about three miles distant, is Darenth, a village deriving its name from the river Darent, on the banks of which it is situated. The church is small and ancient, some portions being supposed to date from the Anglo-Saxon period. The font is inter esting, beiDg of large size, so as to admit of the complete immersion of infants. There are also some monuments. The traveller on the railway between Dart- ford and Greenhithe will be struck with the picturesque appearance of the old sand-pits which are traversed by this line. They contain an area of many acres, the cuttings being of great depth, and it must have been the work of ages to have fashioned them to their present form. Trees grow on their summit to the very edges of the cliffs ; and here and there summer-houses may be seen amidst them, which have all the appearance of a perilous position, while the bottoms of the pits are laid out and cultivated with vegetables. Through the openings that occasionally intervene, and in emerging from some of the short tunnels, the most lovely prospects present themselves. Market Days : Saturdays (corn) and first Tuesday in each month. Fairs : August 2nd in each year. Area : 4,434 acres. Population: 8,298. Newspapers: Dartford Advertiser (i.), Friday, ld. Dartford Chronicle (i.), Saturday, Id. Dartford Express (_.), Saturday, ld. Principal Hotel : Bull and Victoria. Average Train Service : Thirty-five each way on week days ; twenty-one each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 3/-/ 2/6 s, 1/6 t. Return Tickets (4 davs), 4/6/, 3/6 s,2/6 t. DEAL.— (STATION.)— A municipal borough of East Kent (included in the parliamentary representation of Sand wich), market town, parish, seaport, pilot and coastguard station, member of the Cinque Port of Sandwich ; in the hun dreds of Cornils and Bewsborough, lathe of St. Augustine, deanery of Sandwich, archdeanery and diocese of Canterbury ; the terminal station of a branch Hne from Ramsgate on the South Eastern Railway (from which the recent exten sion — jointly undertaken by the South Eastern and London Chatham and Dover Railways — communicates with Wahner and Dover) ; 73 miles from London by road, 21 from Canterbury, 9 from Dover, and 13 from Ramsgate. By the ancient Britons it was called " Dole," signifying a low open plain upon the sea ; and many adhere to the belief, based upon the authority of Henricus, that it is the place where Cæsar landed. It was annexed to tbe Cinque Ports soon after the Conquest, Henry VIII. erected three castles in its vicinity — those of Deal, Walmer and Sandown — for the defence of the coast ; and besides these, there are two batteries ; making five

58 libraries, bazaars, <fcc. There are also national and infant schools, custom house, dispensary, infirmary, and old and new assembly rooms. There ia little or no trade, the population being chiefly employed as boatmen, pilots, and fishermen. Boat building exists on a small scale, and passing ships are supplied with stores. The intrepidity of the Deal boatmen in putting to sea in the roughest weather, for the purpose of saving lives and relieving distressed vessels, is familiar to all. Market Days : Tuesdays and Saturdays. Fairs : April 5th and October llth. Area : 1,124 acres. Population: 8,009. Municipal Electors : 1,475. Newspapers : Deal Chronicle (l.), Friday, ld. Deal, Walmer, and. Sandwich Mercury (a), Saturday, ld. Deal, Walmer, Dover and Kentish Telegram (l.), Friday, Id.; Saturday, 2d. Deal, Walmer, and Sandwich News (l.), Wednesday, ld. Principal Hotels : Pier ; Royal ; and Walmer Castle. Average Train Service : Five each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 10/10 /, 11/10 s, 6/10 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 25/3 /, 18/- s, 11/- t. DEPTFORD. — (STATION.)— A suburb of the Metropolis in the county of Kent (western division) ; it is in Green wich union, county court district, and parliamentary borough. Deptsord is within the jurisdiction of the Metro politan Police, Board of Works (iu parts), und the Central Criminal Court. The principal feature ofthe place is the Dockyard, first established by Henry VIII. Here, in 1581, Queen Elizabeth visited Drake's ship, the " Golden Hind;" and after dining on board, tho honour of knighthood was conferred upon the famous mariner. The Dockyard build ings and premises altogether comprise an area of thirty-one acres. The town is irregularly built. The chief buildings are the parish church of St. Paul, a well- endowed charity school, two ancient hospitals for decayed pilots and ship- masters, or their widows, one of which comprises fifty-six houses within the walls, belonging to the Trinity House. The wharves, storehouses, and privato yards for ship-building, mostly employ the inhabitants. The old bridge was taken down in 1859, and replaced by a substantial cast-iron one. A Baptist fortresses within four miles. Walmer Castle is the official residence of the Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports, and in it the Duke of Wellington died in 1852. Deal Castle has been converted into a family residence, the moat having been planted with trees, and changed into a promenade ; aud Sandown, where Colonel Hutchinson was imprisoned and died in 1664, is now in ruins. For parliamentary purposes Walmer was united to Deal by the Reform Act, which places, in conjunction with Sand wich, return two members to the House of Commons. Deal was made a free borough, by charter,in 1699, by William HI., with a mayor, twelve jurats, and a council of twenty-four ; the jurats acting as magistrates, separate from the county justices. The corporation now consists of a mayor, six aldermen, and eighteen councillors, and the borough has a com mission of the peace, with quarter sessions and its own police force. The corporation is the urban sanitary authority. Water and gas works are in the hands of joint stock companies. There is a cemetery of five acres in extent, under the control of the parochial burial board ; interments also take place at the parish church in Upper Deal, and at St. George's in Lower Deal. The borough consists of Upper and Lower Deal, Walmer, Sholden, and Great and Little Mongeham. The parish church of St. Mary is small but ancient, in the Norman style, with zigzag mould ings, and is surrounded by a fosse. A chapel of ease, dedicated to the Saviour, was built in 1848. Other churches are — St. George's, St. Andrew's (recently altered and repaired), St. Leonard's, and St. Martin's at Great Mongeham. The Catholics, Wesleyan Methodists, Inde- pendents, Primitive Methodists, and Unitarians also have chapels in the town. In 1864 a handsome iron pier was erected, which forms a good promenade in summer for visitors. At Walmer there is a large naval and military hospital, and barracks for soldiers. On the shore is an electric time-ball for the use of ships in the Downs. The air being good, and the sea beach favourable for bathing Deal has of late years been resorted to as a watering-place, and several smart-looking villas and rows of houses have been erected for the accom- modation of visitors, besides baths,

59 chapel and schools were recently erected at the junction of the old and new roads, near the toll-gate. By the muni ficent gift of £10,000 by the Baroness Burdett-Coutts, a church was erected in 1855, on the Lewisham Road in tbis parish, with parsonage house, grounds, and schools for 200 boys, 170 girls, and 200 infants. The workhouse at Deptsord occupies the site of Saye's Court, the residence of Evelyn, the author of the celebrated " Diary," "Sylva," and numerous other works. This talented and amiable man was wide and handsome principal street, with two others branching out at its southern end ; the whole town being very clean, well paved, and lighted with gas. St. Martin's church is a handsome structure of the decorated style, partly rebuilt in 1837, aud almost wholly so in 1873-6 at a cost of £26,000 ; it contains the mauso leum of the Dukes of Norfolk, lords of the manor. In the churchyard is buried, Hoole, the well-known translator of Tasso and Ariosto. There are also district churches at Holmwood Common and Westcott, near Berry Hill. There DEPTFORn DOCKYARn. well skilled in painting, engraving, and architecture. His gardens wero considered the wonder of the age— he being as skilful in gardening as in the more elegant accomplishments. The Train Service is very frequent, and the Fares from the London terminii small. are places of worship, also, for Wesleyan Methodists, Independents, Society of Friends, and Roman Catholics, with national and infant schools. Dorking has a Public Hall, circulating libraries, and reading - rooms ; and near the " Glory," a public park-like resort, is a Cottage Hospital. Tbe town is celebrated for its breed of fowls, and has a pretty extensive trade in corn, flour, and lime obtained from the neighbouring chalk hills. In these chalk-pits, which are situated about half a mile from the town, on the north side, are several large kilns. The lime produced here is much valued, on account of its property of hardening DORKING.- (STATION.)— A market town and parish of the county of Surrey (western division) ; in Dorking union, county court district, and petty sessional division. Dorking is charm ingly situated in a sandy valley on the south part of the river Mole (referred to under the heading of Box Hill Station which is in the parish), and consists of a

60 under water ; and it is said to have been first extensively used in the metropolis, in building the London Docks, and the Sessions House and County Gaol in Horsemonger-lane. The large cellars or caves beneath the town, dug out of the solid rock, are highly curious. It is said that, more than one hundred years since, a man was foolish enough to ex pend all his property in making the largest of these excavations, at the bot tom of which there is now a spring of pure water. [The environs are adorned with some handsome country seats ; among which we may notice Shrub Hill ; the Rookery, the birthplace of Malthu3 ; Deepdene, a fine Italian villa, surrounded by beautiful grounds, which its owner, H. T. Hope, Esq., M.P., greatly extended by throwing into them the estates of Betchworth and Chart parks. Near the Deepdene, on a sloping piece of ground, stands tho Church of St. Paul, consecrated in July, 1857 ; it is built of Bath stone and flint, in the early decorated or geometrical style. The east and west windows are fitted with painted glass. The walls of the interior are ornamented with ecclesiastical devices, in stamped stucco. The church and parsonage ad joining — ■ handsome buildings — were erected at the sole expense of John Labouchere, Esq., of Broome Hall, who also liberally endowed the church. The site was given by Henry Thomas Hope, Esq. In the neighbourhood, also, is Denbies (referred to under the heading of Box Hill Station), on an elevation about two miles north-west ; the mansion was built, in 1734, by Jonathan Tyers, the originator of Vauxhall : this estate now belongs to the Right Hon. George Cubitt, M.P., son of the late Thomas Cubitt, Esq., the celebrated engineer. The beautiful church on Ranmore Com mon is dedicated to St. Barnabas : The spire is 156 feet high. The whole cost was defrayed by Mr. George Cubitt. About three miles south is Wootton, long the abode of John Evelyn, author of the "Sylva;" and about a mile beyond is Leith Hill, 993 feet high, the most elevated spot in Surrey, commanding a view of London northward, and of the British Channel to the south. Westcott, or Westgate- street, is a hamlet in the parish of Dorking, lying one mile and a half west of the town on the Guildford- road, and, together with the hamlet of Milton, has been assigned as a new eccle siastical district. The church of the Holy Trinity is a beautiful edifice, designed by Scott, standing on a piece of waste land, commonly known as Westcott Heath. William John Evelyn, Esq., is lord of the manor. Coldharbour is a hamlet and ecclesiastical district, partly in the parish of Dorking, three miles and a half from the town. Holmwood is a borough tithing of Dorking, and ecclesiastical district, partly in Dorking and partly in Capel parish, two miles south of the town, and including Holmwood Common. Here is a district church. There are charities of about £500 annual value. Berry Hill is half a mile south-east of Dorking ; Chardhurst, one mile south ; Combe, three-quarters of a mile north west.] Market Day : Thursday. Fair: the day before Holy Thursday (Cattle). Area : 10,034 acres. Population : 8,567. Principal Hotel : Red Lion. Average Train Service : Fifteen each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 4/- /, 3/- s, 2/1 /. DOVER. — (Stations — TOWN AND HARBOUR, and the ADMIR ALTY PIER.) — A parliamentary and municipal borough of the county of Kent (eastern division), market town, and poor-law union of twenty-three parishes, seaport and steam-packet station, one of the Cinque Ports, in the hundred of Bewsborough, lathe of St. Augustine, deanery of Dover, and archdeaconry and diocese of Canterbury ; a terminal station of the South Eastern and the London Chatham and Dover Railways ; 76 miles from London by the former, and 78 by the latter line ; 16 mdes from Canterbury. On account of its position as the nearest landing place from the Continent, Dover bas from the earliest period been a place of some importance. It was the place which Julius Cæsar intended to land his forces when he invaded England, but the heights ap peared to him so formidably defended by the Britons, that he was obliged to go further north. It was called " Dwyr " (from " Dwyffyrrha," a steep place) by the ancient Britons, " Dubris " by the Romans, " Dofre " or " Dovre " by the Saxons, and in Domesday Book appears under the name of " Dovere." As the

61 principal of the Cinque Ports it figures conspicuously in history — William the Conqueror was the first who gave to the Cinque Ports an independent jurisdic tion ; by him they were created into a sort of palatinate, with a lord warden, invested with civil, military, and naval authority, and having his seat of admini stration at the Castle of Dover. Each of the five ports had its own corporation of twelve jurats, from whom the mayor and bailiff were chosen. The Parlia mentary Reform Act of 1832 and the Municipal Act of 1835 broke up to a great extent the peculiar political and municipal organisation of the Cinque Ports, and assimilated their local govern- were commenced, the entrance was deep ened, the pier repaired, and the outer harbour enlarged to the extent of 7£ acres. In 1847 a new set of works was undertaken for the formation of a harbour of refuge, intended to enclose no less than 520 acres ; the Admiralty pier, which forms its west arm, was commenced in 1848, and has been thiown out to nearly half a mile from the shore. This portion underwent great damage by a storm on New Year's day, 1877 ; it is estimated that these gigantic works will have cost, when completed, some where about £2,500,000 sterling. The other pubhc national buildings are — the custom house, the excise office, the alien DOVER CASTLE (FROM THE ENTRANCE TO THE HARBOUR). office, the royal engineers' department the military hospital, the pilots' office, the brigade office, &c. The town hall was once part of the " Maison Dieu" (a hospital founded by Hubert de Burgh), and was purchased from the Government by the corporation, who converted the nave of the old church into the town hall, the Lady Chapel into the Sessions hall, the vaults into dungeons, aud the tower into a residence for the governor. In 1849 the corporation erected the museum and philosophical institution ; besides which Dover contains a theatre, the Welliugton hall, and assembly rooms, the Apollonion hall, the working men's institute, the proprietary library, the philosophical institution, the youths' ment to that of other towns. Dover has a separate commission of the peace, quarter sessions, and police force. The corporation act as the urban sanitary authority, and they have established waterworks under the Local Government Act of 1858 ; the gasworks are in the hands of a joint-stock company. The castle occupies an area of thirty-five acres, on the summit of a cliff. The modern fortifications connected with the castle are very extensive. The opposite heights, known as "the Citadel," are also fortified. The first works of im portance in connection with the harbour were those commenced by Henry VIII., and continued by Elizabeth and James I. In the year 1844, great improvements

62 institute, ifec, and a monument erected to tbe memory of the officers and men of the 60th Rifles who fell in the Indian war. Before the Reformation tbe town had seven churches and several monastic establishments, including the Priory, now almost wholly gone. Of the churches two only are left — St. Mary's, a Norman edifice ; St. James's, an Anglo-Saxon building, and the new church, built in close proximity. Others are — Trinity, Christ's, and St. John's mariners' churches, a military church in the castle, and another on the western heights, with others in the suburban parishes of Charl ton, Buckland, Guston and Houghan. The Baptists, Independents, Wesleyans, Latter-day Saints, Roman Catholics, Unitarians, and Jews have chapels in the town ; and there are national, parochial, and sectarian schools. Tho charitable institutions are — the hospital and dispensary, the female home, the sailors' home, the Albert philanthropic institute, and many other charities, in cluding a set of thirty-eight almshouses, with an income of £200 per annum. — The trade of Dover, apart from that connected with the mail and packet service to the Continent, consists mainly of ship-building, rope and sail making, and the supply of ships' stores. Eggs, fruit, and other rural produce are im ported from France, and the fishery and coasting trades are in a thriving condition. Market Days : Wednesdays and Saturdays. Area : 1,262 acres. Population: 28,500. Municipal Electors : 4,100. Parliamentary Electors : 4,239. Newspapers : Dover Chronicle and Kent and Sussex Advertiser (l.c), Saturday, 2d. Dover Express (l.), Friday, ld. Dover Standard (c), Saturday, ld. Dover Telegraph (a), Wednesday, ld. Hop Journal, 1st of month and fortnightly during season, 12s. 6d. per annum. Publisher, R. Turner. DUNTON GREEN.— (STA- TION.) — A village within the parish of Otford and county of Kent (western division) ; in Sevenoaks union and county court district, and Sutton-at- Hone petty sessional division. The present parish church of Otford occu pies the site of one burnt down in 1637; it was, however, considerably altered in 1863, and contains numerous monuments. The river Darent flows through the village, and the Sevenoaks race-course is within the parish on the Otford Castle estate. The see of Canterbury became possessed of Otford in the early part of the llth century, and the archbishops long had a magnifi cent residence here, of which some ruins remain. The castle well takes its name from St. Thomas _ Beckett. There are places of worship for Nonconformists. Brick-making and lime-burning give employment to a large number of the inhabitants. Area : 2,791 acres. Popu lation: 1,126. Average Train Service: Seven each way on week days ; three each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 4/6 /, 3/3 s, 1/6J t. The inanorof Westerham was anciently in the possession of the Camville family, but reverted to the Crown at the close of the thirteenth century, when Edward I. granted it, with Edenbridge, to the Abbot of Westminster, for the per formance of masses for the repose of the soul of his beloved Queen Eleanor. The church is a large and handsome building, containing a variety of interesting tombs and brasses, especially a cenotaph in memory of General Wolfe, who was born in this town. The river Darent takes its rise in this parish, at a small dis tance south from Squeries. Two remark able phenomena, called slips, occurred here, on the southern escarpment of the sand-hill, in 1596 and 1756 : in the former, nine acres of ground continued in motion eleven days ; and iu the latter two acres and a half, some parts sinking into pits, and others rising into hills. Popu lation: 2,283.] parish of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Romney Marsh union and ROMNEY MARSH (AND DIXOENLSS IN THE DISTANCE) VIEWJED FROM HYTHB DYMCHURCH[andROMNEY MARSH]. —(Station— WESTEN HANGER— 6 miles.) — A town and criminal jurisdiction, and New Romney county court district. Dymchurch was at one time the " capital " of the Romney

64 Marsh, a district that forms a peculiar "liberty" extending over the whole or parts of twenty-seven parishes, mostly within the lathe of Shepway. With the view of encouraging the colonization of the Marsh, it was favoured with a special jurisdiction distinct from the county ; the charters granted by Edward IV., Henry VII., Henry VIII., aud Elizabeth, constitute the inhabitants a body cor porate under the control of a bailiff and twenty-four jurats, appointed from among themselves by twenty- three lords of manors in and adjoining the Marsh, The bailiff is elected annually at Whit suntide, and he and four other jurats appointed by the bailiff, jurats, and com monalty, annually on Michaelmas Day, are the magistrates. The liberty has both a criminal and civil jurisdiction, but the last-named has long since be come obsolete. The justices hold a court of general sessions once a year, or more often if occasion requires. The corporation have the charge and manage ment of the " Dymchurch sea-wall," made to resist the inroads of the sea and defend the Marsh from inundation ; it is more than three miles long, upwards of twenty feet in height, and of consider able width, with three grand sluices to discharge the inland waters. The expense of the repairs of the " Dyke " is defrayed by a rate levied over the whole of the " liberty." Dymchurch has been a place of some importance, and charters were specially granted to it by Henry IL, Edward VI., and James II. The parish church is a small but ancient building. Area: 1,534 acres. EDENBRIDGE. — (STATION.) — A small town and parish of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Seven- oaks union and petty sessional division, and Tunbridge county court district. The town derives its name from a bridge over the Eden. The town contains several chalybeate springs, strongly impregnated with iron, and one with sulphate of magnesia. Iron mines were formerly wrought in the hills, in the southern part of tho parish. The church, dedi- cated to St. Peter and St. Paul, is a large, striking building, having a spire- steeple at the west end, and in an early and later English style. A handsome national school corresponds with the architecture of the church. A walk of about three miles south-east of the station, or by a pleasant route from the town along by-lanes and field-paths, brings the tourist to Hever Castle, erected in the reign of Edward III. by William de Hevre, from which family it came by marriage to the Cobhams of this county, from whom it derived the com pound name of Hever- Cobham ; it was by one of that family sold to Sir Geoffry Bulleyne, Knight, the grandfather of the unfortunate Anne, who was born here. The castle was afterwards tho residence of the repudiated Anne of Cleves, who died here in 1556, after a quiet sojourn of sixteen years. She died in the fourth year of Philip and Mary, at which time the castle reverted to the Crown. It was given by Mary to Sir Edward Waldegrave, whose family in 1715 conveyed it to Sir William Hum- phreys, Bart. ; and in the year 1745 it was sold to Timothy Waldo, Esq. Little is seen of the castle until it is closely approached, owing to its lying in so low a spot. It is quadrangular, in form, E A R L E Y— (STATION.)— An ecclesiastical parish (formed in 1850 out of the parish of Sonning) of the county of Berks ; in Wokingham union and petty sessional division, and Reading county court district. The church of St. Peter consists of chancel, nave, and transepts, in the early English style of architecture. There is a handsome school, with master's house attached, in connection with the church, supported by voluntary contri butions, in which boys and girls receive a sound plain education at a trifling cost. The Reading Cemetery is in this parish. The district of Earley contains, amongst other properties of note and interest, the ancient domain of Whiteknights (for-

■-,r, enclosing a courtyard. The principal part is the fortified portion, and consists of a large and lofty gate-house, flanked by two square towers. It is built of stone, and is evidently of great strength. Over the gateway impend bold machico- lations, from which missiles might be poured on the heads of assailants. The towers are pierced with œillets and loop- holes, through which arrows might be discharged. Three stout gates, and as many portcullises, are arranged, one behind the other, within the gateway. In the gate-house are guard-rooms ; the chambers above were provided with fur- naces for melting lead and pitch. The interior of the castle is in tolerable pre- servation. Among other things shown to the stranger, is Anne Boleyn's bed- room. It is worth seeing, although but scantily furnished ; but what furniture there is is ancient. The bed is affirmed to be the veritable one she slept in : it is antique-looking, with heavy hanging curtains. The chairs and tables, and a strong, carved oak chest, are said to have belonged to the Boleyns. The village of Hever was formerly part of the extensive patrimony of Sir Steven de Penchester, or Penshurst. The church is dedicated to St. Peter ; and is for the most part decorated. The Boieyn chapel is of the late perpendicular style. In the Boieyn chantry is a beautiful brass to Sir Thomas Boieyn. There are several other brasses in good preservation. In the interior of the church is a stately tomb, in marble, to the memory of Sir Thomas Boieyn, who died in 1538. There are also memorials of the Cobham and Waldo families. Near Hever is tbe picturesque village of Chiddingstone. The church, dedicated to St. Mary, is a large, old, and handsome building, with a tower, con- sidered one of the finest in the couuty. In the interior are some fine monuments to the Streatfeild family.] Market Days : Every second and fourth Tuesday in the month. Fair : A fat-stock show in De- cember. Area : 5,287 acres. Population : 1,891. Principal Hotel : Crown. Average Train Service : Nine each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 7/- /, 4/6 s, 2/7 /.
