The station is on the Addiscombe Road Branch Line from Lewisham. Average Train Service : Twenty each way on week days , four each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 1/4/, I/- s, lOd. /. Return Tickets (4 days), 2/- f, 1 /6 s, 1/2 t. ELTHAM.— (STATION .)— A town and parish of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Lewisham Union and Greenwich county court and police district. It is also within the jurisdic tions of the Metropolitan Police and Central Criminal Court. The ancient palace of Eltham was one of the most magnificent royal residences in England. The property is ascertained to have be longed to the Crown in the time of the Saxons. The Conqueror granted it to one of his Norman followers ; but having again been forfeited to the Crown, it passed into the possession of Anthony Bee, the famous military bishop of Durham. He is the earliest proprie tor of the manor who is recorded to have erected any buildings on the site of the palace — although there can be little doubt that there was a house there be fore his time. He built a splendid mansion, which appears to have been completed soon after the middle of the thirteenth century; King Henry III., accompanied by his queen and all the principal nobility, having kept his Christmas here in 1269. On the death of the bishop, which occurred at this place in 1310, the manor of Eltham fell again to the Crown, in the possession of which it has since remained. For the next two centuries the place was a favourite residence of our monarchs. John, son of Edward II., was born here in 1315. In the reign of Edward III., the parliament was, on several occasions, assembled at Eltham ; and here tbat prince, in 1365, entertained, his captive, John, King of France, with sumptuous hospitality. The palace was afterwards almost entirely rebuilt by Edward IV., who, on the con clusion of the work in 1482, is recorded to have kept his Christmas in the hall with great state and splendour. Large additions were afterwards made to the building by Henry VII., who, like hi3 predecessors, generally lived here, and was wont to dine every day in the hall surrounded by his barons. At this time the royal palace of Eltham

66 consisted of four quadrangles, enclosed within a high wall, beyond which was a moat of great width. The whole formed gateway in the north wall. There waB also another bridge and gate at the opposite side of the enclosure. Of tho ELTlsAM PALACE (FROM AN OLD PRINT), an irregular area, approaching to a square in shape, to which the principal entry was over a bridge and through a I buildings, the most important part con sisted of a high range, which crossed the I court from cast to west, and included the

67 hall, the chapel, and the state apart ments. To the palace were attached a garden and three parks, comprehending together about 1,300 acres, besides the demesne lauds of 4,000 acres more. These parks were stocked with deer, and many fine old trees that still remain testify how richly wooded the place must have been formerly. Of all this magnificence, but little now remains ; and many parts of the buildings can scarcely be traced even in their foundations. Henry VIII. deserted Eltham for the new palace of Greenwich. After this, the spot was rarely visited by the Sovereign. At the Commonwealth, a palace so im pregnated with royalty could not but be distasteful to the rigid soldiers of Crom well ; so it was seized and sold ; and at the same time, the parks were broken into, and the deer dispersed and killed. The work of devastation thus begun, was continued until the greater part of the palace was reduced to ruin. Al though the property reverted to the Crown at the Restoration, no pains were taken to protect the relics from violence and spoliation. On the con trary, the old palace was turned into a quarry, and all the materials tbat could be converted into use were gradually removed. Fortunately for the hall, it was considered, by some influential observer on the spot, that it would make a good barn, and to this accidental circumstance we are chiefly indebted for its preservation. The three parks at- tached to the palace, with the demesne lands, extended over 1,652 acres, on which grew 7,700 trees. The royal hall is visible during the winter months at a considerable distance, and from various points of Blackheath and its vicinity forms au interesting landmark to the stranger. In summer, however, when the luxuriant foliage of the trees expands on every side, it is only seen by glimpses through the straggling trees of the park. In the immediate approach, the first objects that arrest the attention are masses of ancient wall, very thickly mantled with ivy, and at the base of which the water of the original moat still keeps its bed. Over this an old bridge of three arches conducts to the •enclosure once covered over with the habitations of royalty, the lodgings for numerous retainers, aud displaying the magnificence for which the Court in olden times was famous, but now re duced to this solitary hall, flanked on the left by several dwellings. Tho situation of this palace must have been eminently striking. Standing on a height of greater elevation than any iu the immediate district, except Shooter's Hill, the ground sloped gently away towards the west, over a rich and in teresting landscape, including Black heath, Greenwich Park, and the Surrey hills, between which stood London, with the lofty spire of the old cathedral of St. Paul in view, and the insulated pile of Westminster Abbey, then with - out towers ; the distant heights of Highgate terminating the background. On entering tho great ball, a screen, once elaborately carved, and running across the building, opens a thorough fare to a corresponding entrance on tlie opposite side. In the centre of the screen is an inner door to the hall. The noble proportions of this magnificent apartment are apparent at a glance. Tho purposes of a common barn to which the hall was long applied, have materially altered and defaced some of its most striking features ; but enough will be seen to awaken the admiration of every lover of olden art. The magni ficent roof, owing to judicious repara tions made several years since at tbe expense of Government, and under the superintendence of Mr. Smirke, is now in good condition. It is wholly constructed of chestnut. The main beams are seventeen inches square and twenty-eight feet loug, perfectly straight and sound throughout. A forest must have yielded its choicest timber for the supply of this building, and it is evident that the material has been wrought with incredible labour and admirable skill. The length of the hall is rather more than a hundred feet, the breadth thirty-six, and the height forty five feet, lt has five double windows on each side, exclusive of the great bays, at the end of which was the chief entrance into the state apartments. At the upper, or north end, was the high dais, slightly elevated and running across the hall. The two great bow windows at either side are adorned with beautiful flowing tracery, and in style and proportions are magnificent. As-

68 ciently indicate the lapse of time since these passages were entered." The town of Eltham is small, but agreeably situated : the area of the parish contains 3,712 acres. The church, dedicated to St. John, is a plain structure, but it contains several interesting monuments, particularly one to John Lilburne, who acted a conspicuous part during the Commonwealth, and in tbe events which preceded that era, In the churchyard are interred the remains of Dr. George Home, Bishop of Norwich, and Doggett, the comedian, who bequeathed a coat and badge to be rowed for on the Thames annually, on the 1st of August. Area : 3,712 acres. Population : 4,064. Average Train Service : Sixteen each way on week days ; eight each way on Sun days. Fares from London : 1/10/, 1/4 s, 9d. t. Return Tickets, 2/9 f, 2/3 s, 1/0 /. ERITH. — (STATION.)— A town and parish of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Dartford union, county court district, and petty sessional divi sion. Erith mainly consists of one principal and irregular street. On the eastern side of the town the pretty river Darent contributes its waters to the Thames; it is joined by the Cray, another " faire " river, in the marshes ; the former rising near Westerham, the latter near Orpington ; the conjoined rivers enter the Thames near " Long Reach Tavern." The pier was built in 1842, and is 444 feet long. Erith was anciently called Lesnes. Lambarde relates an interesting event that occurred here about a century preceding the Conquest, in which St. Dunstan figures in the recovery of certain lands under ecclesiastical jurisdiction. Another historical event is recorded at a later period, when Henry VIII. rested at Erith on his way to meet Francis I. The ancient church, which is ren dered additionally picturesque from the ivy which almost entirely mantles it, formerly possessed a somewhat dis figured interior, arising from a want of tact in its arrangement ; it was com pletely restored in 1877. In a corner of the chancel is an interesting marblu monument, much dilapidated, but still bearing evidences of its former splen dour. The carved work around its sides exhibits traces of the various colours and gilding with which it has been cording to Mr. Buckler, who published a valuable account of this palace, " the taste and talent of ages are consecrated in the design of this interior ; and it is scarcely possible to imagine proportions more just and noble, a plan more perfect, ornaments more appropriate and beautiful ; in a word, a whole more harmonious than this regal banqueting room." This hall was undoubtedly the erection of Edward IV., whose well-known symbol, the expanded rose, is still to be seen on some portions of the building. In 1836 a discovery was made of some subterranean passages connected with the old palace. A pamphlet published at Greenwich at the time gave the following account of these undergound communications : — " Tradition (it is said) has always kept up a belief of the existence of an under ground passage to Blackheath, from Greenwich; and it was affirmed in the neighbourhood that at Middle Park, connected with these passages, there were one or more apartments under ground for sixty horses." The account then proceeds : " Under the ground floor of one of the apartments of the palace, a trap-door opens into a room underground, ten feet by five feet ; and proceeding from it, a narrow passage, of about ten feet in length, conducts the passenger to a series of passages with decoys, stairs, aud shafts, some of which are vertical, and otheic; on an inclined plane, which were once used for admit ting air, and for hurling down missiles and pitch balls upon enemies, according to the mode of defence in those ancient times; and it is worthy of notice that, at poiuts where weapons from above could assail the enemy with greater effect, these shafts verge and concentrate. About five hundred feet of passage have been entered, and passed through in a direction west, towards Middle Park, and under the moat for two hundred feet. The arch is broken into in the field leading from Eltham to Motting ham; but still the brickwork of the arch can be traced further in the same direction. The remains of two iron gates, completely carbonized, were found in that part of the passage under the moat ; and large stalactites, formed of super-carbonite of lime, hung down from the roof of the arch, which suffi-

69 richly ornamented, and the recumbent figure possesses all the quaintness and simplicity of the old monumental effigies. Thero is neither inscription nor date remaining on the tomb, but it is well known as that of Elizabeth, Countess of Shrewsbury and Countess of Pembroke, who received a grant of Erith manor from Henry VIII. Scattered over the pavement of the chancel are two or three very perfect brasses ; and near the altar is a piece of sculpture, by Chantrey, to the memory of Lord Eardley, father-in-law of the late Lord Saye and Sele, and a former possessor of Belvedere. The most con spicuous tomb in tbe churchyard is an obelisk dedicated to the memory of Henry Dismore. Within the church of Erith a meeting was held, in the reign of John, between the King's com missioners and a party of the dis contented barons. There are Wesleyan, Congregational, Baptist, and Catholic chapels. A School Board for the whole of tbe civil parish was established in 1871. Erith is a favourite station for various yacht clubs and the headquarters of the Corinthian Yacht Club. Extensive brick fields lie on the eastern boundary of the parish ; and the excavation of the hills, from which sand is transported by steam tramways as ballast for merchant ships in the port of London, has given to one portion of the parish a peculiar appear ance. The Public Hall is a brick build ing, used for public meetings, concerts, and assemblies. Many villas have been built on the wooded heights overlooking the river ; and the bank cf the Thames is occupied by many factories, and the iron foundry of Messrs. Eastons and Anderson, which gives employment to over a thousand hands. The Metro politan Main Drainage southern outfall works are at Crossness point, in this parish. Belvedere House, Erith, is a spacious edifice of brick, devoid of all exterior ornament, yet of good archi tectural proportions. The interior consists of elegant suites of rooms, ornamented with a valuable collection of paintings, many by the first masters of ancient times, and several by the most eminent painters of our own country. The grounds around the mansion are extensive, and arranged with great taste. The views of the river that occasionally present them selves through opening trees, or the bolder prospect of the noble stream as seen from some neighbouring hillock, are very fine. Fair : Whit-Monday. Area : 4,613 acres. Population : 8,289. Average Train Service : Twenty each way on week days ; ten each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 2/6 /, 1/10 s, 1/3 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 3/9 /, 2/9 s, 2/3 t, ordinary. ETCHINGHAM. — (STATION.) — A village and parish of the county of Sussex (eastern division) ; in Ticehurst union, Burwash petty sessional division, an d Hastings county court district. This place boasts a very fine cruciform church, with a square tower and short spire or pinnacle ; it is said to be the best specimen of Norman architecture in this part of the country. The village was anciently called "Echinam." Area: 3,750 acres. Population : 894. Average Train Service : Seven each way en week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 13/6 /, 10/- s, express ; 12/-/, 8/6 s, 4/0-i t, ordinary. Return Tickets (8 days), 21/- /, 16/- s, express ; 19/- f, 13/6 s, 8/1 /, ordinary. FARLEIGH, EAST. — (STA TION.) — A large village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in Maidstone union, county court district and petty sessional division. St. Mary's parish church is an ancient stone build ing. The village is on the south bank of the river Medway, which is here crossed by a bridge of five arches. Area : 2,028 acres. Population : 1,625. Average Train Service : Six each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 8/- /, 5/6 s, 3/3 t. Return Tickets(4 days), 12/6/, 8/6 s, 5/-/. FARNBOROUG H.—(STA TION.) — A village and parish of North Hants ; in Hartley Wintney union, Farn ham county court district, and Odiham petty sessional division. The village is on the borders of the county of Surrey, and comprises Aldershot (North Camp) within its boundary. The parish pos sesses several large mansions and hand some villa residences ; many are induced to reside permanently in the place owing to the salubrity of the district and its contiguity to the Camp. The parish church is an ancient building. Area : 2,208 acres. Population: 2,597 (ex-

70 either by the Danes or by the inroad of the sea, in 1052. Her father built a castle and church here in 630 ; and a priory for Benedictine monks, with a church, was founded by Nevil de Man deville in 1092, at first on tho site of tho old nunnery, but afterwards removed, in consequence of the devastations of the soa, to the site where the present church stands. This establishment shared the fate of all other monasteries in the reign of Henry VIII., and the only remains at present oxisting are the priory house, which, about the year 1650 had become the property of John Dixwell, Esq., one of the judges of Charles I., and who also signed the warrant for his execution. Folkestone is a member of the Cinque Port of Dover, and was formerly placed under the same jurisdiction as the other Cinque ports. The town has received several charters, that of Charles II. being the governing one until the Muni cipal Act came into operation. That statute provided for a council, compris ing a mayor, four aldermen, and twelve councillors (since increased to fifteen), and a court of quarter sessions, with a recorder, police force, &c. The Urban Sanitary Authority is now vested in an Improvement Commission, which in 1855 secured the " Folkestone Improve ment Act," and executed main drain age works, at a cost of more than £6,000. The water works are at Cherry Gardens, and there is an efficient gas supply. The older and lower quarters of the town are very irregularly built, having steep and narrow streets, which, nevertheless, are clean and well paved. The modern town is regularly laid out, and built on the cliffs, the front forming a much-admired promenade, called " The Lees," from wliich steps and a sloping road give access to the beach. The style of the houses is very good, some of them adapted as lodging-houses being of a very large size, aud of attractive appearance. The pathway along the cliffs, between this portion of the town and Sandgate, forms one of the most charming walks which can possibly be conceived, the view from it being unsur passed in beauty and variety. Shorn cliffe station, it should be mentioned, ia nearer to what is now generally spoken of as "West Folkestone" than the junction station, and more largely used elusive of military). Average Train Service : Five each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 5/- /, 3/6 s, 2/6 t. Return Tickets (8 days), 7/6 f, 5/- -s. FOLKESTONE. — (Stations— FOLKESTONE TOWN and JUNC TION and FOLKESTONE HAR BOUR.) — A municipal (and, in conjunc tion with Hythe, a parliamentary) borough of East Kent ; a seaport, mar ket town, and parish, united with Dover as one of the Cinque Ports, in the hun dred and county court district of Folke stone, lathe of Shepway, union of Elham, and archdeaconry and diocese of Canterbury ; 17 miles from Canterbury, 15 from Ashford, and 5 from Dover. The route to and from the Continent via Folkestone and Boulogne has, under the present management of the South Eastern system, become the most fa voured by all classes of travellers, and is the one now generally used by royal and distinguished personages. The sea journey is very little in excess of the distance vid Calais and Dover, and now occupies twenty minutes less time than that route, owing to the magnificent steamers which have been put on the service (see page xi). The railway journey between the two capitals is lesseuedby 28 miles,and the whole j ourney from London to Paris, or vice versa, can now be accomplished by this route in a few minutes over eight hours. The South Eastern Company have much im proved Folkestone harbour and the packet service, ant) have infused a spirit of activity into the French authorities and officials with the view of adding to the already increased facilities afforded by the Northern Railway of Franco. With larger harbours and boats it is expected the duration of the journey from London to Paris will be still more reduced. Folkestone lays claim to very high anti quity, and has been supposed, from the coins and other relics discovered in the neighbourhood, to have been known to the Romans. It was called by the Saxons" Folcestane," and appears inthe Domesday Book under the name of " Falchestan." The first nunnery in England was established here by St. Eanswitha, the daughter of Eadbald, king of Kent, of which she herself became first prioress, but which was destroyed,

71 by visitors. The parish church of St. Mary and St. Eanswythe is an ancient structure. The chancel is of the early part of the twelfth century ; and in the north wall is an anc'ent tomb, with buttresses at the sides, and a range of trefoils in open work beneath the lower mouldings of the arch ; in front is a row of small mutilated figures ; and upon the tomb lies the effigy of a knight in armour, with his head resting on a helmet, and his feet on a lion. The monument is supposed to belong to some member of the Seagrave or Sandwich families. Against the east wall of tho south aisle is an altar tomb of variegated marble, in memory of the Herdsons, once lords of the manor. A brass plate in the nave records the name and character of Joan, mother of the celebrated discoverer of the circulation of tha blood, Dr. Harvey, who was a native of Folkestone. The rest of the edifice, both inside and out, is of very difftrent periods, and incongruous in character; it was completely restored and largely improved in 1809. There are four other churches — Christ Church (built in 1850, at the solo expense of the Earl cf Radnor, lord of the manor, and partly endowed by him) ; St. Peter's, erected in 1863 ; Holy Trinity, also built by tho Earl of Radnor, in 1868 ; and St. Michael aud All Angels, opened in 1873. Tlie Wesleyan, Congregationalist, Bap tist, Primitive Methodist, and Friends denominations have places of worship here. Sir Eliab Harvey's free grammar school has been rebuilt ; it was founded in 1674, and Dr. Harvey contributed to iis support by his will. The Town Hall was erected in 1860, on the site of the old one : it is in the Italian style, with plain rusticated ground floor and Cor inthian columns, and entablature above, with clock chamber, containing an illu minated clock by Messrs. Gillett <fe Bland, of Croydon : the large hall is about eighty feet by fifty feet in size, and there are council, magistrates', com mittee, and other rooms in the building, with police station and market under. The bathing establishment stands at the base of the cliff beneath " The Lees." On the lower tier is a large swimming and plunge bath, and also every description of medicated and invalid baths : the first floor is devoted toa scries of warm and cold baths, fitted in excellent style — one side for ladies, and the other for gentlemen — and the upper tier is set apart for the sub scription and assembly rooms, which are furnished in the samo manner and pos sess all the characteristics of the best London clubs, comprising reading, bil liard, and refreshment rooms, besides the large saloon, which is used for the balls and concerts that take place period ically, and at other times as a general lounge for the subscribers : it was opened in July, 1869, and is the property of a joint-stock company. If we except a small fishing and coasting trade, there is no business at all carried on in Folke stone, apart from that which is the natu ral consequence of its being the South Eastern Railway Company's harbour of embarkation and debarkation to and from the Continent. No harbour existed at Folkestone prior to the time of Henry VIII., and the works which were con structed under his orders were not re markable for strength. Henry visited the town in 1543, and a portion of his army embarked here for France. The town records of the years 1635, 1654, and 1699, show that effoits were made to keep open the harbour which here, as at Dover, was constantly choked up by tho accumulation of shingle, but it seems that they were insufficient, for in 1725 the inhabitants petitioned the Govern ment to grant them letters patent to collect charitable subscriptions through out the kingdom to repair the damages the harbour had sustained. An Act of Parliament was obtained in 1766 to raise money for the purpose of repairing the harbour, and for new works, which were to be maintained by a duty levied or. coals. In 1807 another Act of Parlia ment was obtained for making a new harbour, the capital being £22,000 in shares of £50; £37,500 more was ob tained in the same manner, and a further sum of £10,000 was borrowed of tho Government on mortgage. These sums were not, however, sufficient for the com pletion of the works, and the harbour, being again left to itself, soon became, as before, filled up with shingle and sand. In 1842 it was purchased by the South Eastern Railway Company, and the first step they adopted for arresting the shingle, was the carrying out a gre've, formed with piles, from tbe south-west 7

72 arm of the pier, which graduaUy led to the formation of a breakwater. This stopped the further accumulation of shingle in the harbour, which was then, at great expense, effectually cleared. This breakwater has been greatly im proved by constructions of masonry intended to bind the work together ; and at the same time great addi tions and improvements have been made both in the foundations and superstruc tures of the original piers, ln fact, Folkestone Harbour — now 14 acres in extent, with an entrance 123 feet wide — has, owing to these improvements, twenty feet of water when the tide is in, and is capable of being entered by steamers three hours and a half after high water ; during neap-tides there are occasionally four or five feet of water in the entrance at low water, and, immediately outside, sufficient for a steamer to take her pas sengers from the pier-head and work herself clearly off. The new pier enables passengers to land and embark at all times of the tide. The Harbour House, the residence of the Marine Superinten dent, was erected in 1843 ; it is of the Venetian style of architecture, and has a tower 100 feet in height, with an illumi jated clock. A magnificent view of the French coast is obtainable from the gallery at the top of the building. The custom house is a very handsome edifice, situated on the Quay, adjoin ing the Harbour Station; alongside of which are waiting and refreshment rooms, from which the passengers can at once step into the boats or trains. The Pavilion Hotel, on the west side of the harbour, is the property of the Railway Company. It is constructed almost en tirely of red brick with stone-dressings, and, although exceedingly plain, possesses an aspect of old - fashioned comfort. Market Day : Thursday. Fairs : Easter Thursday ; January 28th ; September 1st (pleasure). Area : 2,578 acres. Popula tion : 12,698. Municipal Electors : 2,353. Newspapers: Folkestone Chronicle (n.), Saturday, 2d. Folkestone Express (i.), Saturday, Id. Folkestone News and East Kent Chronicle (l.), Saturday, ld. Principal Hotels: Pavi lion (close to the Harbour) ; Paris ; and West Cliff. Average Train Service : Ten down and six up on week days (not including Tidal trains) ; five each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 20/- /, 15/- s, express ; 18/6/, 13/6 s, 6/-/, ordi nary. Return Tickets (8 days), 33/6 /, 25/- s, express ; 31/- /, 22/6 s, ordi nary. FORDWICH. — (Station— GROVE FERRY— 1 mile.) -An anoient town and corporate member of the cinque port of Sandwich, in the county of Kent (eastern division). It is in Bridge union and Canterbury county court district ; is distant two miles from Canterbury. The corporation style is " the mayor, jurats, commonalty," (fee. The mayor and jurats are justices of the peace by virtue of their offices, but it is seldom the number specified in the governing charter is kept up. The first charter was granted by Henry II., and the second by King Edward. The corpora tion has authority for an unlimited criminal jurisdiction, and a hundred court and court of requests, but they are practically obsolete. Fordwich was formerly a place of some importance ; the sea then flowing up the river Stour rendered it navigable for ships of con siderable size, which frequented this port. The river is still navigable for barges as far as the bridge above the town. The church of St. Mary consists of chancel, nave and north aisle. The Town Hall was rebuilt in 1555, and has been restored ; it is a square wooden framed building, with gaol underneath. There is an old ducking stool, in which scolds were formerly bound and ducked in the Stour; the feswelle (or thieves' well, in which felons were drowned — that being the general mode of execu tion in the Cinque Ports), is still shown. Near the Town Hall are the remains of an old fort. The corporate area extends over the whole of the parish (excepting a small portion on which there are no houses, and which is comprised in the boundaries of the city of Canterbury), of Fordwich and part of the parish of Sturry. Area : About 500 acres. Population: 224. FRANT— (STATION.)— A village and parish of the county of Sussex; in Ticehurst union, Tunbridge Wells connty court district, and Frant petty ses sional division. A small portion of the parish is in the county of Kent. St. Alban's Church is ancient, and contains monuments to the Abergavenny, Weller

73 and Browm families. Both village and church are romantically situated on the brow of a hill, and command most extensive views. Frant Court was for merly the seat of Lord Stratford de Redcliffe. To the west of Frant, but not visible from the line, stands the noble demesne of the Marquis of Aber gavenny, Eridge Castle (once one of the principal seats of the far-famed Neville family), an irregular but splendid cas tellated Gothic pile, the front cf which is almost covered with ivy and other creeping plants. It stands in a well wooded and watered park, abundantly stocked with deer, and comprising about 3,000 acres of land, being also sur rounded by about 10,000 more, all in cluded within the estate. The park plantations have been arranged with consummate taste, and nurtured with such care that many of tho trees have attained an enormous growth ; and within the park is a variety of rides (said to measure altogether fifty-four miles), which conduct to scenes of various characters, and occasionally embrace the most interesting objects in the adjacent country. In a part of tho park, near Frant, on a lofty knoll, 659 feet above the level of the sea, are the remains of au ancient circular encampment, said to be Saxon. The hill is therefore called " Saxonbury Hill." In 1828, a round tower was erected in nearly the centre of the entrenchments. The neighbour- hood abounds with mansions (including Shernfold Park), and genteel villa-resi- dences, among the prettiest of which is Saxonbury Lodge, the grounds of which are laid out with great taste, and com- mand fine views of Eridge Park and the surrounding country. About three miles and a half, also, to the east of the line in this part of its course is Bayham Abbey, a demesne of the Marquis Camden, originally built about the year 1200 for Premonstratensian Monks, or White Canons, and dissolved at the Reformation, when its revenues were applied by Wolsey to the erection of colleges at Ipswich and Oxford : it was afterwards forfeited to the Crown, and granted by Elizabeth to Viscount Mon- tague, whose descendants sold it to Lord Chief Justice Pratt, ancestor of the present marquis. Area: 9,066 acres. Popidation: 3,263. Average Train Service : Four each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares froyi London: 9/6 /, 6/6 s, 3/l£ t. Return Tickets (4 days), 15/- /, 10/6 s, 71- t. GATTON.— (Stations— REDHILL and MERSTHAM— li miles.) — A parish and village of the county of Surrey (mid division) ; in Reigate union, county court district and petty sessional division. This place is famous as being — next to Old Sarum— the most notorious of the " rotten ' ' boroughs which existed prior to the Reform Act of 1832. At the time of its disfran chisement, there was stated to be seven voters in all to return the two members of Parliament, but practically there were not more than three — namely, the lord of the manor, his agent and the rector. Gatton Park, the property of Lord Monson, is a beautiful domain, with a large sheet of water — covering more than 30 acres — known as " The Lake." At the sale of the manor and Estate, previous to the Reform Bill of 1832, the auctioneer, in describing the property, is stated to have made use of these words, to describe its charming scenery : " Open wide the gates of Paradise, and you enter Gatton Park." The parish church is an old building, in the Early English style. Between Gatton and Redhill, at a place called Battle Bridge, the Danes are alleged to have been defeated with great slaughter, by the Saxons. Area: 296 acres. Population : 267. GOD AL MING. — (Station— SHALFORD— 3 miles.)— A municipal borough, parish, and market town, in the western division of tho county of Surrey, hundred of Godalming, union and county court district of Guildford, arch deaconry of Stoke, and diocese of Win chester ; 3J miles from Guildford. It is a station on the London and Ports- mouth branch of the South Western Railway, and by its advantageous situa tion on the river Wey, has water com munication with Guildford, Aruudel, Chichester, and London. The town is of Saxon origin, and was originally called " Godhelm's Ing," meaning the meadow of Golhelm, a Saxon thane. Some have derived the name from Goda, a Saxon lady, who founded a religious house here and was renowned for her

74 abound in the neighbourhood. Fair: July 22. Area : 6,830 acres. Popida tion: 2,254. Average Train Service: N ine each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 5/6 /, 3/6 s, 2/2 *. Return Tickets (4 days), 8/6 /, 5/9 s, 3/9 /. GOMSHALL.-(ST ATION.) — A hamlet of the parish of Shere, in the county of Surrey (western division). It is pleasantly situated on a small stream called the Tillingbourn, at the foot of the North Downs range. Shere is distant one mile ; that place (in cluding Gomshall) has an Area ol 6,396 acres, and a Population numbering 1,660. Average Train Service : Seven each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 5/-/, 3/6 s, 2/6 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 7/6 f, 5/- s, 4/- t. GRAVESEND. — (STATION.)- A parliamentary (returning one member) and municipal borough of Mid Kent ; a market town, parish, poor-law union, and seaport, in the lathe of Aylesford, hundred of Toltingtrough, and deanery, archdeaconry, and diocese of Rochester, situated on the right bank of the Thames, 2 1 miles below London ; it is also a station, by means of a ferry to Tilbury, on the London and Southern! Railway. It has communication with London by steam-packets on the river and with Rochester (seven mile3 dis tant), <fec. The town is called " Graves ham " in Domesday Book, and at that time contained the three manors of Gravesend, Milton, and Parrock, which it still retains, held respectively by the Eai 1 of Darnley, Joseph Harvey, Esq., and the Corporation of Gravesend. In a charter granting the tithes of the town upon St. Augustine's Monastery at Can terbury, it is denominated " Graves hendo." According to Leland, " in the begynning of the tyme of Richard II., the Frenchmen entered the mouth of the Thaimes, and brent and spoyled al the way that they came, and at last, approaching this toune, set on fyre and .spoyled it alsoe. Kinge Henry VIII. buylded a block house at this toune, and foure others not farre from it." The forts now existing for the defence of the town and the approach to tbe metropolis are Tilbury, on the opposite shore, where Queen Elizabeth reviewed her troops on charity— hence " Goda's alms," or " God-aiming." The manor was formerly the property of the episcopal see of Salis bury. Queen Elizabeth first incor porated Godalming in the year 1575, under the style of " the warden and inhabitants;" the warden to be chosen on Michaelmas day, out of eight assist ants. The borough finally came under the provisions of the Municipal Reform Act. A commission of the peace, separate from the county, was granted in 1879, and the borough has its own police force. Edward III., in the 20th year of his reign, exempted the town by charter from several tolls. The urban sanitary authority is now vested in the corporation. The cemetery is controlled by a burial board. A private company supplies the gas of the borough. The public buildings comprise the parish church of SS. Peter and Paul, dating from temp. Henry VII., four dissent ing chapels, national, British and infant schools, town hall, market house, new public hall, county court, police station and Wyatt's almshouses. There are a few small charities. The Charterhouse Schools are in tbe borough, and, from their position, form a conspicuous land mark. Trade, Manufactures, &c. : For merly the manufacture of kerseys flourished here, but it is now decayed. The present manufactures are stockings, gloves, flannels, baizes, paper, parchment, and leather. There is also a small trade in timber carried on. Market Days : Wednesdays and Saturdays. Fairs: February 13, July 10. Area : 480 acres. Population : 2,444. Municipal Electors : 396. Principal Hotels : King's Arms ; Red Lion. GODSTONE. — (STATION.)— A village and parish of the county of Surrey (eastern division), in Godstone union and petty sessional division, and Reigate county court district. The station is at Lagham — three miles dis tant from the village — and adjoining the parish of Bletchingley, which, pre vious to the Reform Act of 1832, was a borough, returning two members to Parliament, the number of voters being about twenty. At Castle Hill and Godstone Green are remains of Roman encampments. The parish church is a restored building of the Early English style. Firestone and lime quarries

75 the approach of the Spanish Armada, and three other forts on the Kentish coast. In August, 1850, a fire broke out which destroyed houses and property of the value of £100,009, the rebudding of which has been a great improvement to the town. Gravesend was enfranchised by the Reform Act of 1867. It was not incorporated until the reign of Elizabeth, when tbe government of the town was entrusted, by charter, to a mayor, deputy mayor, eleven jurats, and twenty-four common councilmen, with a recorder, high steward, chamberlain, ite. In 16 2)4., the Corporation purchased the manor of Parrock, which comprehended the right of ferry across the river, the site of the town hall, the market place, and the free school. The Corporation act as the urban sanitary authority. The waterworks i.nd gasworks are in the hands of private companies. There is also a cemetery. The old parish church of Gravesend was burnt down in the reign of George II., and rebuilt at a cost of £3,000, when its name was altered to St. George's, in honour of the reigning monarch. The parish church of Milton, dedicated lo St. Peter and St. Paul, was built in the fifteenth century, and Holy Trinity Church, iu Milton, in 1848 ; St. James's was built in 1851, on a site given by the Earl of Darnley, and Christ Church in the year 1852. The Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist, a fine structure, was erected in 183 1, at a cost of £7,000. The Wesleyans, Baptists, Independents, Primitive Methodists, and Mormons have chapels in the town. The town hall, where the quarter and petty sessions are held, and the county court, where all municipal business is trans acted, were rebuilt in 1836, at a cost of £3,000, and have offices for the police, fire brigade, <fec, with dwellings for the superintendents, and underneath is the market house. It is a Doric building, with pillars and emblematic figures on its facade. Other public buildings are — the assembly rooms, built in 1841-2, at a cost of £3,000, with au organ, and accommodation for 1,000 people, a fine building with an Ionic portico ; the Workmen's Hall, Milton Mount College (a large and beautiful building for daughters of Congregational ministers), Parrock Hall (an industrial school for boys), the theatre, the dispensary and infirmary ; the town pier, completed in 1834, whence is the ferry to Tilbury, built at a cost of £30,0 .10 ; the Royal Terrace pier, erected in 1845, and costing £9,200, for the use of the Blackwall steam-packets ; and the Rosherville pier, for the use of passengers visiiing the well-known gardens of that name. Windmill Hill is a place of resort for juvenile excursionists. The institutions include a free grammar school, founded in 1580 ; there are thirty boys on the foundation, but it has since been in corporated with the National Society. Almshouses, built in 1836, accommodate thirty aged persons of both sexes, and there aro numerous other charities aud charitable bequests. Gravesend being the boundary*- of the port of London, customs afficers and pilots embark aud disembark here in respect of vessels from and to foreign ports. It is a place also where troops and passengers embark for long voyages, to avoid the passage down the river, and many royal and illustrious personages have landed here. It has carried on a flourishing trade, greater formerly than now, in supplying out ward-bound ships with stores. Besides this, the chief trades of the town are — fishing for shrimps, cod, turbot, ifec , and that of watermen in going with pas sengers and goods to and from passing vessels. Market Days: Wednesdays aud Saturdays, aud first and third Thursdays. Fairs : May 4th and October 24th (stock and pleasure). Area : (of municipal borough), 1,256 acres ; (of parliamentary borough), 3,159 acres. Population : 21,265, municipal ; parliamentary, 27,493. Municipal Electors : 2,770. Parliamentary Electors : 3,295. News papers : Gravesend Free Pres3 (l.), Saturday, ld. Gravesend Journal (a), Saturday, ld. Gravesend and Dartford Miscellany and Railway Guide (n.), Wednesday, |d. Gravesend and Dart ford Reporter (l.), Saturday, ld. Princi pal Hotels: Falcon; Prince of Orange; and Rosherville. Average Train Service : Eighteen each way on week days ; eight each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 3/6 /, 2/8 s, 2/1 t Return Tickets (4 days), 4/0 /, 3/6 s. GREENHITHE. — (STATION.) — An ecclesiastical parish (formed out of the civil parishes of Swanscombe and Stow) of the county of Kent (western

76 series of low trefoil-headed arches, in relief, spring from small pillars of Pet worth marble, and, most probably, a similar range of arches rested on the projecting plinth beneath the windows of the nave. In the pavement of the chancel a curious brass monument will be observed to John Lambarde, rector of this parish, who died in 1408. The tombs of the Wiltshires are curious. The eastern pointed window is large and handsome. Rather less than a mile from the church stands Stow Castle, a private mansion built on the site of an ancient Norman fortress, dating from the time of Edward HI. Of this castle a small square tower, covered with ivy, is the only relic of the olden edifice. Swanscombe is said to derive its name from Swine's camp, the Danish king Sweyn having erected a castle here to preserve a winter station for his ships. This place is also said to be the spot where the march of William the Con queror was impeded by the m en of Kent until he had consented to grant them a full confirmation of all their ancient laws and privileges. The manor-house is an ancient building, formerly the seat of the Weldon family. The manor is said to be the oldest in the county. The church is an ancient edifice, uninterest ing as regards its outward appearance, and presenting a plain interior. It con tains, however, some important monu ments erected in the early part of the seventeenth century to members of the Weldon family ; one in particular to Sir Ralph Weldon, who was chief clerk of the kitchen to Queen Elizabeth, and died in 1609. His effigy and that of his lady are represented in a recumbent attitude, and at their feet are the effigies of a son and a daughter. Three other sons and five daughters are represented, kneeling in front of the tomb. In the woods south of the church are some re markable caverns, called Clappernapper'a Hole, to which is attached some interest ing legend. The wood is much resorted to by gipsy parties. Population of Greenhithe : 1,452. Average Train Ser vice : Fifteen each way on week days ; eight each way on Sundays. Fares from London.- 3/3 /, 2/6 s, 1/8 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 4/6/, 3/6 s, 2 '9 t. GREENWICH— (STATION.)— A parliamentary borough, within the division) ; in Dartford union, county court district, and petty sessional division. Greenhithe consists of a main street, with a pier in the Thames, for the convenience of steam-boat passengers. The appearance of the place from the river is very picturesque. Its red brick cottages and tall chalk cliffs project boldly forward from the dark woods of Swanscombe, which, stretching far away inland, bound the distant horizon. From here started, on May 24th, 1845, the ill fated fifty-eighth exploring expedition to the Polar Seas, the Erebus and Terror, being under the command of the lamented Sir John Franklin, and Captains Crozier and Fitzjames. Within view of the river is the celebrated Ingress Abbey. This large mansion was built by the late Alderman Harmer out of the stone from Old London Bridge. It is a structure in the Tudor-Gothic style of architecture, and with its luxuriant wooded park is an object of great attraction. Near it are the ruins of a nunnery. Here are also a number of very excellent family resi dences ; the handsome row of semi detached villas in the Italian style at Cobham-terrace occupy a fine position, on an eminence overlooking a great extent of country. At Greenhithe are Roman cement works, chalk and lime works, and some market-gardening. A short distance to the right of Greenhithe, within the compass of a ten minutes' walk, and crowning an eminence which overlooks the Thames, stands Stow Church, dedicated to St. Mary, one of the most interesting edifices in this part of Kent. Two centuries since, its fine embattled tower was surmounted by a lofty octagonal spire, supported at the sides by elegant flying buttresses , but a terrific thunderstorm hurled part of it down, melting the bells as they hung, and made the speedy removal of the remainder necessary. It has a square massive tower at the west end, embattled, which is curiously constructed. The visitor will be sure to notice the fine proportions of the north doorway, and the richness of its decorative mouldings, which are still to be traced, though much injured by time. Pointed arches, spring ing from clusters of slender columns, separate the side aisles from the nave. A richly-decorated arch divides the nave again from the chancel, around which a

77 metropolitan area, and county of Kdnt (western division) ; it is the chief centre of a union, county court, and police dis trict in the Metropolitan Police, London School Board, and Central Criminal Court districts. The station at Green wich is situated about two huudred yards from the parish church. Opposite the station are the Almshouses, founded in the reign of Elizabeth ; and further on, towards the town, at the corner of Royal Hill, are baths and wash-houses, near to wliich may be observed the new lecture hall, which cost £(,,000, and is capable of holding a thousand persons. The library attached to this establish ment contains over eight thousand vo lumes. The route is easily followed to the Royal Hospital (see engraving at pageæzi-.), the great point of attraction to travellers from all parts of the world. Finding the old palace of Placentia to be in a state of decay, Charles II. caused it to be partly taken down, and a splendid pile of buildings to be erected in its place. This now forms the north-west wing of the hospital. It was built under tho direction of Webb, son-in-law to Inigo Jones, and became the occasional residence cf Charles. The structure which this monarch left un- finished, William III. granted, with the grounds thereunto belonging, to be converted into a hospital for aged and disabled seamen. The architect was the celebrated Sir Christopher Wren, who undertook to superintend the work without emolument. The hospital is divided into four wings, built principally of Portland stone ; two of these front the river, and two the park. The north- west wing next the river is that erected by Charles IL The north-east wing is called Queen Anne's building. In the south-west wing, called King Wil- liam's Building, is the Painted Hall, which we shall have occasion to de- and chapel, from each of which is conti nued a noble colonnade of the Doric order, 347 feet in length, and terminating with the palace of Henrietta Maria, con sort of Charles II., now the Naval Asylum, above which is seen the Royal Observatory on an eminence in the park. On the west wharf of the hospital is the obelisk, of Aberdeen red granite, erected to the memory of the chivalric Lieutenant Bellot, of Arctic celebrity. It stands on a plinth and three steps. The obelisk itself is highly polished, and the faces of the other work are " fine-axed." On the plinth is cut the simple inscription, " Bellot." On the opposite side of thepedestal is abronze tablet recording the sad event of his death. This monument is a prominent object from the river, being about thirty-four feet in height, and is an ap propriate tribute to one of the noblest sons of France. In crossing the broad walk of the central square, the statue of George II. , by Rysbrack, sculptured from a block of marble taken from the French by Sir George Rooke, is seen. Entering through the doorway in the centre of the first building ou our right, a broad staircase conducts to a long gallery, called King Charles's ward. In the Council-room are several paint- ings by Kneller, Lely, Gainsborough, Thornhill, and other celebrated artists. In the Antechamber are two large sea pieces, presented to the Hospital by Philip fiarman, representing the naval exploits of his ancestor, Captain Thomas Harman, in the reign of Charles H.; and six smaller pictures, represent- ing the loss of the Luxembourg gal- ley, which was burnt on her passage from Jamaica to London, in 1727. Captain William Boys, who was one of six survivors of this calamity, was after- wards Lieutenant-governor of the Hos- pital. In King William's Building is tho Painted Hall, a noble naval gallery, the design of Sir Christopher Wren, 106 feet in length, 56 in width, and 50 high. It is lighted on one side by a double range of windows, and is surrounded by a range of lofty Corinthian pilasters supporting a rich entablature. In the vestibule, which is surmounted by one of the two domes conspicuous on the hospital, a collection of dingy, tattered . flags droop, dull, motionless, and dusty, scribe. The fourth, or south-east wing, commonly called Queen Mary's Build ing, contains the chapel. From the river the hospital is seen to advantage, seated on the terrace, which is 875 feet in length. In tho centre is a landing place from the river, from whence the view of this sumptuous pile is strikingly beautiful, extending through a length ened perspective of elegant buildings, enriched by the stately domes of the hall

78 sidj walls display the landing of the Prince of Orange at Harwich, and of George I. at Greenwich. Several memo- rials of naval worthies are shown here, such as the moth-eaten coat of Nelson worn at the battle of the Nile, models of ships of wai, (fee. ; or the visitor may refer to some of the old pensioners, who are always near at hand, ready for a trifle to exercise their powers of memory, and several of whom may have been actors in one or other of the great naval engagements represented on canvas. It is but just to add to our brief notice of the paintings in the great hall, that they were principally obtained by the exer- tions of Edward Hawke Locker, Esq. A few yards along the colonnade,which is 347 feet in length, leads to the south-west quarter, where an alto-relievo comme- morates Nelson's 122 battles. An ob- ject that attracts attention is a huge gun, mounted upon a handsome metal car- riage, and pointing its threateniug muzzle across the river. It is a trophy brought by Admiral Duckworth from the Dardanelles in 1891. This gun car- ried marble shot, weighing 150 pounds each, the bore being 14 inches in diame- ter, or 3 feet 6 inches in circumference. On the sides of tho carriage which sup- ports it are the names and dates of vari- ous naval victories, the earliest being " Camperdown and Duncan, 1794 ; " the latest, " St. Jean D'Acre and Stop- ford, 1840." Engraved upon the top is a long inscription. The chapel was built by a self-educated architect, James Stuart, whose celebrated work on the " Antiquities of Athens " showed the ex- traordinary development of his genius. This chapel is described as the most highly decorated of any modern ecclesi- astical building in this country. In the vestibule aro statue3 of Faith, Hope, Meekuess, and Charity, after designs by West. A flight of fourteen steps leads through folding doors of mahogany, ex- quisitely carved, with an architrave, frieze, and cornice of statuary marble,iuto the chapel, which is 111 feet in length, and 52 in breadth, with a lofty arched ceiling, divided into compartments, and elegantly ornamented with foliage and other designs. Within the entrance is a portico of four fluted columns, of the Ionic order, each formed of one entire block of veined marble, 15 feet high, over the marble statues of the heroes, Nelson, Duncan, St. Vincent, and Howe, whose trophies they were. Here will be seen, also, the model of an antique ship, found in the Villa Mattea, given by Lord Anson. Standing upon the steps the view of the hall, with its ac- cessories of ornament and pictorial walls, is impressive. The ceiling, painted by Sir James Thornhill, was the occupation of nearly six years, and was paid for at the rate of three pounds per yard. It is in compartments; the figures in the centre represent King William and Queen Mary seated on a throne, at- tended by the cardinal virtues, aud sur- rounded with emblematical representa- tions of the seasons, the signs of the zodiac, and numerous allegorical devices from mythology and history. A series of portraits of the most distinguished admirals, together with paintings of their principal naval engagements, deco- rate tho walls ; and over the great arch at the upper end of the hall are the British arms supported by Mars and Minerva. The pictures are arranged some- what chronologically, beginning, at the left-hand corner,with the Armada and the naval heroes of Queen Elizabeth's reign, and ending, on the right-hand side of the entrance, with the bombardment of Algiers by Lord Exmouth, A painting of more than usual interest represents Henry VIII., in the Henri Qrace-a- Dieu, sailing to Calais to meet Franc's I. of France. This was the father of ships, and was the first double-decker that was ever built in England. The visitor should not omit to see a view of the old palace at Greenwich, 1690 (be- fore its endowment as an hospital), and a view of Windsor Castle as it appeared in the same year. Both these paintings, which are highly curious, are by Vors- terman. From the saloon a flight of steps leads into the upper hall, in wliich the funeral car of Lord Nelson is de- posited. The ceiling is decorated with portraits of Queen Anne and Prince George of Denmark, together with va rious emblematical figures, among which Sir Jame3 Thornhill has introduced his own likeness ; in the angles are the arms of England, Scotland, France, and Ire land, between which are represented the four quarters of the world with their several emblems and productions. The

79 which support the organ gallery. On each side of the portal are Corinthian pillars of scagliola, with 'bases and capi tals of marble, of which the shafts are 28 feet high; and on each side of the altar are corresponding columns wliich sup port the roof. The painting over the altar is by West ; the subject is the shipwreck of St. Paul at Melita, the Malta of the moderns. Over this is a clever chiar-oscuro of the Ascension ; and surmounting the lower windows are other paintings in the same style. The hospital formerly received about 3,000 naval pensioners of all ranks, but by a recent Act of Parliament out pensions were substituted, and the splendid pile appropriated as a Royal Naval College, having accommodation for 700 students. All officers of the Royal Navy and Marine Artillery and Engineers can be admitted, and a limited number of officers of the Mercantile Marine. The course of study includes the higher branches of mathematics, astronomy, hydrographic surveying, ex perimental sciences, marine engineer ing, naval architecture, fortification, in ternational and maritime law, modern languages, and hygiene. The infirmary is now used by the corporation known as the "Seamen's Hospital," formerly attached to the floating ship " Dread nought." To the south of the hospital is the naval school. This institution is intended for the clothing, maintenance, and education of the children of seamen. It comprises an upper and lower school. The scholars, now numbering about 800, are admitted between the ages of eleven and twelve, and receive a very efficient education from masters appointed for the purpose. The schoolrooms consist of two spacious wings, each 146 feet in length and 42 in breadth, connected with the central building by a colonnade of the Tuscan order, 180 feet long and 20 wide. The central building, formerly the palace of Queen Henrietta Maria, erected in 1635, and considerably en larged for its present purpose, contains apartments for the superintending cap tain, the chaplains, the head master, (fee. In the western wing are the chapel and the upper school room, with a lateral recess, over which are two spacious dor mitories, containing hammocks sus pended in two tiers on each side. To the west of this wing is tllO gym- nasium, with complete appaiatus for the practice of those athletic exercises so essential in a nautical education. In part of the ground is a circle of lofty masts and slighter poles, affording a complete course of gymnastics, peculiarly adapted to naval purposes. Tho east wing comprises the lower school-room, with dormitories and a re- fectory, together with a room for wash- ing. The grounds surrounding the build- ing are pleasantly laid out. A small observatory is attached to the house. The Park, one of the most favourite resorts of the citizens of London, and the scene of many a festive picnic, comprising nearly two hundred aci .s of undulating and wooded land, was laid out by the celebrated Le Notre, in the reign of Charles II. The rows of stately elms and chestnuts were planted by Evelyn. Famous as the park now is, it also wore its holiday garb on many a stately occasion in oldon time, for Greenwich was then specially favoured by royalty. Of the original palace of Greenwich, or as it was when repaired and partly rebudt in the reign of Henry VII., not one stone remains, but for many centuries our monarchs made it their frequent residence ; and it was the birthplace of the bluff Hal, and his daughters Mary and Elizabeth ; here also Edward Vi. died. When Henry VII. willed the coronation of his queen, Elizabeth, she came from Greenwich attended by " barges freshly furnished with banners and streamers of silk." When Henry VIII. avowed his marriage with Anne Boieyn, she was brought by " all the crafts of London" from Greenwich to the Tower, " trum- pets, shawms, and other divers instru- ments all the way playing and making great melody." Iu December, 1536, when the Thames was frozen, " the King's Majesty, with his beautiful spouse, Queen Jane, rode throughout the city of London to Greenwich." Queen Elizabeth had a predilection for Green- wich, and made it her favourite resi- dence. Here several councils were also held, at one of which (1559) it was deter- mined that no nuncio from the Pope should enter the realm. From One- Tree Hill, a well-known rendezvous for holiday folks, and the scene of much

80 merriment amongst yonng people, a splendid panorama of the river and the neighbourhood is displayed. It is, how ever, from the summit of the hill upon which stands the Observatory, 160 feet above the river, that the greatest variety of prospect can be enjoyed; and this leads us to speak of the building itself, which occupies the site of an old fortified tower, erected in the early part Of the fifteenth century by Humphrey, Duke of Gloucester, brother of Henry V. It consists of two buildings, one a low oblong edifice, which is properly the Observatory, and the other a house for the Astronomer Royal. The uppor part of the latter, however, besides serv ing as a library-room, is also fitted with instruments, and there is a camera obscura on the top of tho house. The library contains many scarce and valuable works, principally on scientific subjects. The meridian of this Observatory is cele brated as that whence tho longitude is computed in all British maps and charts. To insure greater accuracy and uni formity in the movement of railway trains, the clocks in all the stations keep Greenwich time. Tbe. chronometers for the navy are all rated here. On the eastern angle of the buildiDg there is a ball of wood, which is raised half-way to tbe top of a pole five minutes before I p.m., and at two minutes before one to the top, from whence at 1 o'clock, mean time, it is dropped, for the purpose of indicating the true time for tbe ship ping, that the commanders may set their chronometers. The town of Greenwich does not possess, in itself, many attrac tions, although various improvements have been made of late years. The streets are narrow, and the houses, with the exception of those recently erected, are mean and irregular. The parish church dedicated to St. Alphage (who was martyred on this spot by the Danes in the commencement of the eleventh century), is a large and massive structure in the mixed Greek style of architecture, with a square tower, above which is a cupola supported on pillars of the Corinthian order, and surmounted by a small spire. The interior contains nothing worthy of particular remark. There are five other churches in Green wich—St. Mary, Trinity, St. Paul's, St. John's and Christ's ; also many dissenting places of worship. Charities are abundant : the most worthy of note are Queen Elizabeth's College, the first public charity after the Reformation, instituted in 1558, for the maintenance of twenty poor men and their wives. The original endowment has been augmented by subsequent bequests, and its revenues are under the management of the Drapers' Company. Trinity Hospital, commonly called Norfolk College, founded by Henry Howard, Earl of Northampton, in 1613, for the relief and support of twelve poor men of the parish of Greenwich, and eight poor men of the parish of Shotsharn, in Norfolk, is endowed with £660 per annum. One of the noblest charities of Greenwich, it was founded by John Roan, who bequeathed all his posses sions, "to bring up so many poor town born children of Greenwich at school, that is, to reading, writing and cipher ing, and each of them 40s. per annum towards their clothing, until each of them shall accomplish the age of 15 years." Among the free schools is the Grey Coat, endowed in 1643 ; the other charities are the Green Coat, endowed in 1672, for the support and education of the sons of town-bom watermen, sea men, or fishermen of Greenwich. The Blue Coat, National, British, Infant, and Ragged Schools are also well supported. The Jubilee Almshouses receive fifteen inmates, each of whom receives a stipend of £10 per annum. The marketisa com modious building. There are also several institutions for the cultivation of litera ture. Greenwich contains many large factories, a rope-yard, iron foundries, iron steamboat works, and engineering esta blishments. The town is chiefly supported by the numerous visitors who throng here from all parts of the metropolis by railway and by steamer. Area (of the par liamentary borough which includes Charl - ton, Woolwich, Plumstead, and Dept sord): 8,581 acres. Population (of ditto): 169,ci61. Area (of the parish of Green wich): 2,051 acres. Population (of ditto) : 40,412. Parliamentary Electors (whole borough) : 22,161. The Train Service from and to the London terminii is very frequent — both on week days and Sun days ; and the Fares small. GROVE FERRY.— (STATION.) — A hamlet in the parish of Chislet, and

81 connty of Kent (eastern division). This is the nearest South Eastern Railway Station for Reculver. Average Train Service: Four each way on week days; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 15/-/, 10/- s, 6/2/. Return Tickets (8 days), 22/6/, 16/- s, 10/- /. GROVE PARK— (STATION.)— A suburb in the parish of Lee, and county of Kent (western division). The station is the point of junction for the Direct Bromley Line. Average Train Service : Twenty each way on week days ; nine each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 1/6 /, 1/- s, 8d. /. Return Tickets, 2/- f, 1/6 s, 1/2 /. GUILDFORD— (STATION.) —A parliamentary (returning one member) and municipal borough of West Surrey ; a market town and the capital of the county, beautifully situated on tbe de clivity of a range of chalk hills, on the eastern bank of the Wey, in the hundred of Woking union, county court district, and petty sessional division of Guildford, deanery of Stoke, archdeaconry of Surrey, and diocese of Winchester. It is also a station on the Portsmouth branch of the South Western Railway, and has water communication, by means of the river Wey, with London, Godalming, (fee. Guildford was a royal Saxon "ville," with a palace belonging to the king. It stood by a ford over the river, whose waters were remarkably clear, which caused it to be called Gegldford, or the Golden Ford. Alfred the Great be queathed it, by will, to his nephew Ethelred. Henry II. built a palace here, and the town was the occasional abode of royalty through several succes sive reigns. Two monastic institutions were also founded in the vicinity during the reign of Henry III. The borough returned two members to Parliament from the twenty-third of Edward I. until 1867, when the representation was reduced, and in 1874 it was made the seat of a suffragan bishopric to Win chester. Guildford is a very ancient prescriptive borough, and was considered such in its first known charter, that of Henry III., a.d. 1256. The town was governed by a mayor, recorder, seven magistrates, and an intermediate num ber of bailiffs, which seldom, however, exceeded twenty, by the style and title of "the mayor and approved men of Guildford," who held a court every thre6 weeks, and had the power of trying capital causes. Afterwards the title was changed to that of " the mayor and burgesses," and so continued until the Municipal Act. The corporation have adopted the Public Health Acts. The waterworks were transferred to them a few years sidee. In the reign of George II. an Act was obtained for lighting the town, the power being vested in the cor poration, but the gasworks were erected by a proprietary company in the year 1824. A cemetery is in existence for all the parishes except that of Stoke. Guildford contains twenty three churches, some of them in teresting specimens of antique archi tecture ; nine dissenting and Roman Catholic chapels ; a grammar school, founded by Edward VI., which enjoys a high reputation as a classical seminary ; Archbishop Abbot's school, with twelve trustees for its management ; and several national, British, parochial, and other schools ; the county assize courts, a town hall, police station, corn market, county court office, theatre, dispensary ,the Guild ford institute, the mechanics' institute, the working men's institution, Abbot's hospital, Stoke hospital, &c. The Royal Surrey county hospital, costing £15,000, was opened in 1868. In speaking of public buildings, the first place is, how ever, due to the ancient Castle, apparently of Norman origin ; and although its quadrangular keep is nearly all that now remains, standing boldly on the brow of the hill facing the west, and constructed chiefly of ragstone, flint, and chalk, there are traces of foundations that prove the original building to have covered altogether more than four acres of ground. The tower, together with the gateway, consists of three stories ; but all the floors, together with the roof itself, have long been destroyed, and there is no access to the upper part except by steps or ladder. There are some crypts, also, once forming a part of the castle, that are well worth an examination. The trade of the town and district is chiefly confined to agri culture. Market days : Saturdays (corn) and Tuesdays (stock). Fairs: May 4 and Nov. 22 (stock). Municipal Area: 543 acres; Parliamentary Area: 644 acres. Population: 9,106 (municipal); 9,801

82 (parliamentary). Municipal Electors: 1,422. Parliamentary Electors: 1,411. Newspapers : Guildford Journal (l. a), Tuesday, ld. Guildford Times, Satur day, ld.
