GUSTON— (Station— DOVER— 2 miles.) — A parish and village of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Dover union, county court district, and petty sessional division. The newly constructed Dover and Deal railway runs through the parish and has its station at Martin. The church is an interesting structure, which in part dates from the Norman era. Area : 1,041 acres. Popu lation: 728. shire and Wiltshire. Length, 66 miles; breadth. 42 miles ; circumference, 225 miles; square miles, 1,672. The Isle of Wight, which is included in the county, is 22 miles long by 13 broad, with a cir cumference of 56 miles. The principal rivers are the Itche_, Anton, Hainble, Avod, Stour, Exe, and Test. There are also the Andover and Basingstoke canals, and nearly 3,800 miles of roads. The railways belong chiefly to the South Western system. A trunk line from London enters the county on tho north east at Farnborough, passing by Basing stoke and Winchester to Southampton. The South Coast line extends out of Sussex to Portsmouth. A branch of the South Western line extends from Gosport to Salisbury, crossing the main line at Bishopstoke. The Southampton and Dorchester line throws off branches to Lymington, Christchurch and Bourne mouth. There is also a lino from Redbridge to Andover, and from Basing stoke to Salisbury. One from Ash aud Farnham to Winchester passes by Alton, and there is another from Southampton to Netley, and from Bishop's Waltham to Petersfield. Porchester is intersected by a line from Havant to Fareham The direct Portsmouth railway from London runs by Petersfield and Havant. A branch from Reading to Basingstoko connects the Great Western system with the South Western. The South Eastern line from Guildford, via Ash, to Reading, passes Farnborough and Blackwater. In tbe Isle of Wight there is a line from West Cowes to Newport, and another from Ryde to Ventnor. The county has a great variety of soils, but the prin cipal part is chalk ; the Dorsetshire border has large tracts of heath, and towards the sea are great quantities of marsh land, but very fertile ; all the re mainder is excellent land. It is one of the most fertile and populous counties in England. On the downs, of which a ridge runs almost across the country, are fed extensive flocks of sheep. Be sides wheat, barley, and hops, it is famous for bacon, honey, and timber, the last in particular, on account of its great woods, of which the principal are the New Forest, and the Forest of Berc. In the chalk district, Walbury Beacon is 1,011 feet high (the highest chalk in England), Sidon Hill is 942 feet high, H A L S T E A D.-(STATION.)-A village and parish of tho county of Kent (western division); in Sevenoaks union, county court district, and petty sessional division. The parish church of St. Mar garet is an ancient building. Area : 827 acres. Population: 365. Average Train Service : Ten each way on week -days ; three each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 3/9 f, 2/9 s, 1/5$ t. Return Tickets (4 days), 5/4 /, 4/- s, 2/6/. HAM STREET.— (STATION.)— A village (chiefly in the parish of Orle stone, but partly in Warehorne), of the county of Kent (eastern division). The village contains a public hall and a chapel. A stock fair is held here annually, on the last Thursday in August. Average Train Service : Four each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 15/-/, 10/6 s, 5/2J /. Return Tickets (8 days), 24/-/, 17/6 s. HANTS (County of). — The •more correct designation of this county, though but little used, is Southampton shire. Its most contracted title is that of Hants. It is a maritime county, bounded on the north by Berkshire, east by Surrey and Sussex, south by the English Channel, and west by Dorset-

83 Butser Hill 917 feet, Beacon Hill 900 feet, aud Portsdown Hill 444 feet. In the Isle of Wight the downs range from 400 to 600 feet high, rising to 845 feet at St. Catherine's Hill, and are accompanied with ironsand, wealden clay, (fee. The scenery of the interior of the island, and of Undercliff at its back, is proverbial for its beauty. Hampshire returns four members to Parliament, two for each division, north and south, and the Isle of Wight also returns one member. It is in the western circuit, the assizes being held at Winchester, and it com prises an archdeaconry in the diocese of Winchester, province of Canterbury. The borough representation comprises Portsmouth, Southampton, and Win chester (city), two members each; Andover, Christchurch, Lymington, Newport (I. of W.),and Petersfield, one member each. The shire has 38 hun dreds, 10 liberties, 351 civil parishes, besides parts of others, 24 poor-law unions, 1 poor-law union under a Local Act, 1 poor-law parish, 26 regis try districts, 9 municipal boroughs [An dover, Basingstoke, Lymington, New port (I. of W.). Portsmouth, Romsey, Ryde (I. of W.) Southampton (county of itself), and Winchester (city)], 22 urban sanitary authorities, 22 rural sanitary authorities, and 20 turnpike trusts. It also has one court of quarter sessions, and is divided into 14 petty sessional divisions, and 17 lieutenancy sub divisions. The boroughs of Andover, Portsmouth, Southampton, and Win chester (city), have commissions of the peace and separate courts of quarter sessions ; the boroughs of Basingstoke, Newport (I. of W.), Romsey, and Ryde (I. of W.), have commissions of the peace only. The boroughs of Basing stoke, Newport (I. of W.), Portsmouth, Ryde (I. of W.), Southampton, and Winchester (city), have their own police. Christchurch is a corporate borough, not subject to the Municipal Corporations Acts. In the extreme north Hampshire consists of the lower eocene strata (Lon don clay, &c.) An extensive tract in the north and centre exhibits chalk and its associated marls. The London clay beds reappear in a kind of belt crossing the county from Havant towards Salisbury. The neighbourhood of Southampton dis plays the Barton and Bagshot series, which also extend round by the New- Forest to Christchurch. The Isle of Wight has the upper eocene beds (fluvio marine) in the north, chalk in the cen tral parts, and the greensands and wealden clay in the south. The geology of this island is peculiarly interesting. Hampshire was a seat of the Belgæ, and was part of Britannia Prima, and of Wessex. The Britons styled it Gwent, i.e. full of downs. In the ninth and teuth centuries tho Danes wasted Hamp shire ; and in the Parliamentary war several battles aud sieges took place here. There are many Roman, monas tic, and castellated antiquities (some of which are in good preservation), as Netley and Beaulieu Abbey, and Por chester, Carisbrook and other castles. The manufactures are of little impor tance, except such as are connected with the ship-building yards at Portsmouth and Northam. Overton has silk mills ; and in a few other places, linseys, drug gets, bombazines, <fec, are made. The making of bank-note paper is carried on at Freefolk, and of watch chains at Christchurch. Principal Markets, Fairs, &c. — Andover : Fridays — November 17 (cattle). Basingstoke : Wednesdays and Saturdays — a large stock fair is held in July. Gosport : Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. Lymington: Mondays — May 12, October 2 (general stock). Newport (I.W.): Saturdays and alter nate Wednesdays. Portsmouth : Tues days and Saturdays. Romsey : Thurs days — Easter Monday, August 26, — November 8. Southampton: Fridays Trinity Monday and Tuesday. Win chester : Wednesdays and Saturdays — first Monday in Lent, August 2 (stock and cheese), September 12, October 23 and 24. Yarmouth (LW.) : Fridays. Area of county : 1,032,105 acres. Popu lation: males, 275,393; females, 269,291 ; total, 544,684. Parliamentary Electeirs in 1 880 (excluding boroughs) : North Division, 5,761 ; South Division, 9,863 ; Isle of Wight, 4,841. HASTINGS.— (STATION.) — A parliamentary (returning two members) and municipal borough of East Sussex ; one of the Cinque Ports, a market town, poor-law union of thirteen parishes, .and county court district, in the arch deaconry of Lewes and diocese of Chi chester. It is also the eastern terminus

84 of the London Brighton and South Coast Railway. The old town of Hast ings is situated in a valley between two hills, opening to the sea. On the east hills are traces of a Roman encampment, and on the west are the ruins of the castle. The new part of the borough, called St. Leonards, is in a direct line along the shore to the westward. The name of Hastings appears, in conjunc tion with that of " Pevensea," in a charter of King Ossa. The name is probably derived from the tribe of the Hestingii. In the reign of Athelstan, the town possessed a mint, and in that of Edward the Confessor it was incor porated among the Cinque Ports. The Normans landed not far to the west ward, and the famous battle of Hastings took place at Battle, in its vicinity. In 1090 William Rufus took up his abode in Hastings Castle, which had only just been built or restored, and in the same year Battle Abbey was consecrated. In 1360 the town suffered from the French, and lost its importance until it gradually became celebrated as a watering-place. Hastings has been a place of note from very early times. Elizabeth ,-sve the town a charter appointing a m<.jor and twelve jurats. The corporation, as now constituted, is the urban sanitary authority. The borough has a separate court of quarter sessions, and its own police force. A complete system of main drainage has been executed. The waterworks belong to tho town; the supply is chiefly obtained from Artesian and other wells, whence the water is pumped by steam-power to the summit of the hills. The gasworks belong to a company. There is a handsome borough cemetery at Ore, some distance from the town. The ancient castle is tastefully laid out in walks and gardens. There are seven churches, including All Saints' (1068) and St. Clement's (1284). The Independents have built a handsome chapel at St. Leonards. Other denomi nations, including the Baptists, Wes leyans, and Roman Catholics, have places of worship, the last-named having also a college (All Souls'). Other struc tures include the town hall, music hall and assembly rooms, infirmary, dispen sary, and a handsome memorial tower to the late Prince Consort. There is also a handsome pier. The inhabitants are chiefly occupied in providing for the wants of the numerous visitors, Hast ings having long enjoyed the reputation of being one of the most favoured English sea-coast resorts. [Fairlight is situated about two miles north of the town. From this spot, which rises gradually to an elevation of nearly 600 feet, the eye wanders over a fine country of hill and dale, varied with numerous towns ; a wide expanse of the British Channel, extending from Beachy Head to the South Foreland, a distance of eighty miles, and bounded by the cliffs of Boulogne. A descent from the rocks, by several paths, leads to the Dripping Well and to Fairlight Glen, 560 feet above the sea. At the top of the glen is Fairlight Place ; the road branching off to the right leads to the Lovers'-seat, a romantic Bpot, from whence may be seen a glorious view of the bold sweep of the cliffs right away to Dungeness, with masses of undercliff piled over each other in romantic con fusion, aud clothed with brushwood down to the very edge of the sands, while across the sea may occasionally be seen, in clear weather, the dim outline of the French coast. A charming spot is Pett, a small village north of Fair light, four miles and a half from Hast ings. At low water, during the spring tides, the remains of a wood may he seen imbedded in the sands. Gucstling is a village north of Fairlight and Pett. Broomham Park, which skirts the side of the road, is a seat belonging to the Ashburnham family. Mayfic ld, in the parish of Guestling, is the birthplace of Gregory Martin, the translator of the Rheims version of the Bible. Ore is a small parish, two miles north of Hast ings. The church contains a sepulchral brass. Ore Place, a mansion belonging to the Elphinstone family, is situated on the north side of the churchyard. Part of the house is very old. A little on the Hastings side of Ore Rectory, is a path which leads through fields to the Old Roar, a romantic spot, and a fa vourite resort of the artist. Hollington is a small parish north-west of Hastings, chiefly remarkable for the picturesque and secluded situation of its church, which is in the centre of a wood, a quarter of a mile from any habitation. A longer excursion may be made to

85 Bodiam Castle (13 miles), a distance which will be slightly increased if, as may easily be done, Brede and Northiam are taken in the way. The return may be by Sedlescombe. Brede is distant from Hastings one mile only, and should be visited, if only to examine the old parish church and its beautiful monuments. Brede Place, of which the great hall, &c, still remain, is now a farm-house. Crowhurst lies between Hollington and Catsfield. Crowhurst Church stands pleasantly in a valley, surrounded by trees. Tho nave was rebuilt 1794. In the tower window are considerable remains of stained glass. Crowhurst was long held by the Pelhams ; aud in the tower door-case, and the tracery of the windows above, occurs the well-known Pelham Buckle, the achievement adopted in memory of the taking of the French King at Poic- tiers, an exploit in which Sir John Pelham assisted. A wooden buckle, probably a part of the old screen, is also nailed to the front of the gallery. In the churchyard is a noble yew of un- known antiquity, twenty-seven feet in circumference at four feet from the ground. South of the church are the remains of an ancient manor-house of late Early English character. It was a small parallelogram with a porch, and contained only threo rooms, a vaulted ground floor, a large room above, and one over the porch, perhaps an ora- tory. The east window of the large room has very good mouldings.] Mar- ket Day : Saturday. Fairs: Whit Tues- day and July 26. Municipal Area : 1,636 acres. Parliamentary Area : 4,617 acres. HEADCORN.— (STATION.) —A village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in Hollingbourne union, and Maidstone county court district and petty sessional division. Headcorn is situated in a valley, which is tradition ally reputed to have been an estuary, or great arm of the sea. Marine shells, chiefly of a small size, are continually being found here. Tbe town is situated on a branch of the Medway, and on the road leading from Maidstone to Tenter den. The church, dedicated to St. Peter and St. Paul, is an ancient struc ture. In tbe churchyard is an oak of extraordinary size, measuring forty feet in circumference. Thero are dissenting places of worship and schools in this village. Hops and fruit are grown here. In this parish, on Mottenden Manor, there was a monastery of Crouched Friars, where " miracle plays " are said to have been performed ; this, with one exception — Boughton Blean — being the only place in Kent where these extrava gances took place. Near Headcorn is Chart Sutton, and the fine seat and park of the De Bouveries, the house most beautifully situated, overlooking the Weald and its contiguous districts. The neighbourhood, also, is said to have been formerly planted in vineyards, from the produce of which considerable quantities of excellently -flavoured wine were made. Sutton Valence, too, though now an insignificant village, deserves notice as having been the pro perty of the Valences, formerly a power ful baronial family in this district ; and near it are the venerable ivy-mantled ruins of Sutton Castle, which, from the remains of the keep aud walls, appears to have been strongly fortified, and may perhaps have been used as a place of defence for its lords during the wars of the barons. The churches of both these

86 be superior for its bracing qualities to any other seaside resort in England, although its exposed position renders it very cold aud bleak. Area of Chapelry : 100 acres. Population: 2,097. Newspaper: Herne Bay Ob server and East Kent Times (n.), Saturday, Id. Principal Hotels: Brunswick ; Dolphin ; Railway ; and Station. villages are good specimens of the grave Norman style, and contain within them some good carvings aud interesting monumental brasses. Tbe three vil lages of Sutton Valence, East Sutton, and Chart-next-Sutton are contiguous. East Sutton Place is the residence of Sir Edward Filmer, Bart. The Cloth workers' Grammar School, founded in 1576, by William Lambe, Esq., has been much enlarged and repaired. The foundation is designed for the free education of twenty-four boys resident in the county of Kent, and for six or more sons of members of the Cloth workers' Company, who are entirely supported by them at the school. There are almshouses, and a national and British school at Sutton Valence. Average Train Service : Six each way on week days ; two each way on Sun days. Fares from London : 13/- /, 8/6 s, 3/10 /. Return Tickets (8 days), 19/6 /, 12/0 s, 7/4 /. HERNE BAY.-(Station-STURRY — 5 miles.) — A watering place and chapelry, in the parish of Herne and county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Blean union and county court district, and Canterbury petty sessional division. This place sprang into existence a few years ago. The town or street stands about the centre of the parish of Herne, and directly faces the North Sea. The church of St. Martin is a handsome building, consisting of a nave, two aisles, and three chancels, with a square tower. It is partly in the Early English and partly in the Perpendicular style, and was restored in 1854. Several curious tombs and brasses may be seen here. The chapel-of-ease to tho mother church is a neat Gothic building. There are places of worship for Nonconformists and assembly rooms for visitors. Pro minent objects in the town are the clock house or tower, erected on the parade at a cost of £4,000 by Mrs. Thwaites, and the pier (opened by the Lord Mayor ot London, Sir Sydney H. Waterlow, Bart., in 1873). The former is 75 feet high, and forms an excellent land mark by night as well as by day, the faces of the clock being illuminated. The parade extends nearly the whole length of the town, which is governed by Improve ment Commissioners. The air at Herne HIGHAM.— (STATION.)-A vil lage and parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; iu North Aylesford union and petty sessional division, and Roches ter county court district. The village is aucient, a church haviug existed here before the Norman Conquest. A nun nery was established here by King Stephen. An ancient causeway leads across the marshes to the Thames, over which there was formerly a ferry. Near the station is a barrow. The church is venerable, and contains a piscina, a large aud ancient altar tomb, some curious tiles and a font. Over the communion table is placed a tablet in commemoration of Sir Francis Head, Bart., who resided on his estate, called the Hermitage, in this parish, and died there in 176S. Gad's Hill, on tho Rochester-road, celebrated by Shakespeare as the spot where Prince Henry and Falstaff robbed travellers, is in the south-western part of this parish. There is a comfortable inn at this place, with a characteristic portrait of Falstaff on one side, and Prince Hal on the other. Here long resided our great novelist Charles Dickens, to whom all who read the English language are indebted. Three miles from Higham Station is Cowling Castle, said to be so named from its cold, bleak situation. It was originally a square building, flanked by towers, surrounded by a moat, and having at a short distance a detached gateway for the principal entrance. At the south-east angle are the remains of a circular tower, picturesquely clothed with ivy ; but the rest of the building, with the exception of the gateway, is little more than a heap of ruins. The gateway is a very bold and handsome structure, consisting of an arched entrance, flanked by two large semicircular towers, embattled and machicolated. The groove of the port cullis is still visible. There was an ascent by a flight of stone steps within each tower, to their roofs. On the front Bay is considered by some authorities to

87 of the eastern tower is affixed a tablet of brass, in the form of a deed or grant, with Lord Cobham's seal of arms de- pending, and bears an inscription in ancient characters. According to tradi- tion, the founder, John, Lord Cobham, temp. Richardll., 1310, was apprehensive that the strength of his castle might give umbrage at court, and therefore set up this inscription to vouch for the purity of his intentions. Sir George Brooke, Lord Cobham, in the reign of Mary, successfully defended this castle against his grandson, Sir Thomas Wyatt. The village of Cowling is small. The church is ancient. Area : 3,141 acres. Population : 1,098. Average Train Ser- vice : Twelve each way on week days ; eight each way on Sundays. Fares from London ; 4/6 /, 3/3 s, 2/4 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 6/6/ 5/- s, 3/9 /. HILDENBOROUGH.— (STA- TION.) — A small hamlet and ecclesias- tical parish (formed out of the civil parishes of Tonbridge and Leigh) of the county of Kent. The church was erected in 1844. The village possesses a work- ing men's institute. Area ; 3,380 acres. Population : 1,182. Average Train Service : Ten, each way on week days ; three each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 7 j- /, 4/9 s, 2/4 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 11/- /, 8/- s, 4/6 /. HUNDRED OF HOO.— This •district is mainly comprised in tbe tongue of marsh land which stretches from Higham and Strood between the Thames and Medway channels. That portion of it which faces the North Sea opposite Sheerness is known as the Isle of Grain ; it is a parish in the mid division of Kent ; the marshes and a wide creek once rendered the parish a perfect island, but it is now connected by road with Rochester, some twelve miles distant, which place only affords land communication with the parish. From Sheerness the Medway has to be crossed by boat, which in rough weather is an unpleasant journey. The north- east corner of the island is strongly for- tified, the earthworks enclosing barracks for 300 artillerymen. Huge guns command the entrance to both the Med- way and the Thames. Almost in a line due north with the fort, is stationed the Nore lightship, a well-known beacon for mariners. The church — St. James's — is very ancient, the arch dividing the chancel and the nave displaying traces of Saxon architecture, and the pews bearing date 1645. The monastery at Minster formerly held sway over the church. [A new railway from Higham to Port Vic toria, a point between Queenborough and Sheerness, but on the north side of the Medway, is now in course of construction. There will be a deep-sea pier at the port, from which there will eventually be a direct steam-boat service to Belgium, Holland, and Germany.] Area : 3,156 acres (much of it marsh land). Popu lation: 292. HYTHE.— (STATION.)— A parlia- mentary (returning one member con- jointly with Folkestone and Sandgate) and municipal borough of East Kent, a seaport and one of the Cinque Ports, market town, parish, and bathing place, situated on the south coast of Kent, at the foot of a steep hill, in the union of Elham, huudred and county court dis- trict of Hythe, lathe of Shepway, deanery of Elham, and archdeaconry and diocese of Canterbury, 7 1 miles from London by road, 20 from Canterbury, and 5 from Folkestone. Hythe is a corruption of "Have" or "Haven" derived from its harbour. It would appear that there was originally a very ancient port, called "Limene" which became choked with sand, and from whence the inhabitants removed to West Hythe; this place also shared a similar fate, and the present town of Hythe rose into importance Until the sand tilled its harbour to such an extent that it can now only be approached by small fishing boats. That it was at one period a place of con- sequence, and had a good harbour, is proved by the circumstance of its having been made one of the Cinque Ports, and furnishing five ships, with twenty men and a boy to each, for the Royal Navy. In a crypt under the church is a mass of human bones, said to be those of Britons who were slain in a battle with the Saxons in 845, and in the neighbourhood are the remains of Saltwood Castle. The town was incorporated by Queen Elizabeth, with a mayor and jurats, and was governed under her charter until the passing of the Municipal Act. It has a commission of the peace, with a recorder, magistrates, and a police force, and holds quarter sessions, and petty sessions fort- 8

88 j longing to a company. The burial board is not connected with the corporation. | The parish church of St. Leonard's is a nightly. An Act was passed in the 38th year of the reign of George III., whereby commissioners, now represented by the members of the town council, are ap pointed for paving, lighting, (fee. The waterworks are the property of the cor poration. There are also gasworks be- Norm an structure, with atower that forms a landmark for mariners. The other public buildings include Wesleyan , Indepen dent, and Primitive Methodist chapels; a

89 guildhall and market house, rebuilt by the corporation in 1794, a gaol, barracks for 300 men, the royal school of musketry, a literary institute, a public library and newsroom ; a dispensary, and baths, with waiting rooms, built by the corporation in 1854 at a cost of £2,000. Among the charities are — St. Bartholomew's hos- pital, founded in 1318 for five brothers and eight sisters ; St. John's hospital, founded in 1570, for two men and seven women; and a few others. The national schools are supported by voluntary contributions. Hythe depends for its trading prosperity upon the School of Musketry, where there are constantly members of the army and of the volun- teer corps, learning the use of the rifle ; and upon the influx of visitors in the summer, who resort to the town for bathiiig. The reputation of the town for sanitary purity is very high. There are also some fishing boats belonging to the place, and a few colliers unload here. Market Days : Thursdays and Saturdays. Municipal Area : 1,744 acres. Parlia- mentary Area (which includes Folkestone and Sandgate) : 13,591 acres. Municipal Population ; 3,383. Parliamentary Popu- lation : 24,078. Municipal Electors : 554. Parliamentary Electors : 2,748. Principal Hotels : The Seabrook (property of the South EasternRailway Company); Swan ; and White Hart. Average Train Service : Eight down and five up on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 19/- /, 14/- s, express ; 17/- /, 12/3 s, 5/8 /, ordinary. Return Tickets (8 days), 32/-/, 23/6 s, exp. ; 27/0/ 19/- s. KENLEY— (STATION.)-A ham- let in the parish of Coulsdon and county of Surrey (eastern division). The village is situated in Caterham Valley (1 mile east from Caterham Junction), and on a part of the Surrey downs. The several roads in which the residences are built wind up the hills, which are of consider- able altitude and finely wooded. Kenley contains some fine mansions, with exten- sive grounds attached, some of which are built on spots in the ascent of the hdls, commanding very extensive views ; there is a good supply of excellent water, also gas. The church of All Saints — a chapel of ease to Coulsdon church — is in the Early Geometrical style. Average Train Service: Ten each way on week days; four each way on Sundays. Fare* from London: 3/- / 2/4 s, 1/2 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 4/9 f, 3/6 s. KENT (County ol).— Kent is a maritime county, bounded on the north by the Thames and German Ocean, east and south-east by the latter and the Straits of Dover, south by Sussex, and west by Surrey, and having on its east and south coasts the North and South Forelands and Dungeness. Length, 67 mdes ; breadth, 35 miles ; circumference, 190 miles ; square miles, 1,627. Watered by the Stour, Medway, Darent and other rivers. The Medway is the noblest feeder of the Thames, and has a total length of sixty miles, forty of which are navigable. Lime-burning is carried on upon the Lower Medway ; on the upper streams, the paper trade, to which it is navigated by steam. Ships and large vessels get up to Rochester bridge. The Dour River is a very trifling stream, but it received its present name from the Britons, signify- ing " water," and was known also to the Romans as the Durius. It gives name to Dover, in the valley of which it anciently formed the haven, now built upon and carried out seaward. The river Rother rises in Sussex ; it is navigable on its entry into Kent, and was anciently called by the Britons and Romans the Limene, entering the sea at New Romney. In the time of Ed- ward I. it deserted its channel, and formed a new one by Rye and Winchel- sea. The principal canal is the Royal Military Canal,running along the borders of Romney Marsh from the P^other to Hythe, very little above the level of the sea. The Gravesend and Rochester Canal has been partly used for the North Kent Railway, but its basins and the portions from Gravesend to Higham still remain. The county is intersected by nearly 4,400 miles of roads, and the railway communi- cation is effected by the lines belonging to the South Eastern, and London Chatham and Dover Railway Companies. On that part of the coast bounding the estuary of the Thames, there are num- erous examples both of the gain and loss of land by the sea. Off tbe east shore lie the well-known Goodwin Sands, between which and the mainland is the equally weD-known roadstead called the Downs. Kent may be designated a hilly country, being divided by two

90 nearly parallel chains of chalk hills, which traverse the county west to east, terminating in lofty chalk cliffs at Dover, Folkestone and Hythe. The climate of Kent is in general mild and genial. The soil may be divided into the gravel, chalk and clay, which pro duce, where they mix in due proportion, an extremely fertile loam. The alluvial soils along the Thames and Medway7, and in Romney Marsh, produce some of the richest pastures in the kingdom. The gardening of the county was much improved by the Netherland refugees in the sixteenth century. The woods iu Kent arc extensive, and produce much oak, beech, hop-poles, billet-wood, hoops and bark, besides timber for ships and house-building. The lathe of Sutton-at- Hone is a great fruit district, and the valley of the Medway is famous for hops, and the hopping season is as joyous here as the vintage is elsewhere. Building stone is quarried in the chalk, and the ragstone of the Weald. Fa versham, Milton and Whitstable are celebrated for their oysters. The county returns two members for the east division, two for the mid, and two for the west. It is in the South-eastern circuit, the assizes being held at Maid stone, and it constitutes the archdeacon ries of Canterbury and Rochester, in those dioceses, province of Canterbury. The borough representation comprises Canterbury (city), Dover, Greenwich (metropolitan borough), Maidstone, Rochester (city), and Sandwich, two members each, Chatham, Gravesend, and Hythe, one member each. The shire has 5 lathes and 61 hundreds, and comprises the barony of Bircholt, the lowery of Tunbridge, the liberty of the Isle of Sheppey, the liberty of New Romney, 437 civil parishes, besides parts of others, 25 poor-law unions (exclusive of the Metropolis), 1 poor-law district under a special Act (Canterbury), 3 poor-law unions within the Metropoli tan district (Greenwich, Lewisham and Woolwich), 29 registry districts, 12 municipal boroughs [Canterbury (city and county of itself), Deal, Dover, Faversham, Folkestone, Gravesend, Hythe, Maidstone, Margate, Rochester (city), Sandwich, and Tenterden], 34 urban sanitary authorities, 25 rural sanitary authorities, -and- 22 turnpike trusts. It also has one court of quarter sessions, and is divided into 16 petty sessional divisions and 17 lieutenancy sub-divisions. All the boroughs above named have commissions of the peace and separate courts of quarter sessions, and their own police. The liberty of Romney Marsh has petty and general sessions,and theancient borough of Queeu- borough has a court of quarter sessions distinct from the county. Dover, Hythe, New Romney, and Sandwich are cinque ports, aud Deal, Faversham, Folkestone, and Margate are corporate members of one or other of them. Fordwich (corporate member of the cinquo port of Sandwich), Lydd (corporate member of the cinque port of New Romney), and New Romney are governed under old charters and not amenable to the Municipal Corporations Act, 1835. The Cinque Ports' justices exercise jurisdiction in and for tbe Deal Division of the liberties of the Cinque Ports (comprising the parishes of Ringwould and Walmer and the hamlet of Kingsdown), and the parish and town of Ramsgate. The towns of Ramsgate and Tunbridge Wells main- tain police establishments separate from the county. A considerable portion of the county is included in the Metro- politan Police, Central Criminal Court, Metropolitan Board of Works and London School Board jurisdiction. Chalk and greensand prevail in tbe hills, and cla.y mixed with gravel, sand or loam in the more level tracts. Kent is first distinctly noticed by the name of Cantium, doubtless a Latinization of the ancient British appellation of the same territory. By the Saxons it was called at first Kant-wara-rike , meaning the " Kentish men's country." The present name is an evident derivation of the first word of the Saxon compound. In the earliest times of English history the "men of Kent " showed themselves true to their orifiin, and were looked upon as the stay of our naval power. Hence the establishment of the Cinque Ports, endowed with exclusive and valuable privileges, and which, down to the seventeenth century, supplied the greater part of the shipping and 3eamen to our fleet. It remains at the present time in the possession of the chief of our naval arsenals, and contains many important establishments. Julius Cæsar

91 landed here, and Kent has been the seat of many sanguinary conflicts. William the Conqueror burnt Romney and Dover, but confirmed the men of Kent in their privileges. These are chiefly comprised in gavelkind (from the Saxon Gafel, signifying a rent or acknowledgment in money or in kind, and Gafelkind lands, those for which a rent was paid, or, in other words, lands held by socage tenure, in contradistinction to those which were held by military service), or the suc cession of all the sons, or brothers, and nephews to landed property, and the right of non-forfeiture of lands, except for treason. The year 1170 is memorable for the return of Thomas a Becket from his long exile, and still more so for his murder at Canterbury ; nor is the year 1172 les3 remarkable for the voluntary penance which Henry II. underwent at his tomb. ln 1381 the insurrection under Wat Tyler commenced at Dart ford, and the insurgents encamped on Blackheath, whence they proceeded to London. In 1450, also, the rebels under Jack Cade encamped upon Blackheath, and ou the same heath, in the February following, a great number of his par tisans craved pardon of the king upon their knees. In 1459 four thousand French troops landed on the coast, and burned the town of Sandwich. The year 1 677 i3 memorable in Kentish annals for the daring attack made by a part of the Dutch fleet on the shipping in the Medway. In Decembsr, 1688, the fugi tive King James II. was seized at Sheer ness and conveyed to Faversham. The Emperor Charles V. landed at Dover from Corunna, May 16, 1520, on a visit to Henry VIII. Charles II. landed at the same place, May 26, 1660, on his return from exile. The manufacturing industries of Kent include the making of bricks, tiles, pottery, cement, and lime, in which several thousand people are engaged, paper, gunpowder (Dartford, Erith, Tunbridge, and Faversham), sugar-moulds, tobacco-pipes, hop-bags, sacks, copperas, sugar refining, tar, whiting, and Tunbridge ware. There are also considerable ship-building and marine-engine yards, iron foundries, breweries, maltings, and tanneries. The chief seats of manufacture are Greenwich, Deptsord, Dartford, Maidstone, North fleet, and Faversham. The Cinque Ports figure conspicuously in English history. In the time of the Emperor Diocletian, the Romans placed that part of the British coast nearest the Continent under an officer called the " Count of the Sea Coast," whose duty it was to protect it from invasion. In imitation of this, Edward tbe Confessor constituted the five ports of Dover, Hastings, Hythe, Romney and Sandwich, a body cor porate, under the government of a portreeve or warden, who also hold tho office of Constable of Dover Castle, and they afterwards became designated as " The Cinque Ports ; " to these were added in early times the ancient towns of Winchelsea and Rye, to which all the privileges of the Cinque Ports were given. They had a peculiar jurisdiction, separate from that of the county, and were obliged to furnish ships and forces in war time, but, in return, were exempted from pecuniary subsidies, and had other im munities, one of which was that they could not be sued in any but their own towns ; the warden was also permitted to rank as an admiral. William the Conqueror, however, first gave the Cinque Ports an independent jurisdic tion ; by him they were created into a palatinate, with a lord warden, who was invested with civil and military authority, the chief seat of his adminis tration being Dover Castle. Each of the five ports had its own corporation of twelve jurats, from whom the mayor and bailiff were chosen. Formerly there were several courts exercising a general jurisdiction over the ports, and their members, extending from Birchington, near Margate, to Seaford, in Sussex, that of Shepway being the supreme court. The lord warden was the president, tho other members being tbe several mayors and bailiffs, and a certain number of jurats from each town. The Court of Brotherhood and the Court of Guestling were in some respects to be compared with the Imperial Parliament, and it is believed that they were the models on which the latter was originally estab lished. The Court of Lodemanage licensed and regulated the pilots. These courts are now only mere forms. In tho 6th year of his reign, Edward I. gave the oldest charter now on record ; it is 99 years older than the first charter of the City of London. It states that the

92 alternate Mondays (cattle) — December 4. Sittingbourne : Fridays — third and fifth Tuesday in month (cattle). Tenterden: Fridays- first Monday in May (general), first Friday in September (lambs). Ton bridge: first and third Tuesdays — October 25 (cattle). KNOCKHOLT.—(Station—DUN TON GREEN— 2* miles.)— A village and parish of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Bromley union, county court district, and petty sessional divi sion. This place is celebrated for a clump of remarkable old trees known as the " Knockholt Beeches," which are on a hill 770 feet above the level of the sea, and distinguishable for many miles. H undreds of excursionists visit the neigh bourhood in the course of the summer. Area: 1,700 acres. Population: 676. LADYWELL— (STATION.) - A district of the parish of Lewisham, in the county of Kent. The station is the first beyond Lewisham, on the Addis combe Road Branch Line. Lewisham Cemetery is close to the station and railway. Average Train Service: Tweuty each way on week days ; six each way ou Sundays. The Fares from the London terminii are small. king had seen the charter granted by his predecessors, William I. and Edward the Confessor. In the 18th year of tho reign of the same monarch, each of the ports returned two " barons " or members to Parliament. Charles II. gave the Cinque Ports their last charter in the 20th year of his reign. Until the revolution of 1688 the lord warden exercised the right of nominating one, and sometimes both the members of Parliament for each port ; a special Act abolished this pri vilege in 1689. The Parliamentary Reform Act of 1832 and the Municipal Act of 1835 broke up to a great extent the peculiar political and municipal organization of the Cinque Ports, and their local government has been assimi lated to other towns. By the 1st sec. of 51 Geo. III., cap. 36, the magistrates of the Cinque Ports (who are appointed by the Lord Warden) are empowered to act in such of the liberties of the Cinque Ports as have not separate commissions of the peace. They now exercise their fuuctions in Ringwould, Walmer, and Ramsgate. Area of county, 1,004,984 acres ; number of bouses (1871), in habited, 151,314 ; ditto, uninhabited, 10,850 ; ditto, building, 1,253 ; popula tion (1871), males, 417,506; females, 430,788 ; total, 848,294; average number of persons to an acre, 084 ; ditto acres to a person, 1-18 ; number of parlia mentary electors in 1880 (excluding boroughs) — east division, 13,169 ; mid division, 8,763; west division, 14,873. The principal markets and fairs are as follows : — Ashford : Tuesdays — August 27 (lambs). Canterbury : Wednesdays and Saturdays (lean stock), and great markets, second and fourth Tuesdays. Deal : Tuesdays and Saturdays — April 5, October 11. Dover: Wednesdays and Saturdays. Faversham: Wednesdays and Saturdays — (great markets) first and third Tuesdays (stock) ; October 11, 12 and 13. Folkestone : Thursdays. Gravesend : Wednesdays and Saturdays, and first and third Thursdays (stock)— May 4, October 24. Hythe : Thursdays and Saturdays. Maidstone : Thursdays, and a great market (for stock) the second Tuesday in each month — February 13, May 12, June 20, October 17 (general fair and for hops). Margate: Wednes days and Saturdays. Rochester : Tuesdays (corn). Sandwich : Wednesdays (corn), LEE— (STATION.)— A parish aud suburb of the metropolis, in the county of Kent (western division) ; it is iu Lewisham union and Greenwich county court and police court districts. The jurisdiction of the Central Criminal Court and the Metropolitan Police in clude Lee. There are five churches (all built since 1840) and several Noncon formist chapels. The district is much favoured for residential purposes. The railway crosses a very pretty park called " the Cedars ; " it surrounds a plain stone mansion and encloses an orna mental lake. The Merchant Taylors' Company have almshouses here. Tho public hall adjoins tho station. Area: 1,234 acre3. Population : 10,493. Tho Train Service is very frequent, and the fares from the London termiuii small. LEEDS CASTLE.— (Stations— MAIDSTONE or HEADCORN — 6 miles.) — The village of Leed3 is in tho mid division of the county of Kent, Hollingbourne uuion and Maidstone county court district and Lathe of Aylesford petty sessional division. It is renowned for its magnificent castle,

93 presents very attractive features to the notice of the tourist. Among the curio sities which are displayed in great abun dance in the principal apartments, the visitor should not forget to remark the chest and keys that once belonged to the unfortunate Anne Boieyn. A remark ably handsome bedstead, a relic of old times, is also shown. The park is very extensive, and is pleasingly diversified with woodland scenery. The view of the castle from the grounds is remarkably fine. Many of the trees are of great size and beauty. About three-quarters of a mile westward, from the castle, and in the parish of Leeds stood Leeds Abbey, founded in the reign of Henry I., for Augustine canons. This monastery was a very extensive building, and the church was of great size and beauty ; but of the former there are only a few remains, and none whatever exist of the abbey church. Area of Leeds parish : 1,643 acres. Popu lation: 711. the seat of the Wykeham-Martins, which is in the parish of Broomfield. This romantic structure is built entirely of stone, principally in the 13th, 14th and 15th centuries, and in different styles of architecture. Leeds Castle was given by William the Conqueror to his brother, Odo, Bishop of Bayeux, on whose dis grace it was granted to De Crevequer, by whose family it was presented to Edward II., who gave it to Bartholomew, Baron of Badilsmer, who treacherously fortified it against the King, and in 1321 refused a night's rest to Isabel the queen. Leeds Castle was visited by Richard II. In the reign of Henry V., Joan of Navarre, the second queen of Henry IV., being accused of joining a conspiracy against the life of her step-son, was sent a prisoner to this castle. In the reign of Henry VI., Archbishop Chicheley presided here at tbe trial of the Duchess of Gloucester, in 1440. This unfortunate lady was charged with sorcery and witch craft ; she was found guilty and sentenced to three days' penance in London, and committed to perpetual imprisonment in the Isle of Man. In 1359, great improve ments were made by William of Wyke ham ; and in 1822, a part was rebuilt. In 1778, George III. and his queen lodged here, after reviewing the camp at Coxheath. The castle is situated in a beautiful park, surrounded with a large moat of running water, which rises at Lenham and empties itself into the Medway. The site of the castle is rather low in respect to the grounds to the south and east, but to the north-west it commands an extensive panorama. The keep, which has an imposing appearance on approaching the castle from the east, consists of the remains of towers, once of impregnable strength, connected by an armed and covered archway with the rest of the castle, from which it is other wise separated by the water of the moat. In whatever point of view the castle is regarded, the most picturesque combina tions are visible; the great lines are finely broken, the masses boldly pro jected, the colours chastely blended, and in many places beautifully relieved by groups of ash and other trees, which cluster round the older and more de cayed towers ; and the picture is finished by an amphitheatre of umbrageous hills. Tho interior of this stately mansion LEWISHAM.— (STATION.) — A parish and suburb of the metropolis, in the county of Kent (western division) ; in Lewisham union, and Greenwich county court and police court districts. The jurisdictions of the Central Criminal Court aud the Metropolitan Police in clude Lewisham. The station is situated on the slope of an eminence amidst picturesque scenery, beautiful green meadows rising abruptly to the summit of the hill on the left, dotted with hand some residences and gardens, while the common is seen intersected by various cross roads and studded with houses on the low ground or valley to the right. Lewisham is a populous parish, Syden ham being a chapelry in the district. The parish church, dedicated to St. Mary, has a square tower at the western end ; there are also two district churches and several dissenting chapels. Among the charities are the Free Grammar Schools, founded in 1652 by the Rev. Abraham Colfe, with seven exhibitions of £10 each to either of the Universities. Lewisham consists principally of a long street ex tending about two miles on the Tun bridge Road. Rushey Green and Cock shed, on the road to Bromley, Perry Hill and Perry Slough, Catford Bridge, and Southend, a rising neighbourhood, are in the immediate vicinity. Area: 5,72*5 acres. Population: 36,')25. The Train

94 Service is very frequent, and the Fares from the London terminii small. 11,788 acres of land and 1,715 of water. Population: 1,936. LYMINGE — (Station—WESTEN HANGER or HYTHE— 4 miles.)— A village and parish of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Elham union and petty sessional division, and Hythe county court district. The village of Lyminge is situated in a most secluded and picturesque district. It is sheltered by two ranges of high ground in the valley ofthe Lesser Stour, which from its source at the southern extremity of the village winds northward, and joins the Greater Stour near Canterbury. To the south the valley opens to the sea between Hythe and Folkestone. Stone Street, the road of the fourth iter of Antonius from Durovernum (Canterbury) to- Portus Lemanis (Lympne) runs in a straight line for about twelve miles from Canterbury, and then towards the ridge of the elevated ground which faces the sea, divaricates on the right to Lympne, and on the left to Lyminge. From the " Via Limenaea," a word whose root is most probably British, its name is derived, but its connection with the ancient haven failed to give it either the interest or the celebrity which it acquired from its becoming tho resting-place of Queen Æthelburga (or Æadburg), who passed the years of her widowed life (633-647) in the nunnery she founded at Lyminge in the former of these years. Of the occasion of this foundation, Goscelinus (who wrote about 1090) gives this description. " In the church of Lyminge, which belongs to the Arch bishop, the Queen Æthelburga is known tobeburied,but she is there vulgarly called Æadburg." (Tbe dedication of the present church is to St. Mary and St. Æadburg.) " For we know from historians and chronicles that Æthel burga was given in marriage to Edwin, King of Northumberland, and after the death of the King she returned and lived at Lyminge, and took the sacred veil from the blessed Honorius there ; and there (a.d. 647) she died and was buried in the ides of December, and she, as we gather from the opinion of primitive antiquity, through the death of King Edwin and by the favour of her brother Eadbald, first founded and upraised the temple of Lyminge, and hath obtained there the chief name, and that singular LONDON BRIDGE—(STA TION.) — Originally the metropolitan terminus of the South Eastern Railway. (For particulars see page xiii.) LYDD and DUNGENESS (Stations—APPLE DORE or HYTHE— 7 miles.) — A small town and parish of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Romney Marsh union and petty sessional division and New Romney county court district. Lydd, anciently called Holydean, is an appanage of the Cinque Port of New Romney, and the charters of tho ports apply within its boundary. The cor porate body is composed of a bailiff and twelve jurats (or fewer), who are magis trates for the town by virtue of their office. They have power to hold a court of sessions and gaol delivery, but all criminals are tried by the county justices under 5 George IV., chap. 85. The church of All Saints is a fine building, with a chancel, nave, and lofty tower ; it contains several memorial brasses dating from the thirteenth century, and the tower is reputed to have been built by Cardinal Wolsey when vicar of the parish. The town is situated at the heads of a number of nariow tongues of marsh land which go by the names of Rype and Midrips. The well-known promontory of Dungeness is in the parish of Lydd, but. the lighthouse is nearly four miles from the town. It was erected at the sole expense of the late Earl of Leicester, from the designs of the late Mr. Wyatt, and it is now fitted with the electric light. Dungeness is the nearest point on the English coast to France, the distance to Cape Grisnez being veiy little over twenty statute miles ; and it is not unlikely that it will be utilised before long as a new packet station for the Continent. The depth of water on both sides of the point is so great that large vessels occasionally " stand in " to the land sufficiently close for tbe voices of their crews to be distinguished. Not the least advantage involved in the pro bable selection of the " Ness," as the place of departure for " the shortest passage " across the dreaded straits, is the shelter it affords on its eastern side from the south-west gales. A branch line is now in course of construction from Appledore to Dungeness. Area :

95 monument which exists in the north east aisle (Porticus) of the church against the south wall covered with an arch.' ' Tho site of this venerable burial-place, and the foundations of the north chancel of Ethelburga's Church are still to be seen, whde the charters of endowment of her foundation present fourteen of the earliest documents of the Anglo- Saxon chartulary. That of Coenulf (in S04) speaks of Lyminge as "the place where rests the body of St. Æadburg." Of the fabric itself it may be observed that a portion of the south wall of the nave is a relic of Ethelburga's founda tion, while tbe walls of the chancel and a part of the south wall of the nave belong to tho rebuilding of the church, which from documentary evidence is known to have been carried on between 9G5 and 1085, in which latter year Lanfranc, who had selected Lyminge as one of his manorial residences, trans lated the body of Æthelburga to his newly founded college of regular Canons of St. Gregory's in Canterbury. The north aisle was added about 1400 to the original structure, the arcade being apparently the work of Cardinal Bourchier, whose arms were anciently in one of the windows bchiud it. The tower is the work of the primacies of Cardinal Morton and Archbishop Warham, whose arms are on either side of the western doorway. The whole of the more ancient portion of the walls is built in irregular herring-bone work, with occasional bonding courses of Roman bricks and flat stones, in rude imitation (apparently) of the earlier church, and without any attempt to free them from the masses of concrete in which they were embedded. Three small windows in the chancel, and one in the nave, the arches of which are turned with Roman brick, together with a recess in the south wall formed of the same material, represent the simple features of the church which succeeded the foundation of the Queen, aud in which there can be little doubt that Lanfranc himself, during his residence at Lyminge, officiated. It was at Lyminge, in the year 1279, that Archbishop Peckham hell his first homage, when Gilbert de Clare, Earl of Gloucester, appeared at his court, and the reconciliation between the Archbishop and that great feudatory was effected, Here, also, the Royal Commission sate on the occasion of the Attainder of Archbishop Arundel which was so soon reversed. Area : 4,620 acres. Population : 1,025. LYMPNE. — (Stations — HYTHE orWESTENHANGER— 2 miles.)— A small village and parish of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Elham union and petty sessional division, and Hythe county court district. Lympne is most remarkable for its fine old church and castle and the ruir s of the Roman fortress of StudfaiL The house to the west of the church, popu larly known as the Castle, is a fine speci men of domestic architecture of the time of Henry V., and was a residential mansion of the Archdeacon of Canter bury. The church contains much Norman architecture, and the facing stones of the Studfall castrum were largely used in the work ; it is dedicated to St. Stephen, and has a chancel, nave, and north aisle, with a square tower and five bells. The building was thoroughly restored in 1878, and will, from its great antiquity and interesting associations, amply repay an inspection. From the top of the castle a splendid view of the coast and Romney Marsh is to be obtained. Leland's description of Lympne clearly substantiates the former importance of the place. The following is that painstaking antiquary's account of it : — " Lymme hille, or Lyme, was sumtyme a famose haven, and good for shyppes that myght cum to the foote of the hille. The place ys yet cawled Shypway (the name of the Cinque Ports Supreme Court — see page 59) and Old Haven. Farther at this day the lord of the Vportes (Cinque Ports) kepeth his principal cowrt a lytle by est fro Lymme hill. Ther remayneth at this day the ruines of a strong fortresse (Studfall) of the Britons hanging on the hil, and commynge down to the very fote. The cumpasse of the fortress seemith to be a x acres, and be likelyhood yt had sum wallo, beside that streeched up to the very top of the hille, wher now is the paroch chirche and the archidiacan's howse of Canterbury. The old walles of the castel made of Briton's brikes, very large, and great flynt set togyther almost indossolubely with morters, macle of small pybble. The walles bo very

96 thikke, and yn the west end of the castel appereth the base of an old towre. About this castel, yn time of mind, were fownd antiquities of many of the Romeynes. Ther, as the cbirch is now, was sumtyme, without payle, an abbay. The graves yet appere yn the chirch, and, of the lodgings of the abbay, be now converted ynto the archidiacon's howse, the which ys made lyke a castelet embatelyd (the present castle). Ther went from Lymme to Canterbury a streate fayr paved, whereof at this day yt is cawled Stony streat. Yt is the straitest that ever I sawe, and towards Canterbury ward, the pavement con- in that time, that— with the exception of a few particulars — it fairly accords with what will meet the visitora' gaze at this day. A winding flight of steps, and a rough trackway a little to the west of the church, load to the foot of the cliff which bounds the village, and thence a footpath by the side of a streamlet con ducts, through a field, to the north side of the remains of the Roman fortress of Studfall. In 1850 the site was excavated by Mr. Charles Roach Smith, F.S.A., and tho course of its walls and tower traced. It was of a hexagonal form, and covered a space of more than ten acres. The few inscriptions which were LYMPNE CASTLE AND CHUECH. tinually appereth a iiii or v myles. Ther cummeth at this day through Lymme castle, a little rylle and other pretty waters resort to the place abowt Lymme hil ; but wher the ryver Lymne showld be, I cannot tel, except yt showldbe that that cometh above Apple dore, iii myles of, and thut ys cours now ys chaunged, and renneth a nerer way ynto the se, by the encresing of Rumeney Marsch, that was sumtyme at se. The old castel of Lyme belonged to Rich. Knight, of Hyne, late decesed." Although three centuries have come and gone since the foregoing description was written, so little has Lympne changed discovered point to the fortress having been garrisoned by that section of the Roman military force which served under the designation of Classiarii Britannici — " British classiarii or marines." A mutilated altar bore an inscription signifying that it had been erected in honour of some deity by " Baufidius Pantera, Prefect of the British Fleet." A variety of coins was also found, but they were of earlier date than the third century. It has thus been impossible to do moro than guess at the period of the erection of tho castrum, which seems to chiefly owe its destruction to several serious landslips.

97 The insignificant hamlet of Court-at- Street, some two miles north-we3t of Lympne, derives its name from the Via Strata (or Stony Street) of the Romans, which led from Canterbury to Studfall Castle. The remote antiquity of this roadway (see Leland's description before mentioned) is vouched for by the fact that it forms the boundary line of several parishes. The small chapel in ruins, below the brow of the hill, was the scene of the religious impostures of the so called " Holy Maid of Kent," in the reign oE Henry VIII., and which arose out of his projected marriage with Anne Boieyn. MAIDSTONE.— (Two Stations— MAIDSTONE TOWN and MAID STONE BARRACKS.)— Maidstone is a parliamentary (returning two members) and municipal borough of Mid Kent; a market and assize town, parish and poor law union in the hundred of Maidstone and lathe of Aylesford, deanery of Sutton, archdeaconry of Maidstone, and diocese of Canterbury. Tho London Chatham and Dover Company's station here is a terminal one. Thetownis43 miles from Londou by the Stroocl and Maidstone branch of the North K ent Railway , with a continuation of that line joining it to the main line Paddock Wood. It has water communication with other places by means of the Medway. The quarter sessions for the western division of the county are held here. Maidstone possesses con siderable antiquity, having been a town prior to the arrival of the Romans, and ranking third in importance amongst the cities of ancient Britain, under the name of Caer Medway. By the Romans it wa3 called Vagniacæ, and afterwards Madus, and was one of their principal stations in this part of the country. Under the Saxons it went by the name of Med wegston, and in the Domesday Book appears as Maddeston, since then cor rupted into its modern name. During the Norman and Plantagenet eras it was one of the possessions of the see of Canterbury, and remained so until the reign of Henry VIII., when rt was trans ferred to the crown by Archbishop Cranmer, and was bestowed by Edward VI. on Sir Thomas Wyatt, who held it ■until his attainder for rebellion, when it again fell to the crown, and was after wards granted to the Romney family. The Archbishops of Canterbury bestowed many favours on the town. Ufford built a palace here in 1318. A college, dedi- cated to all Saints, was erected iu 1260, rebuilt about 1390, and suppressed in 1538. In 1244 a hospital was built for the benefit of pilgrims passing through the town on their way to the shrine of St. Thomas a Becket at Canterbury ; the chapel of this building still exists, having been restored in 1839 and re-constructed as St. Peter's church. There was also a Franciscan monastery, and a house of the fraternity of Corpus Christi, which were suppressed at the dissolution of monas- teries. In Queen Mary's reign Maidstone figures as the place where the insurrection, headed by Sir Thomas Wyatt, of Ailing- ton Castle, lord of the manor, broke out, in opposition to the marriage of tho queen with Philip of Spain, ln the par- liamentary wars, the burgesses espoused the royal cause, and several Kentish gentlemen posted themselves in the town to hold it for the king, making every house a fortress. In 1648 Fairfax at- tacked it with an army of 10,000 men and with great difficulty succeeded in taking it. Maidstone has sent represen- tatives to Parliament since the sixth year of the reign of Edward VI. It was, at an early period, governed by a " portgreve " (an old Saxon word signifying governor) and twelve brethren. It so continued until Edward VI., in the year 1549, gave it a charter of incorporation, aud changed the title of the chief magistrate to that of " mayor " ; the corporation being deno- minated "the mayor, jurats, and common- alty of Maidstone." The charter was forfeited in the reign of Queen Mary, as a penalty for the part the townspeople took in the Wyatt insurrection, but was restored, and a new one was granted by Queen Elizabeth, under the title of " the mayor aud aldermen of Maidstone." This charter was renewed and amended by charters from James I. in 1603, 1619 and 1621, from Charles II. in 1682, and George II. in 1747, which last was that upon which the rights and privileges of the burgesses were based until the Municipal Act of 1835. The borough bas its own court of quarter sessions and police force. The corporation act as_tho urban sanitary authority, and in 1851-2 erected the public baths and wash- houses ; they have also constructed main

98 drainage works, at a cost of £30,000. A new bridge has been erected at a cost of £32,000. The waterworks and gas works are in the hands of private com panies. A burial board, appointed by the ratepayers, control a cemetery of 25 acres in extent, situate on the Sutton road. The buildings comprise the parish church of All Saints, rebuilt in 1395 by Archbishop Courtenay, and occupying the site of an ancient church dedicated to the Virgin. It still con tains twenty-eight carved oak stalls, made for the members of the arch bishop's college. The church of the Holy Trinity was consecrated in 1838. St. Peter's is the restored chapel of the ancient Pilgrim's hospital. St. Paul's, a fine church, of the fourteenth century style, was opened for worship in 1859 ; St. Philip's in 1858 ; St. Stephen's, in the suburb of Tovil, in 1841 ; St. John's in 1860; St. Faith's in 1872, and St. Michael and All Angels' in 1876. The Wesleyans, Presbyterians, Congrega tionalists, Baptists, Primitive Metho dists, Friends, Roman Catholics, and Unitarians have also places of worship. The town hall was erected in the year 1764 ; it is used for magisterial pur poses, and is also the nomination and chief polling place for West Kent. The markets were opened in 1825, over which the large corn exchange was erected in 1835, and concert hall in 1865 ; the exchange has connected with it a farmers' club, an agricultural as sociation, a malt-duty association, a cattle-show club, and a horticultural society. The national and county build ings in Maidstone are — the barracks, erected in 1797 ; the county gaol, a large building, covering thirteen acres of land, erected in 1811-18, at a cost of £200,000 ; the county lunatic asylum, which cost £50,000, opened in 1833, since greatly enlarged ; aud two county hospitals. The grammar school, under the superintendence of the corporation, was established by that body in 1547, who purchased of the Crown the build ings of the fraternity of Corpus Christi, at the suppression of monasteries, and converted them into a school for the education of the sons of burgesses. Connected with it are two scholarships of £40 per annum, and chambers fol residence, in the University College, Oxford, and four day-boys' scholarships of £10 each. There are also the blue- coat and Sir Charles Booth's schools, besides others connected with the churches and chapels ; a diocesan board of education, a Church of England young men's society, a young men's theological and literary society, a mutual improvement association, St. Paul's literary institute, the religious library, the literary and mechanics' institute, the Chillington house or Charles museum, and the Kent archæological society. The charitable institutions are — five sets of almhouses, the West Kent hospital, the Kent county ophthal- mic hospital, and various provident, friendly, and benevolent societies. The principal trade of Maidstone is in hops, many thousand acres of land about the town and neighbourhood being under cultivation for the growth of that plant, of which vast quantities are sent to tho London market. There are also some extensive paper mills, oil mills, and breweries. Market Days; every Thurs- day and the second Tuesday in each month. Fairs: February 13, May 12, and June 20 (stock) — October 17 (stock, hops, aud pleasure). Municipal Area: 4,008 acres. Parliamentary Area : 4,576 acres. Municipal Population: 26,196. Parliamentary Population : 26,287. Municipal Electors: 4,280. Parliamentary Electors ; 3,878. News papers ; Kent Mail (c), Tuesday, ld ; Saturday, 3d. Kent Messenger (l.), Friday and Saturday, ld. Kent and Sussex Times (i.), Friday and Saturday, ld. Maidstone and Kentish Journal (a), Monday, 3d. ; Thursday and Satur- day, ld. Maidstone and Kent County Standard (c), Friday and Saturday, ld. South Eastern Gazette (l.), Monday, 2jd. ; Saturday, IJd. Principal Hotels : Bell; Mitre; Queen's Head ; and Royal Star. Average Train Service : Nine each way on week days ; five each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 8/ /, 5/6 s, 3/3 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 12/6/ 8/6 s, 5/-/. MARDEN.— (STATION.)— A vil lage and large parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in Maidstone union, county court district and lathe of Scray petty sessional division. The parish church, an ancient building, contains a very curious font, with

99 strangely-carved wood-work, and bears the date of 1652. Four miles to the south of Marden is Bougbton Monchelsea, which derives the latter name from the Monchensies, or Mon- chelseas,who formerly possessed the land here ; but it is more commonly called Boughton Quarry, owing to the large quantity of Kentish rag-stone quarried in the hills to the south ofthe village. On the hill-side stands the church, an interesting old structure ; and almost adjoining the churchyard is the fine estate of Boughton Place, the house of which, situated in a spacious, well- wooded park, commands an extensive view over the Weald of Kent. Boughton Mount is also a handsome building. Liuton Park, the seat of the Cornwallis family, is about three miles and a half to the left of the Marden Station. It is a large white stuccoed mansion, sur- rounded by a well-wooded park, and commanding a most extensive view of the Weald of Kent. The church, dedicated to St. Nicholas, is a pretty structure, with embattled tower, octagonal spire, and contains several old monuments, with two by Baily, to the Cornwallis family. Area : 7,694 acres. Population: 2,333. Average Train Service : Five each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 11/ /, 7/6 s, 3/4| t. Return Tickets (4 days), 16/6/, 11/6" s, 6/6/. MARGATE.— (STATION.)— Amu- nicipal borough, market town, member of the Cinque Port of Dover, parish, and sea-bathing place, situated on the northern coast of Kent and at the mouth of the Thames, three miles from the North Foreland, in the isle and union of Thanet, hundred of Ringslow, lathe of St. Augustine, eastern division of Kent, deanery of Westbere, and arch deaconry and diocese of Canterbury. It is united, by branch lines, with the South Eastern and the London Chatham and Dover railways, aud has water communication, by means of steam vessels on the Thames, with London, Gravesend, Thames Haven, (fee. Margate derives its name from its position, having been formerly called "Mere-gate," theentrance to the sea. In the reign of Elizabeth it was an obscure fishing village, after which it employed about twenty small vessels in the coasting and river trade, chiefly in the conveyance of grain ; and it was not until the last century when the advantages of sea breezes and sea- bathing began to be appreciated, and its level sandy beach, salubrious air, and its proximity to London, pointed it out as a favourable locality for sea-bathing ; when it gradually rose into repute, although until the introduction of steam vessels the voyage thither in the old " hoys " was looked upon by the citizens of London as a formidable and perilous undertaking. Notwithstanding the many rivals which have since sprung up, Margate maintains its reputation. Margate was incor- porated in 1857, and a court of quarter sessions granted October 23rd, 1869. The police force is distinct from the county. The corporation act as the urban sanitary authority. The town is well paved, supplied with water by the Town Councd, and with gas by a joint- stock company. The burial board is distinct from the corporation ; the ceme- tery is on the Minster road. The prin- cipal buildings are — the church of St. John the Baptist, dating from the eleventh century, and containing some ancient sepulchral brasses ; Trinity church erected in 1825, the tower built to serve as a landmark ; St. Paul's built 1873 ; and chapels for the Wes- leyans, Baptists, Calvinists, Christian Brethren, Lady Huntingdon's Connec- tion, and Roman Catholics ; National, British, Catholic, and other schools ; a theatre, assembly room, skating rink, the esplanade, jetty (length 1,240 feet) and other promenades; libraries, bazaars, billiard and reading rooms, baths, and all other accessories of a watering place ; a custom house, preventive station, town hall, police station, county court, pier, 900 feet long, constructed by Rennie in 1810, aud an institute. There are also the royal sea-bathing infirmary, esta- blished in 1792, the deaf and dumb asylum, the philanthropic institution, the Alexandra homes for decayed towns- people, the patriotic home, and Yarkley's almshouses for ten widows. The trade of the town is confined to supplying the wants of the residents and visitors. Market Days : Wednesdays and Satur days. Population : 12,000. Municipal Electors: 2,412. Newspapers: Keble's Margate and Ramsgate Gazette (i.), Saturday, ljd, Thanet Guardian (l.),

100 Saturday, ld. Margate and Ramsgate News (l.), Friday, ld. Principal Hotels : Anchor ; Carlton ; Cliftonville ; Crown and Anchor ; Fountain ; Royal ; Royal York; and White Hart. Average Ordinary Train Service : Five each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 15/- f, 10/6 s, 6/2 t. Re turn Tickets (8 days), 22/6 f, 1 6/- s, 1 0/- /. MARTIN.— (STATION on the Joint Line.) — A hamlet of the parish of East Langdon, in the county of Kent, and a station on the new joint line from Dover to Deal. The city and borough representation ia as follows ; London (city), four mem bers ; Chelsea, Finsbury, Hackney, Marylebone, Tower Hamlets and West minster (city), two members each. The shire has 6 hundreds, 222 civil parishes, besides parts of others, 27 poor-law unions, parishes or districts, of which 5 aro outside the metropolitan area, 26 registry districts, 20 urban sanitary authorities (exclusive of tho Metropolitan Board of Works and metropolitan sanitary and nuisance authorities, of which 29 arc in Middle sex), and 4 rural sanitary authorities. It has also one court of quarter sessions, and is divided into 17 petty sessional divisions and 18 lieutenancy sub divisions, of which the city of London is one distinct from the county. The city of London is a county of itself, governed under the provisions of its numerous charters, and has distinctive courts of justice, and its own magistracy and police force. Westminster is a chartered and prescriptive city, with a limited exorcise of municipal authority. Neither city is amenable to the Municipal Corporations Act, 1835, nor are there any boroughs within the county subject to that statute. The liberty of the Tower Hamlets is a separate juris diction, but the powers of its magis trates have been much abridged. The surface of this county is mostly level, the plain being enclosed with a circle of hills — at Highgate, Hampstead, Hornsey, and Harrow-on-the-Hill — none of which exceeds 400 feet in height, but from which a picturesque view may be obtained of the distant metropolis. The county lies within the basin of the Thames. The sub stratum is made up entirely of blue clay, or, as it is generally called, the London clay. In some parts the plastic clay attains a thickness of 100 feet to 120 feet. The soil is gravel, and although not of itself fertile, is so enriched by a profuse application of manure, that it has become equal in fertility to any part of England, and for pasture land, by the improvements made in the drainage, it far exceeds any other part of the kingdom. At the time of Cæsar's invasion, this part of Britain, together with that now forming the county of Essex, was inhabited by the MAZE HILL.— (STATION.)— The Station for Greenwich Park. (For other particulars see Greenwich). The Train Service is the same as for Green wich. MERSTHAM.-(STATION.)— A village and parish of the county of Surrey (mid division); in Reigate union, county court district and petty sessional divi sion. The village is very picturesquely situated in the Vale of Holmesdale, the church — an interesting building of the fifteenth century — occupying a knoll on the up side of the railway ; it has a number of monuments in memory of the Jolliffe family. Merstham House is the seat of Lord Hylton. Area ; 2,593 acres. Population : 937. Average Train Service: Twelve each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from Isondon: 3/8 /, 2/4 s, 1/6 J /. Return Tickets (4 days), 5/6/, 3/9 s, 2/6 /. MIDDLESEX (County of).— The Metropolitan County of England is bounded on tbe north by Hertford, east by Essex, south-east by Kent, south by Surrey, and west by Buckinghamshire. It is further defined by the Thames on the south, the Lea on the east, and the Colne on the west. It is one of the smallest counties in England, but by far the most important, as it contains the city of London, the great emporium of the world. Length, 26 mile3 ; breadth, 18 miles ; circumference, 104 miles ; square miles,281. In addition to the river3 already mentioned, there are the Grand Junction and other canals. Middlesex is wholly within the Metropolitan Police District, and the jurisdiction of the Cen tral Criminal Court, and constitutes an archdeaconry, in the diocese of London, and province of Canterbury. The county returns two members to parliament.

101 Trinobantes, the first British tribe that submitted to tbe sway of the Romans. On the final reduction of Britain it became a Roman province, and was included in the division called Flavia Cæsariensis. The name is slightly corrupted from the Anglo-Saxon Micldle- Seaxe, signifying the county of the Middle Saxons. Including, as Middlesex does, the Metropolis, it is the seat of manufactures of all description, and the influence of its trade and commerce extends to every part of the civilized world. The Act, 39 (fe 40 Victoria, cap. 67, author ises the issue of an order in council for holding a Winter Assize for the whole area of the counties adjacent to the Metropolis (Kent, Surrey, Sussex, Berks, Herts, and Essex) at the Central Criminal Court. Such an order was first issued in the winter of 1876. The Sittings of the Court are held at the Old Bailey. Each Commission recites as Judges — The Lord Mayor ; the Lord Chancellor, and any person who has been Lord Chancellor or a Judge of the Supreme Court ; the Aldermen ; the Recorder ; the Common Serjeant ; the Judge of the Sheriff's Court for the time being ; and the Judges of the High Court of Justice. The Clerk of the Court is Henry Avory, Esq. The Sessions take place monthly.
