102 A metropolitan suburb and ecclesiastical district (formed from the civil parish of St. Paul; Deptsord), in the county of Kent, in Greenwich county court and police court district. The Royal Naval school, Hatcham, is in the New Cross district, which has stations on the South Eastern, London Brighton and South Coast, and London Chatham and Dover Railways. Here also are the Aske schools in connection with the Haber dashers' Company. The Train Service is very frequent, and the Fares from the London terminii, small. NEW ROMNEY.— (Stations— HAM STREET or HYTHE— 8 miles.) —This place is one of the Cinque Ports, and the chief town in the Romney Marsh " liberty," of the county of Kent (eastern division). It was the " Portus Novus " of the Romans, and is a municipal cor poration not subject to the Municipal Acts. It is in Romney Marsh union, and New Romney county court district aud petty sessional division. The char ters of the borough are similar in their grants to those of the other Cinque Ports. The corporate body consists of a mayor, jurats, and commonalty ; it is very probable that this body will soon have to give place to a Council, under the Act of 1835, the members of the second Royal Commission, issued inMarch, 1880, having so recommended. At the time of the Domesday survey, New Romney was a place of considerable importance, but, the sea having receded from it, it has almost entirely lost the situation and characteristics of a port. It returned two members to Parliament until tha passing of the Reform Act of 1832, when it was disfranchised. Most of the im portant documents and charters relating to the Cinque Ports are kept in the Guildhall at New Romney. The church of St. Nicholas is an ancient, handsome, and spacious structure, with a square tower of great height and beauty ; it has nave, aisles, and chancel, with chancel aisles, and contains a piscina and eight bells ; the tower and nave are Norman , the chancel and aisles Early English ; in 1 875 a stained window was inserted in the chan cel, in memory of the crew and passengers ofthe emigrant ship " Northfleet," which wasrun down off Dungeness onthe22nd of January, 1873. During the year 1879, some of the pews were removed from tha of the Metropolitan Board. The Chief office of the Board is at Spring Gardens, Charing Cross. Chairman — Lieut.-Col. Sir James Macnaghten M'Garel-Hogg, Bart., k.c.b., M.P. ; Clerk of the Board — J. E. Wakefield, Esq. The London School Board District is identical with that of the Metropolitan Board of Works. The Board came into existence under the Elementary Education Act, 1870 : its offices aro situate on the Victoria Embankment. Chairman — E . N. Buxton , Esq., Brick Lane, Spitalfields. Clerk of the Board — G. Hector Croad, Esq., b.a. The Conservancy of the Thames is pro vided for by a mixed board, instituted under the provisions of 20 & 21 Victoria, cap. 147 (1857), amended subsequently by 27 & 28 Victoria, cap. 113 (1864). The jurisdiction of the Board extends from Staines to Yantlet Creek. By 29 (fe 30 Victoria, cap. 89, the Conservancy of the Thames and Isis from Staines to Crick lade was vested in the Board, with the ad dition of five specially elected members for that district (better known as the Up per Navigation). The chief offices of the Board are at 41, Trinity Square, Tower Hill, E.C. Secretary — Captain Edward Burstal, R.N. MINSTER.— (JUNCTION STA TION.) — A village and parish of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Thanet Isle and union, Ramsgate county court district and petty sessional division. St. Mary's church is a very old structure in mixed stydes of archi tecture. Minster Abbey — now a resi dence — is an ancient and handsome building, originally founded by Domnera, daughter of Ercombert, King of Kent, about the year 670. Her daughter, Mildred, so far outshone her mother in piety that she was canonized, and the nunnery afterwards called by her name. Ebbsfleet, adjoining this parish, was the landing-place of Hengist and Horsa, as well as of St. Augustine, the first Romish priest who ever visited Britain. The Isle of Thanet union workhouse is in Minster, which is the junction station for Sandwich and Deal. Area : 5,388 acres. Population : 1,853. Average Train Service : Five each wayon week days; two each way on Sundays. Fares from Lon don : 15/- /, 10/6 s, 6/2 t. Return Tickets (8 days), 22/6/ 16/- s, 10/- /. NEW CROSS.-(STATION.)-

Old Romney is a point two and a half miles westof New Romney , with a small ancient church, dedicated to St. Clement ; it contains some brasses and a Norman font. NORTHFLEET.— (STATION.)— A large village and parish within the parliamentary borough of Gravesend and county of Kent (mid division) ; in North Aylesford union and Gravesend county court district and petty sessional division. After passing through the tunnel between Greenhithe and North fleet,a beautiful view, which is heightened by the picturesque appearance of Hug gins' College, with its quadrangular range of buildings and its elegant spire, presents itself to the traveller. The building, of handsome and substantial proportions, is stated on an eminence near Stone Bridge, and is adapted to the convenience and comfort of respectable decayed tradesmen, who have, in addi tion, a weekly allowance of twenty shdlings each. The college consists of forty residences, and a church with a beautiful and lofty spire. The whole of this extensive edifice was raised by tbe nobie liberality of John Huggins, Esq., of Sittingbourne, and is certainly one of the most pleasing instances recorded in our country of individual benevolence. The village, which lies two miles west of Gravesend, is on a chalk cliff rising to a considerable height above the river. It is a favourite resort of the Londoners, for whose convenience several steam boats leave Rosherville Pier at frequent intervals forthe Tilbury Railway Station. Here are large cement and chemical works giving employment to some hun dreds of bauds. The view of the village from the river is very picturesque, displaying to advantage the celebrated lime-kilns, which invariably attract the eye as the leading feature in the land scape. The church, one of the largest in the county, is an ancient and com manding edifice, partially covered with ivy. The great attraction of visitors is Rosherville Gardens, considered the most beautiful artificially picturesque grounds in the kingdom. The name is derived from the late proprietor, Jeremiah Rosher, Esq. The family of this gentle man founded and endowed a handsome church at Rosherville, in the Transition style of architecture. It is remarkable for the beauty of the stone carving, with which it is highly decorated. There is a richly-stained glass chancel window, and also two other memorial windows at the east end of each aisle. Northfleet has an extensive dockyard for ship building, which affords employment to hundreds of the surrounding population. The north-west marsh was formerly covered by the Thames; but is now pro tected by high flood-gates. There are some good residences in this neighbour hood ; among them are Wombwell Hal), Oldbury Cottage, Brook Vale, New House, .fee. Perry Street is a populous district, about a mile south of the church, chiefly of new houses. Crossing tho cemetery at Northfleet, and proceeding some distance, a turn on the left con ducts to Springhead, a favourite resort of Gravesend visitors, and celebrated for its water-cress plantations, nourished by a stream which meanders along soma quarter of a mile of fruit and flower garden-ground. At this spot visitors congregate in large numbers during tho summer months, not only for the pur chase of water-cresses, but to feast on strawberries and other dainties. From hence, a walk may agreeably be extended to Southfleet, which is only a quarter of a mile distant, and is a part, too, of this same rich cultivated valley, which in ancienttimes slept beneath the waters of the Thames. Halting beneath a huge wal nut tree that overhangs the village school, we read above the antiquated porch the inscription — " This school was founded by the piety of Sir John Sedley, Bart., a.d. 1637 ; augmented by Mrs. Elizabeth Sedley, his daughter, a.d. 1639 ; polished and maintained by Sir Charles Sedley, Bart., his son, whom God long continue. Amen." Scadbery, at present a plain farmhouse, was anciently one of the Sedley family estates and seemingly a favourite one, to judge from tho numerous monuments to be seen within the adjoining church. There are brass effigies to John Sedley and wife, having inscribed thereon this strange injunction : " Dig not w*yn too ffote of this tomb." Next, i3 a gorgeous marble monument with rich canopy overhanging a reclining knightly figure, almost as perfect as when it first left the sculptor's hands, and 9

Return Tickets (4 days), 15/6/ 10/6 s, 5/11/. 1?ENSHURST.— (STATION.)-A village and parish of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Sevenoaks uniou and Tunbridge Wells county court dis trict and petty sessional division. Pens hurst Castle (or Place) is the far-famed seat of the Sidneys, open to the public on Mondays and Saturdays, and other days by special permission. Penshurst was erected in the time of Edward VI., in the possession of Sir Steven de Pens hurste, who was made constable and warden of the Cinque Ports by Henry III. ; afterwards it was conveyed to John de Pulteney, who in the reign of Edward III. was knighted ; from this family it came by marriage to Sir John Devereux. After passing through many bands, it was, in the fourth year of Ed ward VI., by the attainder of Sir Ralph Vane, forfeited to the crown, by whom it was given, "with themanours, lands, and appurtenaynces thereunto belonginge, vnto his trvstye and wel-beloved Bervant Syr William Sydney, Knight Banneret," one of the heroic warriors at Flodden Field. The mansion, which stands near the south-west corner of a noble park of considerable extent and much diversified surface, is a large castellated structure, formed into quadrangles, and exhibiting the various styles of two or three succes sive centuries. The principal front ex tends upwards of 300 feet in length. The mansion encloses a spacious quadran gle. An inner portal opens into a cor ridor, where there are th ree arched door ways, leading to the buttery, kitchen, &c. This is divided from the hall by a screen, over which is a gallery for the minstrels ; and from this gallery there were communications with the principal apartments on the north side of the man sion. The fine old baronial hall is 54 feet long by 38 wide. At the upper end of the hall is the dais, or raised plat form. There are three antique tables ■still showing strong traces of its former colouring. Notfar distant may be seen several pieces of court armour, consisting chiefly of a helmet or two, a goodly sword, and a pair of heavy spurs, no doubt worn by the same knight when he was called upon to play his part in some court ceremonial. Near to them is an ornamented canopy. The chancel win dow is of painted glass ; and in this part ofthe church is a triple graduated stone Sedilia, decorated with pinnacles. Close beside is the piscina, and more towards the nave are some carved wooden stalls of an ancient date. But the most re markable architectural object in South fleet Church is the font of Kentish rag stone, carved round its eight sides with scriptural devices of a hieroglyphical character difficult to explain. Area : 3,922 acres of land, and 404 of water. Population : 6,515. Principal Hotel : Rosherville. Average Train Service : Twelve each way on week days; eight each way on Sundays. Fares from. PLUCKLEY. — (STATION.)— A village and parish of the county of Kent {eastern division) ; in West Ashford union and Ashford county court district and petty sessional division. The ancient parish of Pevington is now merged in that of Pluckley. [There are several in teresting and extensive estates within a moderate distance of Pluckley. Goding ton, the noble( residence of the Toke family, who boast of a lineal descent from the Sire de Touque, who came over with the Conqueror and fought at Hastings, is a building partly ancient and partly modernized ; it stands in a tine park of about 600 acres, planted by a celebrated landscape gardener of the last century. The church, also, is a handsome Norman structure, with a lofty steeple at its west end ; and in the in terior are some fine old monuments of refectory. The latter has been converted into a barn, while other portions of the ancient site are occupied by a farmhouse and stables. The whole of this estate was given up at the Reformation and sold. The church is a handsome and ancient building, with a tower and small beacon turret. At the distance of about two miles hence is another noble seat, Eastwell Park, now the property and residence of their Royal Highnesses the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh. The park comprises about 2,000 acres of some of the finest land in Kent, having a very varied surface of hill and dale, and com manding in its more elevated parts a prospect, both north and south, many miles in extent, from Sheerness on one side, to the Channel and France on the other ; it is tastefully laid out, and con tains some noble forest trees ; besides which it is abundantly stocked with deer. The mansion is said to occupy the site where formerly stood the humble cottage erected by Richard Plantagenet, the natural son of Richard III. It stands at the north-east corner of the park, a modern structure, built by Bonomi, on a magnificent scale, with an imposing frontage, and containing a suite of splen did state apartments, with accommoda tion for a large number of guests, be sides exteusive offices, stabliug, (fee, and tastefully-arranged gardens. The village of Eastwell derives its name from the springs or wells with which it is watered, bearing the addition of East to distin guish it, from the adjoining parish of Westwell. Eastwell church, besides several monuments of the Finches, former owners of the estate, contains in its chancel a curious old tomb of Richard Plantagenet. The circumstances attending the residence of this personage at Eastwell are curious. In the year 1543 or 1544 Sir Thomas Moyle, who was erecting a mansion at Eastwell, having noticed that his principal brick layer did not associate with the others, but retired when work was finished, to read, he came upon him suddenly one day, and snatching the book out of his hand, found it was a Latin work. Upon questioning him, be reluctantly acknow ledged that he was a son of King Richard III., after whose defeat at Bosworth, he, being then sixteen years of age, escaped to London, and by way of efieetual con- the Tokes. East Sutton, once a part of the possessions of Odo, the Conqueror's half-brother, after passing successively into the hands of Aylnier, Earl of Pem- broke, Lord Grey de Ruthyn, and others, came at last, in 1010, by purchase, to Sir Edward Filmer, to whose descend- ants it still belongs. The present house is mostly modern, and stands in a park tastefully laid out and thickly clothed with forest trees, chiefly oaks and ashes ; and fronting the mansion is a fine piece of water. The church stands near the summit of a h. 11 overlooking the park. Ulcombe, the ancieut seat of the St. Ledgers. Boughton Malherbe, the pro- perty of the Wottons from the time of Richard II., and the birth-place of the accomplished Sir Henry Wotton, who had the confidence successively of Queen Elizabeth and James I. Thomas, Lord Wotton, lived here in the reign of King Charles I., and the Earl of Chesterfield was the last nobleman who maintained the hospitality and splendour which had distinguished the owners of this castel- lated mansion. Leeds Castle (which ■see) may be reached from here or from Headcorn. Charing is a village about Jive miles and a half north-east of Pluckley station, celebrated as having been once the site of a pidace belonging to the see of C'anteibury ; and near the •ehurch may be seen very extensive re- mains, including a gateway, chapel, and

Sir Thomas, being satis fied of the truth of his statement, would not allow him to continue his labours, but. built a cottage for him, iu which he resided till he died, at an advanced age ; which event occurred, according to the register of Eastwell church, in Decem ber, 1550. A spring of water here still retains the name of Plantagenet's well. As an ecclesiastical structure, Eastwell church, however, is incomparably sur passed by that in the neighbouring parish of Boughton-Aluph, a cross-church of great beauty, and, though much dilapi dated, showing the traces of no little former splendour. To the north of Pluck ley, also, are two other estates of con siderable importance — Hothfield House, long the seat of the Earls of Thanet ; and Surrenden-Dering, the property of the Dering family ; both of them handsome mansions, well situated, so as to com mand extensive views of the adjacent country, and surrounded by wellwooded parks. Hothfield House is comparatively a modern building, having been erected about tbe year 1776. It was in a field on this estate recently enclosed from the common, that Jack Cade, the Kentish rebel, was killed in 1450, by Walter Iden, the High Sheriff of Kent.] Area : 3,094 acres. PLUMSTEAD.— (STATION.)— A township and parish of the county of Kent (western division) ; in Woolwich union, county court, and police court districts. It is included in the jurisdic tions of the Central Criminal Court and the Metropolitan Police. Plumstead Marshes were first enclosed jn the reign of Edward I., by the Monks of Lessness Abbey. Frequent comrninations were issued by the Crown for repairing tlie banks and breaches. Through insufficient attention, however, 2,000 acres were inundated in the time of Henry VIII., and these were not wholly recovered until the reign of James I. Reviews of tbe Artillery take place here, and the Marshes are also utilized for gun practice, ranges, and powder magazines. The town contains some handsome residences, Woolwich having contributed very much to its growth. The church is an old foundation, but many alterations and additions have been made to accommo date the increasing population. This building is on the same range with Shooter's Hill, one mile and a half dis tant. Market gardening is carried on at Plumstead to some extent, and near the Common are brick fields, tile kilns, sand pits, and chalk pits. Area: 3,371 acres of land and 344 of water. Population: 28,259. Average Train Service: Nine teen each way on week days ; thirteen each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 1/9 /, 1/2 s, lOd. /. Return Tickets (4 days), 2/10 /, 21- s, 1/4 /. RAMSGATE- - (STATION.)-A parish, watering-place, seaport, and urban sanitary district of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Thanet union and Ramsgate county court dis trict and petty sessional division. The jurisdiction of the Cinque Ports magis trates extends over the whole of Rams gate. The town derives its name from the British " Rimn's gate " — Rimn being the pre- Roman designation of Thanet — and comprises the two parishes of Rams gate and St. Lawrence. Tho Town Hall wa3 erected in 1839, and the Seamen's Infirmary in 1849. The Ramsgate sands are excellent for bathing, and are the favourite resort, also, of a large portion of the visitors during the summer. The chief glory of Ramsgate, however, is its harbour, of which, iu 1807, Mr. Rennie was appointed engineer, having two piers, that on the east side 2,000 feet, and the western 1,550 feet long, leaving an opening 200 feet wide, forming splendid promenades, and enclosing a water area of 48 acres, divided into an inner and outer harbour, the former enclosed by floodgates and provided with a commodious graving-dock, the latter drying nearly to its entrance at low water. At the end of the western pier is a lighthouse, where, during night, a light is exhibited when the tide permits
"RAMSGATE HARBOUR AND PIER

110 It is in the Gothic style, with a steeple 137 feet high. The length of the church is 148 feet, and the width about 68 feet ; it cost £28,000, and is nearly filled with stained glass. St. Lawrence's Church ia a handsome structure iu the early Nor- man style. A district church or ehapel- of-ease to St. Lawrence, erected 18_4, ou the East Cliff, is dedicated to the Holy Trinity. Christ Church stands in a pleasant situation at the head of the vale, near the West Cliff, and was consecrated in 1847. It is a handsome erection in the EarlyEnglish style, built of ragstone, with stone quoins and buttresses, and consists of a nave, chancel, side-aisles, with porches on the north and south sides, and a tower surmounted by a lofty- spire. All Souls' Church Ls in Broad Street. St. Augustine's Catholic Church is situated on the West Cliff near tho Royal Terrace. It consists of a nave, central tower, a deep chancel, enclosed with richly-carved oak screens, a lady chapel, St. Ethelbert's aisle and a south transept, part of which is enclosed and forms the founder's chapel, with an altar dedicated to St. Lawrence, the patron of the old parish. All the windows are filled with stained glass. The interior length of the church is 90 feet, and the extreme width of transept 60 feet. The walls are built of flint, and the dressings, as well as the internal walls, of Whitby stone. The style is Early Decorated. There are cloisters and a school attached to the church. The whole was erected from the designs and at the cost of the late A. Welby Pugin, the founder of the church, who resided in Ramsgate on the West Cliff in the rear of the promenade. Facing the church is the monastery of St. Benedict, which provides accommo- dation for 12 monks of that order. The Sailors' Home and Mission Church were built in 1877, and opened in June, 1878. Iu tbe yard at St. Augustine's stands a chantry chapel erected for the family of the late Mr. Digby. It is of tbe de corated period in style, and displays some Devonshire marble in the shape of small columns. The Nonconformists have several chapels here. There is also a Jews' Synagogue. The streets of Rams gate (Harbour Street, High Street, and Queen Street, being the chief), are well paved and brilliantly lighted with gas. The Improvement Commissioners own the entrance of vessels. The piers are built of granite and Purbeck stone, rising lu! feet above high water mark, and are 26 feet broad at top, furnishing, as we Have said, beautiful promenade walks for the inhabitants and visitors. The har- bour-master has a handsome residence close to the gates at the eastern entrance; the western pier being approached by the wall dividing the two basins, as well as from the cliS above by a staircase familiarly known as Jacob's Ladder. There is also a corresponding flight of steps on the other side, called Augusta Stairs, leading from the sands to the Mount Albion estate. Near the pier is an obelisk to commemorate the embarka- tion of George IV., from this port to Hanover, in 1821. His Majesty com- manded that henceforth the harbour should be called "the Royal Harbour of Ramsgate," in consequence of which the Custom House was subsequently removed from Sandwich. The port is accessible to vessels not exceeding 400 tons burden within two hours of high water, and, owing to its safety, is used by an immense number cf ships. Besides which it enjoys a small trade with HoUand and tha Baltic, and a considerable coasting trade. The marine population, too, are extensively engaged in fishing and going to the aid of vessels in distress on the Goodwin Sands, directly opposite, at a distance of five or six miles. The Slip- way was erected in 1838-9. The dimen- sions are 480 feet long and 60 feet wide ; and the apparatus is calculated to draw up vessels of from 400 to 500 tons. burden ; 490 sail have been received in this, harbour at one time. A military road for the embarkation and debarka tion of troops was completed mary years back. 1' lootlgates, of a width to admit vessels of any tonnage, surmounted with elegant iron bridges, divide the inner and outer harbour. A substantial jetty of stone, projecting from the basin- wall into the outer basin, occupies the place of the former one of wood. A new engine-house and covered workshops for the men, have replaced the sheds in which they formerly carried on their operations ; aud the lighthouse has been entirely re- erected from its foundation. A lifeboat is kept for use. The pier is, perhaps, the finest marine parade in the kingdom. St. George's Church was built in 1827.

111 both the gas and water works. There are banking establishments, a savings bank, with a literary institute, assembly- rooms, several good libraries, dispensary, town-hall, custoin-house, music-hall, (tc. An excellent promenade on the West Cliff, laid out in an ornamental manner, forms a delightful source of healthy recreation. In 1859, during certain alterations of a sanitary nature, a num- ber of coins were found in the " Roman trenches;" tbey are of the year 48. Tho markets are extremely well supplied with meat, excellent fish, Arc. : and few places on the coast are so cheap as well as healthy and agreeable for a summer's residence. The environs of Ramsgate are charmingly picturesque and diversi- fied. There are several handsome resi- dences. East Cliff Lodge, pleasantly situated about a mile to the north-east of the town, is a large marine villa, belonging to Sir Moses Montesiore. Arklow House, the property of G. S. Measom, Esq., J. P., is noteworthy as the last residence of Mrs. Elizabeth Fry. The caverns at East Cliff deserve par- ticular notice ; they are formed by an ex- cavation at the distance of 30 feet from the cliff, and parallel with it, descending gradually to the level ofthe shore. This subterraneous passage i-eceives its light from arches of such large capacity as to resemble rooms, which are cut at right angles through the chalky cliffs opening to the sea, and these arches being in summer carpeted with turf, and covered with shrubs and flowers, appear very picturesque. The lowest arch termi- nates in a passage leading directly to the beach. Market Days: Wednesdays and Saturdays. Area: 355 acres, of which 95 are water. Population: 14,6-10. READING.— (TERMINAL STA TION.)—The largest and chief town of the county of Berks ; a parliamentary (returning two members) and municipal borough, assize, and market town, and poor-law union of three parishes. The town is situated on the south side of the River Thames, across which there is a bridge, and is intersected by two branches of the Kennet, over which also there are bridges. It is in tbe hundred and deanery of Reading, archdeaconry of Berks, and diocese of Oxford. Reading is a great railway centre, having eonu munication with the metropolis by the Great Western, South Western, and South Eastern Railways, and having lines radiating to Hungerford, Basing- stoke, Farnborough, (fee. It is 39 miles from London by road. Reading derived its name from " Redin," a British word, signifying fern, which grew here very- abundantly. The town was fortified as early as 871, in which year it was taken by the Danes, who held it until 1006, and then destroyed it by fire.- In Domesday Book "Redinge" is stated to have had twenty-eight houses, so that it appears theu scarcely to have recovered from the calamity of 1006. In 1121 a mitred abbey was founded by Henry I., who died and was buried here. The abbey was used as a royTal residence by Henry I. and several of his successors, aud parliaments were held here in 1440 and 1451. In the Parliamentary war Reading was held for the king. Essex besieged the town for a fortnight, and upon King Charles and Prince Rupert coming to its relief, a battle ensued on Caversham Bridge, when tbe Royalists were defeated. The abbey suffered greatly during the siege, and there re- main now only a gateway and the noble ruins of the great hall. Prior to the Reformation there existed a hospital for lepers, founded in 1134 by Abbot Aucherius ; a hospital for twenty-six brethren, and for the entertainment of pilgrims, established by Hugh, the eighth abbot ; a Franciscan monastery, and one of Grey Friars, of which there are no remains, excepting a window aud part of the church of the Grey Friars. Reading was a prescriptive borough, but had a charter of incorporation, granted by Henry III., which was confirmed by successive monarchs, and previously to the Municipal Act was governed by "a mayor, aldermen, and burgesses." The town council act as the urban sanitary authority, and have control of the water works. The borough has a separate

112 directions from the town as a ceDtro, and by the Kennet and Avon Canal. There aro also extensive iron foundries, engino works, agricultural implement manufac tories, biscuit bakeries, flour mills, breweries, potteries, boat building yards, and manufactories of rope, sacks, brushes, bricks, perfumery, seed stores, &c. Market Days ; Mondays (stock) ; Saturdays (corn and stock). Fain: February 2 (cattle), May 1 (cattle and pleasure), July 25 (cattle and cherries), September 21 (cattle and pleasure), first Tuesday and Wednesday in October (hops and cheese). Area: 2,400 acres. Reading Mercury and Berks County Paper (l.), Saturday, 4d. Principal Hotels : George ; Great Western ; and Uppjr Ship. Aver age Train Service: Eight each way on weekdays; two each way on Sundays. RE CULVER.— (Station— GROVE FERRY — 4 miles.) — A parish and village of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Bleau union and Canterbury county court district ard petty sessional divi sion. This place is well known for its church, called the Two Sisters, from two towers at the west end, each surmounted by a spire, and which serve the purposes of a landmark. The towers, all that remain of the ancient church, were pur chased by the corporation of the Trinity House of the parish in 1810, and groins have been laid down for their preserva tion. According to an . ccount written by a Dominican friar of Canterbury, who quitted England at tho time of the Reformation for Louvain, where he died, and bequeathed his collection of MSS. to its University, the designation of the "Two Sisters" arose thus: Frances St. Clair, Lady Abbess of Benedictine Nuns at Faversham, being visited by a violent sickness, vowed that, in the event of recovery, she would visit the shrine of the Blessed Virgin at Bradstow (Broad stairs), and there offer up a costly present in gratitude for the Virgin's intercession in her behalf. In fulfilment whereof, she embarked on board a vessel, accompanied court of quarter sessions and its own police force. The gasworks and ceme tery are in the hands of joint- stock companies. St. Lawrence's Church, built in 1434, stands on the site of a still older church. St. Mary's was rebuilt from the ruins of the abbey in 1551. Trinity Church was erected in 1826 ; St. John's in 1837 ; St. Mary's Episcopal Church, built for a dissenting congrega tion, in 1799, came into the possession of the Church of England in 1836 ; the other churches are— St. Giles, Grey Friars (on the site of the old monastic church), Christ Church, St. Stephen's, and All Saints. There are Baptist, Congregational, Primitive Methodist, Independent, Wesleyan Methodist, and Friends' chapels ; also a handsome Roman Catholic chapel, in the Saxon style, erected on the ruins of the abbey. The county and municipal buildings are the county gaol and house of correction, tho latter on the Pentonville model ; the town hall and police station, the cattle market, <fcc. There are also a theatre and other minor places of amusement, a Freemasons' lodge, and meeting places for societies. The charitable institutions are Kendrick's, Vachel's, Hall's, and other almshouses ; the Royal Berkshire Hospital, established in 1839 ; a dis pensary, a homœopathic dispensary, a philanthropic institution, and various other associations for charitable pur poses. The charities are managed by three separate boards of trustees for the general charities, the church charities, and Kendrick's charities. The edu cational establishments aie the royal grammar school, founded by Henry VII., the blue coat school, the girls' green coat school, a foundation school, national schools, a school of science and art, infant schools, and three board schools, and an athenæum. The town was at one period famous for its cloth manufacture ; but in Camden's time it had declined, the inhabitants having begun to give more attention to " maulting " : " For whereas they had formerly seven score cloathiers, now their number is but very small." At present there is an extensive miscellaneous trade carried on in sup plying the shopkeepers of surrounding towns, by wholesale, with gcods of every description, wbich is much facilitated by the many railways running in all

To perpetuate the memory of this event, and to serve as a guide to mariners, the Abbess, who, with all the passengers, had been saved, caused the church towers to be repaired, and two spiral elevations to be added, which she terns, fibulae, and a variety of trinkets. with some British and Saxon coins, have been discovered. By the fall of the cliff at different times, lumps of metal have been met with, seeming to indicate the destruction of the place by fire. Area : 1 ,653 acres, of which 4U5 are water. Population : 257. RED HILL.-(JUNCTION STA TION.) — A township (forming the eastern ward) of the municipal borough of Reigate (which see). The Brighton main line continues from this station. The Philanthropic Society's farm school for the reformation of juvenile offenders, is in the vicinity. This institution was founded as far back as 1788, tbe society then haviDg premises in the London directed should be called the Sisters The church was founded in the seventh century, together with a monastery for Black Canons, by one Basse, upon land granted to him by Egbert, king of Kent. King Ethelbert, the Britwald, retired here after his conversion, and is said to be buried in the Abbey. Ethelbert the Second, king of Kent, who died in 760, was interred here. There are considerable remains of the Regulbium— a Roman fort, within the walls of which the royal palace of Ethelbert, and the monastery before mentioned, were erected. Roman coins, tesselated pavements, cellars, cis-

114 to Dover, the South Eastern to Guildford and Reading, and tho main line from London to Brighton and the South Coast ; Earlswood, on the Brighton line, three-quarters of a mile from the junc tion; and Reigate Town, on the Guild ford and Reading line. Reigate is desig nated in Domesday Book as " Church felle," or " the Church in the Field." It is supposed to have been a Saxon town possessing a fortress, but there are few records of its history previous to the Norman era. After the Conquest it fell into the hands of the powerful Earls of Warren and Surrey, who built a castle, called Holm Castle, on a rock overlook ing the town, beneath which is a remark able cavern, where, according to local tradition, the barons met to arrange the terms of Magna Charta. The castle has disappeared, and the space which it occupied is now a public garden vested in the corporation by Earl Somers, whoso residence," The Priory," marks tbe site of an ancient religious establishment. The Priory Park is open to the public ; it is rich in sylvan scenery, and is much frequented. Lord Howard of Efimgham, the commander of Queen Elizabeth's navy against the Spanish Armada, and Archbishop Usher, aro buried in the chancel of the parish church ; their rest ing places are not indicated by even simple inscriptions on the pavement. In a room above the vestry, built in 1503, is an unique library, formed in 1701 by the Rev. Andrew Cranstoun, vicar. It contains over 1,700 volumes, including some very choice manuscripts. Many of the books were given by the celebrated John Evelyn, of Wotton. Among other relics is shown Lord Howard's prayer-book. The borough returned two members to Parliament until the Reform Act of 1832, when its representation was reduced to one; it was disfranchised in 1867 owing to the prevalence of corrupt practices. Reigate was incorporated on September llth, 1863, and the council adopted the Public Health Act in 1805. Main drainage works have been provided, and the corporation own a sewage farm of 200 acres. The borough is supplied with gas by two companies, and with water by two companies. The cemetery adjoins the churchyard and is controlled by a burial board. The borough has a Road, St. George's Fields, fro n which they removed in 1S49. Ciiminal boys are here employed, reclaimed, and sent abroad. Red Hill has two district churches, a market ball (market held alternate Wednesdays), and several chapels. The Earlswood estate, for merly the property of Mr. Justice Talfourd, now belongs to the Asylum for Idiots, founded ;n 1847. This noble building was erected at a cost of £30,000, and the institution has now sprung, by the favour of the benevolent British public, into one of our greatest national asylums. It had its origin iu the suggestion of that true philanthro pist, the late Dr. Andrew Reed, the founder of no fewer than six charitable institutions, of all of which he has been the gratuitous honorary secretary. Dr. Reed travelled abroad with this object in view ; and after seeing the state of cretinism in France, Germany, and Switzerland, he went to Sweden and Denmark, and at length set on foot the first asylum in England for this afflicted portion of the human family. The ■design of this asylum is not merely to take care of the idiot, but, by the skilful and earnest application of the best means, to prepare him, as far as possible, for the duties and enjoyments of life. Her Majesty has contributed largely to the funds, and the late Prince Consort laid the foundation and opened this building. The erection forms one of the most attractive objects upon this line. At Red Hill, in the time of Charles I., a considerable number of the Royalists were dislodged by the Parlia mentary forces under Sir William Waller. Principal Hotel : Railway. 116 Leicester, who, however, burnt the priory bridge and a great part of the city. The castle was repaired by Edward IV., but soon after fell to decay. In 676 the city was destroyed by Ethelred, the Mercian, and in 830 by the Danes, who besieged it in 885, but were compelled to raise the siego by Alfred. In 986 it was besieged by Ethelred ; in 998 sacked by the Danes. In 930 Athelstan established three mints in the city, and Canute landed here ; the city suffered severely from five fires in the twelfth century. Wat Tyder attacked the castle ; in 1251 a grand tournament between English and foreign knights was held here ; and in 1688 James IL, on his abdication, em barked for the continent from Rochester. The city has returned two members to Parliament from an early period. The see was founded and a church built by Ethelbert, after his conversion by Augus tine, who also founded a monastery, both which buildings wer3 partially destroyed by the Danes, but were re-established by Bishop Gundulf, who also displaced the secular canons, and established a Benedictine monastery of sixty monks. In 1201 a Scotch baker, going on pil grimage to Jerusalem, being killed on his passage through Kent, was buried in Rochester cathedral, canonized as St. William, and his shrine became a great place of devotion. The cathedral, a fine old edifice, was commenced by Ethelbert, and is a fine specimen of the Anglo- Saxon and Norman style3, but very little of the original building remains. The castle, built in the reigu of the Con queror, is a massive Norman erection, of which the keep still remains — a fine feature in the landscape. It is 70 feet square at the base, and 104 feet high. Portions of the wall of St. Andrew's priory (founded in the year 600), of St. William's gates, and St. Catherine's hospital for leper3, are still standing. The city was incorporated by Henry H., the charter being confirmed by subse quent monarchs, the governing charter to the time of the Municipal Act being that of Charles I., which granted a mayor, recorder, and twelve aldermen. The cor poration is the urban sanitary authority. There are waterworks and gasworks vested in companies. Public recreaticn grounds have been provided by the cor poration, notably those adjoining tho Hastings county court district, and Battle petty sessional division. The place is sometimes called Rotherbridge, owing to its situation on the river Rother. Here was formerly an Abbey of Cister cians, founded in 1176 by Alured St. Martin ; the crypt, three arches of the chapel, au arched entrance at the west end, and the east gable are the only rem ains of tho abbey, now converted into a farmhouse. The Wesleyans and Baptists have chapels here. Market Days: alternate Mondays (horse and cattle). Fair : Annually, on 25th Septem ber. Average Train Service : Four each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 14/- /, 11/- s, express ; 12/3/ 8/9 s, 4/24 /, ordin ary. ROCHESTER - (Station— STROOD — i mile.) — An episcopal city aud parliamentary (returning two mem bers) and muncipal borough of Mid Kent, a river port, and market town ; in the UDion of Medway, lathe of Aylesford, and deanery, archdeaconry, and diocese of Rochester. It has communication, by means of the river Medway and tho Thames and Medway Canal, with London, Gravesend, Maidstone, &c. Roch ester is a city of great antiquity ; the ancient Britons called it "Dur-brif " ; the Romans, whose Watling Street crossed the water here, " Durobrivæ " ; the Saxons '' Hrofecastre " — Horf's castle, of which appellation Rochester is a corruption. At a very early period it was a consider able military station, as Bede terms it "the castle of the Kentish men," and a fortress appears to have been erected here, possibly to guard the passage over the river. Tbe manor was given by the Conqueror to his brother Odo, bishop of Bayeaux, who built the present castle, of which he was dispossessed by Rufus for revolting against his authority. In the reign of Henry I. the archbishops of Canterbury were its constables, but held that office only until the reign of Stephen. During the struggle between John and his barons, the castle was held by William de Albini, against the King, but was taken by the Royalists, and afterwards retaken by the Dauphin of France. In the contest between Henry III. and Simon de Montfort, it was garrisoned by the king, and unsuccessfully besieged by
117 -ROCHESTER CASTI.E (FROM THE RIVER),

118 castle, and are much frequented by tho citizens. There are separate burial boards for tbe several parishes within the city, new grounds having been provided for interments ; and there is a cemetery on the Maidstone road. Besides the cathe dral and castle, are the parish church of St. Nicholas, rebuilt in 1624, and re cently renovated at a considerable ex pense ; the church of St. Margaret, founded by Bishop Gundulf, and rebuilt in 1829 ; St. Peter's district church, built in 1859 ; and chapels belonging to the Independents, Bible Christians, Presby terians, Wesleyans, Primitive Methodists, Irvingites, Roman Catholics, and Swe denborgians. Other public buildings are — the town hall, police station, custom house, corn exchange, market bouse, military hospital, and Fort Clarence military prison, and a fine bridge which spans the Medway, built in 1857 in place of an older bridge erected in the reign of King John. The town quay and landing place was completed by the corporation, at great cost. The markets for cattle have been altered and greatly improved, and extensive dredging opera tions are continually being carried on in the river, under the directions of the corporation. The cathedral grammar school, founded by Henry VIII., in 1 542, and Williamson's free mathematical school for the sons of freemen, are the chief schools; besides which may be mentioned Hayward's schools, the na tional schools, (fee. Tbe charities com prise Watt's hospital, Sir John Hay ward's house of industry, St. Bartholo mew's hospital, erected from tlie funds of St. Bartholomew's charity, St. Thomas' Hospital, St. Catherine's hos pital, and other charities, the whole of which are dispensed by a body of seven teen trustees. The chief importance of Rochester depends upon its military and naval establishments. It has also a shipping trade, some fisheries, especially of oysters, and a large agricultural im plement manufactory. Market Days: Tuesdays (corn) ; great market, fourth Tuesday in each month. Fairs : May 18 and 30, and December 11 (pleasure). Area of city .- 2,900 acres. Population : 18,352. Municipal Electors : 2,036. Parliamentary Electors: 3,026. News paper.- Rochester and Chatham Jour nal (l.o.), Friday, 1 d. Principal Hotels : Bull and Royal Victoria, and Royal Crown. RYE.— (STATION.)— A parliamen tary (returning one member) and muni cipal borough of East Sussex ; a seaport, market town, and one of the Cinque Ports, the head of a poor-law union, in the Goldspur hundred, rape and deanery of Hastings, archdeaconry of Lewes, and diocese of Chichester. It is built on a hill on the edge of an extensive marsh, on the west bank of the river Rother, which here falls into the English Channel. Rye wan a Norman port, and in the time of Edward III. furnished nine ships for the siege of Calais. It was not one of the Cinque Ports of Edward the Confessor's time, when the five ports were enfranchised, but was added along with Winchelsea a little before Henry III.'s reign. The town was for tified in the twelfth century by William d'Ypres, and part of a tower still re mains. It has lost its former import ance, owing to the recession of the sea. This borough enjoys various immuni ties and privileges in common with the Cinque Ports, and has been a corporate town from an early period. As one of the Cinque Ports, it wa3 governed by twelve jurats, two bailiffs, aud a mayor, under the supreme governance of tho "gardien" or " warder," whose juris diction formed a sort of palatinate. The town council act as the urban sanitary authority. The town is well paved and lighted, and is supplied with water from public pumps and water works, the property of the corporation. The gasworks belong to a company. The houses are mostly old-fashioned, and built of brick. The church is an interesting edifice of ancient date ; the altar and clock were taken from one of the stranded ships of tbe Spanish Ar mada. There are five chapels for dis senters. Other buildings include the Ypres tower (formerly the borough gaol), town hall, custom house, free grammar school (1702), free school (1644), two almshouses, &c. There are also three bridges, one being an iron swing bridge for the railway. The trade is limited by the difficulty of keep ing the harbour open. Tho exports are wool, corn, timber, bark and hops ; and the imports coal and manufactured goods. Market Day : Wednesday.

PETER'S .—(Station— RAMSGATE-3 miles.)— A parish and village of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Isle of Thanet union and Margate county court district and petty sessional division. The parish is a member of the Cinque Port of Dover, and within the jurisdiction of the Cinque Ports magistrates. The town of Broad stairs is included in its limits. Tbe parish church of St. Peter dates from the 12th century ; its tower forms a conspicuous landmark for mariners ; it shows the effects of an earthquake, which happened about three hundred years ago. There are also chapels for Nonconformists. The sea-side residence ofthe Archbishops of Canterbury — Stone House — is situated in the parish, near the North Foreland, and contiguous thereto are the St. Peter's Orphan and Convalescent Homes, which owe their foundations, principally, to the active exertions of the present prelate and his lamented lady. Area : 299 acres. Popu lation : 1,926. accession to the throne in 488. It is believed to have derived its name from a large wood which formerly covered this part of the coast. There is an interval of nearly four hundred years before we find any reference to the place. In the year 949 the manor was possessed by one Wulfstan, from whom it passed to Leoflaede, who granted it to the Church of Christ in Canterbury. Earl Godwin held it from the archbishop by the tenure of a knight's service, and after the Conquest it was comprised in King William's grants to Hugo de Mont fort, subject, as far as can be ascertained, to the proprietary rights of the see. Whether or not a fortress did stand hero at the close of the Saxon era can only be surmised, but it is thought probable that Hugo erected, or restored, one, and that from that time strenuous efforts were made to shake off the claims of the arch bishops to the estate. Hugo's grandson, Robert, forfeited his inheritance to Henry I. by treasonable acts, and Henry, Lord Raleigh, who appears to have been the holder of the manor in the early part of Henry II. 's reign, was dispossessed of it for cowardly behaviour in the Welsh wars. It was this seizure by the Crown which gave Thomas a Becket a pretext for complaining that the king had vio lated the privileges of his ecclesiastical office by seizing on a fief belonging to it. Thefact that the prelate's four murderers — Reginald Fitzurze, William de Tracy, Hugh de Morvil, and Richard Brito — slept in the castle the night before the tragedy, which gave a notable saint to the Roman calendar, is held by many authorities to be satisfactory proof that the king personally retained it, after the deprivation of Lord Raleigh. In the first year of his reign, King John, actuated by a desire to cultivate friendly relations with the rightful owners, re leased the castle and manor to them ; and here the unfortunate Edward IT. was once entertained by an occupant of the see. In 1377 (temp. Richard II.) Archbishop Courtenay wholly rebuilt the mansion ; his arms (three bezants with a label of three points) are still remaining on the sides of the great gateway im paled with those of the see of Canterbury. He also enclosed a spacious park round the outer walls. The castlo continued to be one of the favourite residences of SALTWOOD C A S T L E.— (Station — HYTHE — 4 mile.) — Salt wood is a village and parish of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Elham union, and Hythe county court district and petty sessional division. Shortly after quitting the main line of the rail way, beyond Westenhanger, and but a very short distance from the junction, observation is certain to be attracted towards a wooded dell of exquisite beauty on the Up side of the line. Luxuriously embosomed in this charming bower are the magnificent ruins of the baronial and archiepiscopal castle of Saltwood. The enchanting location of tbis venerable building is a convincing testimony to the fervency with which our forefathers worshipped the beauties of nature. Escus, or Oise, a son of Hengist the Saxon, and king of Kent, is said to have built a castle on this spot soon after his

121 the archbishops, until Cranmer, to ap pease the discontent of some of the court nobles, surrendered it, with the manor, to Henry VIII. Thomas Cromwell, Earl of E«sex, was the next owner, and on his attainder the Crown again resumed possession. Edward VI. bestowed them on John Dudley, Earl of Warwick, almost as soon as Le came to the throne ; but two years after Dudley exchanged them with the young monarch for other property. The King then gave them to Edward Fynes, Lord Clinton. In the course of her royal progress through Kent, Queen Elizabeth paid a visit to the castle, riding hither from Sandgate on a pillion, behind Sir Walter Raleigh, with whom his gracious mistress danced gateway, now bricked up to form dwell ings for farm labourers, was defended by a portcullis, and is flanked by the two towers which rear their lofty beads high above the luxuriant trees which spring from the verdant banks of the broad and deep moat. The railway embankment is constructed so near the castle as to make the eastern portion of the ravine almost level with the exterior line of stonework. The court-yard is now filled with barns formed out of the ruins, but at its further end are the remains of the entrance hall, which goes through Us the back, and led originally into an inner court, now divided into two apartments. In one of these apartments, which is vaulted and groined, the principal orna- THE GATEWAY OP SALTWOOn CASTLE. a " saraband " — a kind of saltatory exer- cise then in vogue — on the castle green. In 1580 an earthquake destroyed a great portion of the building, and Mr. Robert Broadnax, of Hythe, who purchased the estate of Lord Clinton, disparked it. During tho three hundred years which have since elapsed, Saltwood has known more than a dozen different proprietors ; the ownership descending by sale or testamentary disposition. Mr. William Deedes, of San lling Park, lately one of the members o>" parliament for the east- ern division of the county, is the present possessor. The castle stands on the summit of a gentle elevation, and oc cupies, with its enclosing walls, a nearly elliptical area of four acres. The main ment is the Tudor rose. The round towers contain hexagonal chambers, in habited by farm servants. The walls of the inner court are polygonal, approach ing the form of a circle. The walls of the banqueting room, hall, and other fine rooms still remain, and several spacious vaults, under different parts of the de cayed stronghold, are used for domestic purposes. From the roofs of the towers the seaward view is very extensive, the horizon being bounded by the white cliffs between Cape Grisnez and Boulogne. The outer walls, with their projecting turrets, are in some places from fifteen to twenty feet high, of massive thickness, and richly clothed with creeping ivy. The principal entrance on the north side

122 township and urban sanitary district (partly in Cheriton and partly in Folke stone parishes) of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Elham union and petty sessional division, and Folkestone county court district. The town is at the foot of the hills crowned by Shorn cliffe Camp. At present Sandgate is tho terminus of the branch line from Westen hanger Junction, but the works are in progress for continuing tho railway to tbe Folkestone Harbour Station. The place is more often spoken of as a village than a town, but as it is now governed by a local board, aud invested with the powers of an urban sanitary authority imder the Public Health Act, it is legally entitled to tho principal designation. One hundred years ago it could not boast more than thirty cottages, raised ia 1773 by a shipbuilder named SVilson for the accommodation of his workpeople. If building operations at Folkestone and Sandgate proceed as rapidly as they have done during the last ten years, the last named place must, almost necessarily, become ab-orbod in the ancient borough aud modern port, of which it is, at this moment, a most attractive suburb. The township was created a separate ecclesi astical district iu 1851, when tho present church was built on the site of a chapel that had been erected by the fourth Earl of Darnley. Sandgate is greatly admired for the large nuniberof its charmingvillas. Close to the western end of the " Broad way," or main street, is a substantially built life-boat station. Both the building and the boat were presented to the town, in 1876, by Miss Hannah Rothschild (the Countess of Rosebery), in memory of her father. A drinking fountain and cuttle trough was given by Lieut.-Colonel Wheatley. There is also a large coast guard station and a handsome block of almshouses — built in 1875 — forming part of the numerous charities with which the town is endowed. Sandgate lacks nothing wbich can aid in rendering it a desirable resort ; the local board have carried out a perfect system of main drainage, and there is a good supply of water from the Honywood springs. Sandgate castle is at the extreme eastern end of the town, and was built by Henry VIII. on the same plan as thoso ho established at Deal, Walmer, and Sandown, for the defence of the coas^. A castle must, — from the high road — discloses a, frag ment of ah elegant arch. Altogether, the ruins afford unimpeachable evidence that Saltwood, in the zenith of its history, ranked as one of the noblest of English ■baronial halls. Tho public are admitted to view the ruins ou week days free of charge ; on Sundays tho interior is closed. Within five minutes' walk of the castle is the pretty village and church of Salt wood. The latter was erected chiefly in the reign of Edward III., and consists of a nave, chancel, north aisle, and square tower with five bells. It contains good Specimens of Norman work, and the east window is filled with stained glass, i depicting the four Evangelists. An oaken window-chest, of very curious and elaborate workmanship, is to be seen in the chancel, and there are several brasses, and an interesting oak font. The church is said to have been split from top to bottom by the earthquake of 1580. Visitors will scarcely fail to remark how thoroughly Saltwood represents the poetic ideal of an English country village. Tlie tree-shaded green iu the centre, the open forge on one side, and the rustic well on the other, supply these choice "bits" which delight the heart ofthe painter. The rectory gardens are de servedly admired, for here can be seen in the early summer some of the finest American plants and trees to be -found throughout the country. Immediately above these " American Gardens " is Hayne Wood, a high point overlooking Sandling Park, tho attractive seat of Bir. William Deedes, J.P., principal repre sentative of a family whose history is inseparable from that of Hythe. The mansion is a square brick building of noble proportions, and enclosed amidst beautiful grounds. Also in the imme diate neighbourhood is Brockhull Park, tlie ancient residence of Mr. William Tournay Tournay, J.P., and member of a family identified with the public life of Hythe for centuries. The estate is inherited direct from the Brockhull family, one of whom, Sir Warren de Brockhull, was seated here in the reign of Edward I. The present mansion was built in 1001 by Thomas Tournay. Close to the village (Saltwood) are the remains of the old hall. Area : 2,600 acres. Population : 680. " SANDGATE.-(STATION,)-A

Queen Elizabeth stayed here in 15S8, and explored the neighbouring localities therefrom. In 180G, the fort underwent thorough repair, and considerable addi tions were made to it. It contains several pieces of ordnance of heavy calibre. Principal Hotel : Royal Kent. Average Train Service : Five each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 19/6 /, 14/6 s, express; 17/6/ 12/9 s, 5/9 /, ordinary. Return Tickets (8 days), 32/6 /, 24/3 s, express; 29/-/, 20/- s, 11/6 /, ordinary. SANDWICH.-(STATION.) — A parliamentary and municipal borough of East Kent; a cinque port and market town, in the union and hundred of Eastry, lathe of St. Augustine, deanery cf Sand wich, and archdeaconry aud diocese of Canterbury. The distances by road are — 68 miles from London, 12 from Canter bury, and 4 from Deal ; there is also water communication with London by means of hoys, and with neighbouring coast towns by small trading vessels. Sandwich derives its name from the sar.dy shore on which it is situated. It is a very ancient town, being referred to in one of the cbartularies of Canterbury Cathedral as early as the year 979, and Wilfrid, Archbishop of York, landed here in the year 665. The town and port rose into importance as the ancient town of Richborough decayed, from the re ceding of the sea, and became of so much importance that it was made one of the Cinque Ports by Edward the Confessor. Iu 1217 it was ravaged by the French. From the Conquest to Richard II. it was the royal port for the navy, and in the reign of Edward IV. had ninety ships. It was plundered and burnt several times by the French, ami was fortified aud walled by Edward VI., soon after which a ship sank at the mouth of the harbour, which became choked up with sand, and from that time its importance as a port declined. Sand wich has returned two members to Par liament from a very early period ; Deal and Walmer were included in the borough representation by the Reform Act of 1832. Sandwich was incorporated by Edward III. with a mayor and twelve jurats, who were ex-ojficio magistrates, and who were summoned to attend meet ings by a horn which was blown in the streets. The corporation as constituted under the Municipal Act adopted the Public Health Acts, -ind the borough has its own court of quarter sessions and police court. The gasworks belong to a company. Water is obtained from the Delph stream and private wells. A short distance from Sandwich is Richborough Castle, a massive building with walls twelve feet thick, erected in the reign of Vespasian, which has seen some hard service, and still survives in ruin, after an existence of nearly 2,000 years. Th ere is also a Roman amphitheatre in the neighbourhood. The old walls of the town have been converted into a prome nade, which, with the venerable Fisher's gate, are all that remain of the fortifica tions. The house where Queen Elizabeth resided in 1572, and a curiously carved house of the age of Henry VIII., are also still in existence. The castlo and tho four other gates have long disap peared. St. John's Hospital, dating from the reign of Edward I., St. Thomas's Hospital from the 16th century, and St. Bartholomew's from the 13th, still exist as charitable institutions. Among the other buildings there are — St. Peter's Church, an ancient structure of brick, with a stone tower ; St. Clement's, and St. Mary's. The Wesleyans, Indepen dents, and Baptists have chapels in the town. The Guildhall was built in 1539, the gaol iu 1830. There are also— a free grammar school, with four scholarships ; a national and other schools ; three hos pitals for the poor, a custom house, assembly rooms, (fee. From a very early period, until the choking up of tbe har bour, Sandwich flourished as a port ; it then declined until, by an Act of Parlia ment obtained in 1847, the harbour was improved, and trade consequently re vived. Its exports now are hops, malt, timber, and con. ; there are, besides, some tanneries and breweries, and ship building is carried on to some extent. Market Days: Wednesdays (corn} ; alter nate Mondays (cattle). Fairs : First Mon day in each month and December 4. Mu nicipal Area : 675 acres. Parliamentary Area: 2,81 8 acres, MunicipalPopulation:

124 coast. The county assizes were held here in the reign of Queen Elizabeth. The parish church of St. Nicholas con tains some fine monuments — amongst others to William Lambarde, the Kentish historian, who died in 1601, and Charles, Earl Whitworth. There are also memo rials to Earl Amherst aud Admiral Amherst. Several inscriptions comme morate the Lambarde, Farnaby, Petley, Streatfeild, Curteis, Theobald, and Fer mor families. There is also an inscrip- 3,060. Parliamentary Population: 14,885. Municipal Electors: 480. Parliamentary Electors: 2,041. Principal Hotels : Bell ; Lord Warden. Average Train Service : Six each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 16/-/, 11/3 s, 6/6 /. Return Tickets (8 days), 24/-/, 17/2 s, 10/6/. SEVENOAKS.— (STATION.)-A parish, market town, and urban sanitary district of the county of Kent (western division) ; in the union, county court dis- RONT VIEW OF KNOLE PLACE (NEAR SEVENOAKS) trict, and petty sessional division of the same name. It is six miles north-west tion to Lady Margaret Boswell (temp. Chas. I.), enumerating her charities. St. John's is a district church, and there are several Nonconformist chapels. In 1450 Jack Cade defeated and slew Sir Humphrey Stafford, near Sevenoaks. Sevenoaks Vine cricket ground is to the north of the town, and adjoins Gallows Common, where criminals were executed in Elizabeth's reign. Sevenoaks is, however, chiefly noted for its con tiguity to the noble mansion of the from Tunbridge and eighteen miles west from Maidstone. The district is much favoured — on account of its healthy situation and picturesque scenery — by City merchants and others, and hand some villa residences are springing up in every direction. There aro gasworks and a capital water supply. The town was a busy spot ia olden times, it being in the direct coach road to the south-eastern

125 Sackvilles — Knolo Park— on the south- east side of the town. It encloses an area of more than 1,609 acres, and is nearly six miles in circumference, of un- dul ating surface, m ost j udiciously planted, and abundantly timbered with spreading elms, stately beeches, and venerable oaks, some of which have attained enormous size ; besides which there are many parts of it that command delicious pros- pects of secluded woodland scenery, as well as of the more distant country, in- cluding the greater part of West Kent, with parts of Sussex and Hampshire. The mansion, which was begun by the Bigods, Earls of Norfolk, late in the fourteenth, and completed in the debased Elizabethan style — probably by the first Earl of Dorset — at the beginning of the seventeenth century, forms a spacious quadrangle, with similar ones behind it, covering altogether more than five acres of ground. It is built chiefly in the castellated style, with numerous square towers, and two embattled gateways or tower-portals — one leading to the outer, the other to the inner quadrangle. The first room we shall notice is the Hall, a noble apartment about seventy-five feet in length, including the screen, twenty- seven feet in breadth, and about twenty- six feet eight inches in height. At one end is a fine Grecian relic, in marble, of "Demosthenes in the act of delivering an oration," which was purchased in Italy for seven hundred pounds. There are also several pieces of sculpture of great merit, and some pictures; one representing " Dover Castle and the adjacent country," painted by Wotton, in 1727. The curious irons in the fire- place, on which are the arms and initials of Henry VIII., conjointly with those of Boieyn, were purchased at a sale at Hever Castle. The long oak table was constructed for the ancient game of shovel-board. The Brown or Horn Gallery is eighty-eight feet in length, and is chiefly filled with portraits of the Reformers and illustrious persons of the time of Henry VIII. On the right of this gallery is an appartment containing some excellent paintings and tapestry, and an oak bedstead of great antiquity. On the left of the gallery is the Spangled Bed Room, so called from the bed and furniture being covered with spangles. There is also some tapestry by Reydam, which, with the whole of the furniture in this room, with a few excep- tions, was presented by James I. to Lionel, fifth Earl of Middlesex, from whom it descended to the Sackville family. In the adjoining Dressing Room are several valuable pictures by the Old Masters, and others. The Billiard Room and Leicester Gallery contain some rare paintings by Vandyke, Holbein, Mytens, (fee. The views from the windows are highly pleasing, overlooking the pleasure- grounds. The Venetian Bed Room is so called from having been the sleeping apartment of Nicolo Molino, a Venetian ambassador. The State bed, with its green velvet furniture, was prepared for King James IL, who was expected to honour Knole with a visit, but did not arrive. In this and the ad- joining dressing room are some speci- mens of Domenichino, and others. The Organ Room is a rude-looking apart- ment, the walls being covered with oak, unpanelled. Here will be seen the remains of an organ said to have been the second made in England. It is placed so that the organist could observe the altar and officiating priests, while he himself, unseen from the chapel, per- formed the requisite music. There is an old oak chest here, grotesquely carved, which belonged to the travelling equipage of Lord Buckhurst, at the time when it was the custom to draw travel- ing chariots with teams of oxen. Ad- joining this room is the pew or gallery, looking down into the chapel, which preserves much of its original character, although the ceiling formerly panelled oak, is now a stuccoed imitation of vault- ing. There is a fine crypt beneath the chapel, with a vaulted roof. The chapel, cr Passage Room, is highly interesting. The walls are hung with tapestry, repre- senting, in compartments, the history of Noah, the building of the Ark, (fee. The most curious relics in this room are those upon the ancient chestnut cabinet. This is a group of figures, most elaborately carved, presented by Mary, Queen of Scots, a short time previous to her exe- cution, to the second Earl of Dorset. The subjects are — Christ's entry into Jerusalem, his Bearing the Cross, Taking down from the Cross, the Entombment. In one of the rooms, on the left of the entrance to the chapel, is a curious old

126 chimneypiece, wHieh bears lire cog nizance of Archbishop Bonrchier. In the Ball Room are portraits, chiefly of the family, by Vandyke, Mytens, (fee. The Crimson Drawing Room contains several splendid paintings by Titian, Veronese, Vandyke, Teniers, Sir Joshua Reynolds, Lely, (fee. There is also a remarkably fine marble chimneypiece, and other curious objects. The Cartoon Gallery displays copies, by Daniel Mytens, of six of the cartoons of Raphael, and rare specimens by the Old Masters. The State Canopy, with its appendages, was used by the Duke of Dorset, when ambassador at the court of Louis XVI. The King's Bed Room is so called from having been pre pared for the reception of James I. It is splendidly fitted up. The walls are hung with tapestry, representing the life of Nebuchadnezzar. The State bed alone is said to have cost eight thousand pounds, and the entire fittings of the room upwards of twenty thousand pounds. The bedstead is richly orna mented, and the bed-hangings and fringed borders are of gold and silver tissue. Silver vases, baskets, urns, (fee, lie about in great profusion. The Dining Parlour contains upwards of sixty portraits of men distinguished in literature and science. There are some good specimens of paintings on glass, and a fine collection of busts, at Knole, principally collected in Italy by the last Duke of Dorset, on whose death, in 1829, the property came into the possession of the Countess of Plymouth, who, iu 1839, married Earl Amherst. Kippington Hall is an exceedingly handsome resi dence. Market Days ; Saturdays (corn) ; the fourth Tuesday in each month for cattle. Area: 6,791 acres. Population: 5,949. Newspapers : Sevenoaks Ex press (c), Tuesday, Id. Sevenoaks Free Press (n.), Saturday, ld. Sevenoaks Herald (a), Friday, ld. Principal Hotels: Royal Ciown ; Royal Oak; Rose and Crown; andSennocke. Average Train Service : Ten each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 5/- /, 3/6 s, 1/8 /. Return Tickets (1 days), 7/6 /, 5/6 s, 3/4/. SH ALFORD. — (STATION.)— A village and parish of the county of Surrey (western division) ; in Hambledon union, and Gnildford county court dis- trict and petty sessional division. The village is prettily situated on tiie Wey. The parish church of St. Mary has undergone extensive restoration. Shal- ford House, the ancient family seat of the Austins, was built in the reigns of Queen Elizabeth and James I., by John Austen, Esq., on the site of the ancient manor house ; a carved oak chimney- piece, with the arms and various family impalements, is the only vestige now remaining to attest its antiquity. The building was modernized about 1760 ; it contains a fine collection of paintings by Rubens, Teniers, Anni- bale Carracci, Denner, Zachtleven, Poussin, and Vandermeulen, as well as some of a more modern school, by Fielding, Elmer, Moucheron, Kneller and Dance ; tho grounds adjoining this. house are very extensive. On the banks of the Wey is Catherine Hill, so called from the remains of a chapel on its summit, dedicated to St. Catherine, and founded probably about the time of Henry III. Fair : Annually on October 2nd. Area: 2,590 acres. Population .- 1,484. Average Train Service: Six each way on week days; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 5/ /, 3/0 s, 2/6 t. Return Tickets (4 days), 7/6/, 5/- s. SHORNCLIFFE CAMP. - (STATION.)— This camp is generaUy considered a part of Sandgate (see under that head), and is in the same parishes as that town. Sliornclifl'c — so named, it is said, from the once bare character of the heights — was first utilised as a camp in 1806, when tbe light infantry tactics were introduced into the British army, by Sir John Moore (the hero of Corunna), and the old 95th regiment formed into the rifle brigade. The elevated site of the plateau commands extensive land and sea views, and its dry soil and bracing air has secured it an excellent reputation for salubrity,. and freedom from sickness of the troops stationed there — wliich usually compriso a battalion of the foot guards, three or four regiments of the line, two regi- ments of cavalry, detachments of the royal engineers and military train, as well as half-a-dozen batteries of the royal artillery. The camp consists of ranges of woodeu and iron huts; the

127 soldiers' huts occupy the first two rows of each range, and the officers' huts and tho staff buildings comprise the third and fourth rows. Each range is calcu lated to accommodate a thousand men, aud the permanent barracks provide for the men and horses of two batteries of artillery. A commodious church is situate in the south-west angle, and there are reading rooms, billiard rooms, and fives courts. Near the church is a large iron tank on arches, surmounted by a clock ; it contains the water supply of the camp, obtained from the reser voir of the Folkestone Waterworks Company, at Cherry Gardens. The water is equally distributed throughout the entire range of buildings, supplying the huts from standards, as well as the ablution rooms and wash-houses, which are in every range. On the sea-face of the cliffs — sheltered from the north and north-east winds — is placed the general hospital, built in four terraces, rising one above the other ; lower down, towards Seabrook, is a hospital for women and children. Shorncliffe is the bead-quarters of the major-general in command of the south-eastern district. Average Train Service : Seven each way on week days ; four each way on Sun days. The church is a handsome and spacious structure. Close by are the remains of Sturry Court, formerly a possession of the Strangford family. Area ; 3,089 acres. Popula- tion ; 1,040. SURREY (County oi).— An in- land county, bounded on the north by the river Thames, which separates it from Middlesex and Buckinghamshire, on the east by Kent, south by Sussex, and west by Hampshire. Length, 38 miles ; breadth, 27 miles; circumference, 145 miles ; square miles, 748. The principal rivers are the Mole, Wey, Bourne brook, Wandle, Blackwater, Putney brook, and Hog's Mill or New Mill brook. There are also the Arundel and Wey, and Basingstoke canals, and more than 1 ,800 miles of roads. Portions of the South Western, South Eastern, London and Brighton, and London Chatham and Dover Railways traverse this county, the several branches being very nume rous, particularly near the metropolis. The surface of the county is in general not elevated, but undulating and diver sified, presenting much pleasing scenery. Surrey returns six members to Parlia ment, two for each division, lt is in the South Eastern circuit, the assizes being held at Kingston, alternately with Guildford and Croydon, and it comprises an archdeaconry in the diocese of Win chester, province of Canterbury. The borough representation comprises Lam beth and Southwark (metropolitan boroughs), two members each, and Guild- ford one member. The shire has 14 hundreds, 152 civil parishes, besides parts of others, 16 poor-law unions or districts (inclusive of 3 unions and 2 parishes with- in the metropolitan area), 16 registry dis tricts, 4 municipal boroughs (Godalming, STAPLEHURST— (STATION.) — A village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in Maidstone union and county court district, and Cranbrook petty sessional division. The church and old timber-built houses of Staplehurst are well worth attention from the artist, as well as the antiquary. It is remarkable for the salubrity of the air. The church is built on rising ground. At this point, also, the lover of ancient architecture may, by a walk of about five miles, indulge himself with a view of Cranbrook town and Sissinghurst Castle ; the latter an in teresting ruin of a noble seat that once belonged to the Saxenhursts and Bakers, but of which the great entrance and some out offices are all that now re main, although about a hundred years ago the buildings were entire. The foundations are very extensive, and the representations of it by Halsted, in his " History of Kent," indicate a mansion of great extent. Area : 5,855 acres. Population : 1,749. STROOD.— (STATION)— A town ship and parish in North Aylesford union, forming a considerable part of the city of Rochester (see under that heading), in the county of Kent. This is the South Eastern station for Chatham and Rochester. There are three divi sions of the parish, known as Intra, Media, and Extra ; the two former are within the city boundaries. The river Medway separates the parish from Rochester and Chatham, and the Ro chester Bridge station is within the parish boundary. The mother church of St. Nicholas has been rebuilt ; St. Mary's — in the ecclesiastical district of that name — was built in 1869. Area . 1,484 acres. Population .- 4,348. 129 Guildford, Kingston-on-Thames, and Reigate) ; 13 urban sanitary authorities (exclusive of the metropolitan sanitary authorities within the county, 10 in number), 11 rural sanitary authorities, and 7 turnpike trusts. It also has one court of quarter sessions, and is divided into 12 petty sessional divisions, and 12 lieutenancy sub-divisions. The borough of Guildford has a commission of tho peace and separate court of quarter ses sions; the boroughs of Godalming, Kingston-on-Thaines, and Reigate, have commissions of tho peace only. The boroughs of Godalming, Guildford, and Reigate have their own police, and the borough of Kingston-on-Thames is within the metropolitan police dis trict. Southwark is an ancient borough appanage — for certain purposes only — of the Corporation of London. Surrey is one of the warmest and driest counties in England, and comprises many varie ties of soil. These include the cold clay, in a strip of the Weald, on the south border, 4 miles broad; a band of green sand near the Haslemere, Leith, and Reigate hills ; the chalk of the Central Downs, or Hog's Back ; and the clay loam and sand, near the Thames, with tracts of moor and heath, near Wimble don, Esher, Woking, Chobham. Leith Hill is 993 feet high, and overlooks an immense range of the Weald ; Botley Hill, near Croydon ; is 808 feet high ; Banstead Downs, 576 feet. The word Surrey is from the Saxon "Suth-rise," meaning " South Kingdom." Under the Romans this territory formed part of Britannia Prima. Subsequently it ap pertained to the Saxon kingdoms of Wessex, Mercia, and Kent. At the time of the Norman conquest, William de Warren was created Earl of Surrey, a title which continues in the possession of his descendants, the Dukes of Norfolk, whose heirs apparent are called Earls of Surrey. There are remains of Waveiiey Abbey, and of Guildford and Farnham Castles. Trade, manufactures, dec. : The manufactures are of little importance except in Lambeth, Southwark, and elsewhere near London.
