SUSSEX (County of). — A maritime county, bordering the English Channel from Selsey to Rye on the south, bounded on the north by Surrey and Kent, and on the west by Hamp- shire. Length, 73 miles; breadth, 25 miles; circumference, 185 mile.s; square miles, 1,461. The principal rivers are the Rother, Arun, Ouse, and Adur. There ia also tbe Guildford, Arundel, and Chichester Canal. The London and Brighton, South Eastern, and London and South Western Railways, with their several branches, connect the principal towns of the county, which is famous for its breed of oxen and Southdown sheep. Hops are grown to a consider able extent. Sussex returns four mem bers to Parliament — two for each division, east and west. It is in the South-Eastern circuit, the assizes being held at Lewes, and it constitutes two archdeaconries in the diocese of Chichester, province of Canterbury. The borough represen- tation comprises Brighton, Hastings, and New Shoreham, two members each, and Chichester (city), Horsham, Lewes, Midhurst, and Rye, one member each. Tli9 shire is divided into an eastern aud a western division, and has 6 rapes and 66 hundreds, 325 civil parishes, besides parts of others, 21 poor-law unions, 1 poor-law district (Chichester) under special acts, 1 poor-law parish (Brighton), 20 registry districts, 5 municipal boroughs [Arundel, Brighton, Chichester (city),

Parliamentary Electors in 1880 (excluding boroughs) : East Division, 10,214; West Division, 3 880 ' SYDENHAM, LOWER.-(STA. TION.) — Sy denham is a metropolitan suburb and chapelry of the parish of Lewisham and county of Kent (western division) ; in Lewisham union and Greenwich county court and police dis trict. The chapelry is divided into several ecclesiastical districts, and there are numerous churches and chapels. Sydenham is, however best known by its connection with the world-famed Crystal Palace, which was budt with the materials of the Hyde Park Great Exhibition buildings of 1 851, and opened on the 10th Juno, 1854, by Her Majesty the Queen. The scheme and cost were undertaken by a public company, with a capital of £500,000. The building measures 1,608 feet in length ; the wings an additional length of 674 feet each, with a railway avenue of 720 feet ; the greatest width is 384 feet, and the general width 312 feet ; the height of the great transept from the basement is 197 feet 10 inches; the area of the galleries is 261,568 square feet, and that of the whole building is 603,072 square feet. Tho north wing of tho palace was burnt down on the 30th December, Hastings, and Rye], 21 urban sani tary authorities, 20 rural sanitary authorities, and 23 turnpike trusts. It also has two courts of quarter sessions (one for each division), and is divided into 18 petty sessional divisions, and 18 lieutenancy sub-divisions. The boroughs of Brighton, Chichester (city), Hastings, and Rye have commissions of the peace and separate courts of quarter sessions. All the boroughs above named have their own police, as also has the township of Hove, near Brighton. Pevensey, Seaford, and Winchelsea are municipal incorporations, not subject to the Municipal Corporations Acts. The South Downs, a range of chalk hills covered by fine turf, continuous with the Downs of Hants near Petersfield, traverse the county eastward to Beachy Head (564 feet high), where they termi nate on the English Channel in a lofty cliff. The upper greensand, the gault, and the lower greensand crop out from beneath the chalk on the north of the Downs ; the rest of the county consist ing of the Wealden clay and Hastings sands, with some occasional diluvial deposits ; the London clay appearing in the vicinity of Chichester, extending along the coast line from Selsey to Shoreham. The Romans included this county in Britannia Prima. It was afterwards part of the kingdom of Suth seaxe or the South Saxons (whence its name), founded by Ella in tbe fifth cen tury. The manufacturing interests are varied but not extensive. Gunpowder is made at Battle, and there is some amount of shipping on the coast. Prin cipal Markets, Fairs, <&c. — Arundel; Mondays— May 14 ; August 21 ; Sept ember 25 ; December 17. Brighton : Thursdays— Holy Thursday and Sept- ember 4. Chichester : Wednesdays and Saturdays — great Market, alternate Wed- nesdays. East Grinstead : Thursdays — April 21 ; December 11. Hailsham : Alternate Wednesdays — Aug. 12 (stock). Hastings : Saturdays — Whit Tuesday and July 26. Haywards Heath : Wednesdays. Horsham : Alternate Wednesdays and Saturdays — April 5 ; June 3 ; July 18 ; November 17 and 27. Lewes : Tuesdays —May 0 (cattle) ; July 20 (wool) ; Sept- ember 21 and 28 (stock). Rye : Wednes- days — great Market every fortnight. Steyning : Alternate Mondays— October 1860, when more than £150,000 worth of damage was done, but has been restored. There are two towers, each rising to the height of 284 feet, and sur mounted by a tank holding 357,675 gal lons, or 1,576 tons of water, for sup plying the highest jets of the great fountains. Each tower contains 800 tons of iron ; the weight of the fountain water piping is 4,000 tons, and its length ten miles ; there are in all the fountains 11,788 jets, throwing 120,000 gallons of w-ater in a minute. The Palace has Fine Arts Courts representing the archi tecture, sculpture aud decorative arts of Egypt, Greece, Rome, Byzantium, as well as of the Mediæval, Renaissance, and early as well as late Italian. A great marine aquarium has been erected at the north end. There are, besides, in dustrial courts, picture gallery, fountains, flowers, and tropical plants and trees.

131 The park is laid out in a style of rich natural beauty, contrasting admirably with the mors artificial charms of the terrace gardens : they together occupy about 200 acres. Entertainments are given in the Palace almost daily through out the year, such as operas, grand, popular and classical concerts, magnifi cent displays of fireworks, displays of the terrace and great fountains, flower shows, natural history shows, and grand musical festivals of the highest class. In addi tion there are occasionally public recep tions or ceremonial visits of foreign Sovereigns, and many great class cele brations of national significance. On days when no special attractions are pro vided, the orchestral band of the Com pany usually performs. There are Schools of Art in connection with the Palace, which attract large numbers of students, both male and female. Average Train Service : Eighteen each way on week days ; six each way on Sundays. Fares fi om London : 1 /- /, 9d. s, 8d. i. Return Tickets, 3/6 f, 1/- s, lOd. /. TENTERDEN.— (Stations- APPLEDORE and HEADCORN— 8 miles.) — A municipal borough of Mid Kent ; a market town, parish, and poor law union of eleven parishes, iu the hundred of Tenterden, lathe of Scray, deanery of Charing, archdeaconry of Maidstone, and diocese of Canteibury ; 55 miles from London, 10 from Rye, and 8 from Cranbrook. The sea at one period came up in a channel within three miles of the town, when it was a place of some importance, and was united to the Cinque Poi t of Rye. In the reign of Edward III. several refugee Flemings settled in the town and established the woollen manufacture, but it has long since died out. Tenterden was anciently one of " the seven hundreds " belonging to the crown, and endowed with peculiar privileges. It was incorporated by Henry VI. as the "bailifl'and commonalty of the town and hundred of Tenterden," and re-incorporated by Elizabeth, under the title of " the mayor, jurats, and commonalty," and the corporate body so continued until amended by tho Muni cipal Act. Tlie manorial rights are vested in the corporation. Considerable drainage works, for so small a town, have been executed. The town is also well supplied with water, and lighted by gas ; the latter works being in the hands of a private company. There is a cemetery outside the town, besides the churchyard, and a small burial ground attached to one of the dissenting chapels. The borough has its own police force. St. Mildred's parish church, with a lofty pinnacled tower, dating from the reign of Henry VI., was part of the monastery of St. Augustine. By an ingenious mode of expression " Tenterden steeple" is said to have been the cause of the Goodwin Sands, the funds for maintaining the sea-wall having been diverted for the erection of the steeple. There are the churches of St. Michael and St. John the Baptist ; chapels for the Wesleyans, Baptists, Calvinists, and Unitarians ; a town hall, corn exchange, workhouse for 400 inmates, assembly rooms, and sub scription library. Likewise a national school supported by funds from the grammar school founded by an ancestor of the Hayman family, and augmented in 1521 by Mrs. Marshall ; British and reformatory schools, &c. The trade of the place is of an almost purely local character. Market day : Friday. Fairs : First Monday in May (cattle); first Friday in September (lambs); Area: 8,869 acres. Population : 3,069. Munici pal Electors : 670. Principal Hotel : White Lion. TICEHURST ROAD.-(STA- TION.) — This station is in the parish of Ticehurst and county of Sussex (eastern division) ; the village is more than three miles distant from the station, and gives name to a union ; it is in Tunbridge Wells county court district and Burwash petty sessional division. There are a number of largo mansions and seats in this neighbourhood, which is particularly noted for the splendid asylum for nervous and insane patients of good means aud position — long the property of the Doctors Newington. The church of St. Mary in Ticehurst is very ancient and interesting. Fairs : Annually on May 4 (cattle) and October 7 (plea- sure). Area : 8,202 acres. Population.- 3,000. Principal Hotel: Bell. Aver- age TrainService : Foureachway on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 11/- f, 7/9 s, 3/9 /. Re- turn Tickets (4 days), 17/9/, 12/6 s, 7/6 t. TONB RIDGE.— (JUNCTION STATION.)— An ancient town, urban

132 sanitary distriot, and large parish of the county of Kent (mid division) ; in the union, county court district and petty sessional division of the same name. Tonbridge may be described as consisting of one main street, run ning north and south in the line of the old coach road, nearly three-quarters of a mile long, with several minor streets branching from it, including some pretty terraces, squares, (fee, in the outskirts ; and at the southern end of the town runs the river Medway, divided into five streams, which are crossed by a corre sponding number of bridges. The prin cipal bridge, which spans the southern most of these channels, was built in 1775. The parish church is an elegant stone structure with a square tower, of modern erection, but containing some interesting monuments, especially one sculptured by Roubiliac. The town bas three other churches, of modern erection, and also three or four dissenting chapels ; there is a good national school. The glory of Tonbridge, however, is its Grammar School, which has for many years enjoyed high repute as a classical seminary ; it was founded in 1554 by Sir Andrew Judd, alderman of London, and is under the government of the Skinners' Com pany, who annually come down to examine the scholars. The revenues now exceed £5,000 a year, and the head master receives a large salary, with a handsome residence. All boys resident within ten miles of Tonbridge are ad missible to the foundation ; besides which, there are others who pay a small quarterage. Tonbridge School has also cousiderableuniversity endowments, viz , a fellowship at St. John's, Oxford ; a scholarship of £20 a year at Brasenose, Oxford ; sixteen open exhibitions of £100 per annum ; two exhibitions at Jesus College, Cambridge, of £75 ; and ten minor exhibitions; all of which are fairly distributed according to merit. The buildings are very handsome, and well worthy of so important an institu tion. There are three exhibitions of £100 per annum, each tenable for four years, at either university. Tonbridge possesses no trifling interest for the antiquary in the ruins of its Castle, shown on Wed nesdays, from nine till four o'clock, by visitors presenting their cards at the lodge. This building, which is supposed to have been erected by Richard Earl of Cla.e, in the eleventh century, at one lime enclosed six acres of ground, and was surrounded by three moats ; but little now remains of it except the keep, small portions of the walls, and an inner gateway, said to be tho finest extant specimen of Norman architecture in this country. The fortress, however, is historically extremely interesting, as having been besieged by William Rufus in his contests with his brother of Nor mandy. It was captured by King John in his struggle with the barons ; and in the reign of Henry III., when it was besieged by his son Prince Edward (afterwards Edward I.), the town was burnt by tbe garrison, to check the approach of the Royal forces. It do volved to the Crown in the reign of Edward II. , and subsequently became the property of the Earls of Stafford, afterwards Dukes of Buckingham, until the attainder of the last duke of that family in 1521, when it again reverted to the Crown. Elizabeth gave it to her kinsman, Lord Hunsdon, from whom it passed to the Berkeleys, and from them to the Vanlores, the last of whom died, without male heirs, in the seven teenth century. Tonbridge Priory was founded in the middle of the twelfth century, for black canons, by Clare, the first Earl of Hertford; and was suppressed in 1526, among the smaller monasteries, at the instigation of Cardinal Wolsey, to whom it was granted by Henry VIII., in order to enlarge the endow ment of his college at Oxford. At what time it became disused, cannot be ascer tained ; most probably, however, at the Dissolution. In April, 1840, the last remaining vestiges, consisting of the great hall and the chapel, were pulled down for the South Eastern Railway In the town the visitor will find some quaint-looking old houses, which undoubtedly were of some consequence in former times. The population of the town depend on retail trade for the supply of the district ; though there are many independent families resident here for the purpose of enjoying the great educational advantages furnished by the Grammar School. The neighbourhood abounds with fine seats and pretty villas ; and there are few towns in England the environs of which f urnish such beautiful

133 walks and drives as Tonbridge. Somer hill, once the property and residence of Sir Francis Walsingham, is a mansion pleasantly situated on the brow of a well-wooded eminence, about two miles from Tonbridge. It belongs to Sir Julian Goldsmid, Bt. From a turret in the court, on the north side of the house, are seen the Canterbury Hills, near Dover, at a distance of fifty miles. Four miles from Tonbridge, on the Maidstone road, is Hadlow Castle. An octagonal tower, ninety feet high, affords some magnificent prospects. Between Ship bourn — about five miles from Tonbridge — and Ightham,on the left, is the Moated House, in the occupation of the Selby family since the latter end of the reign of Queen Elizabeth. The house is situated in a dell, and contains a chapel, which is a rich treat for the antiquary. The hall is considered a fine specimen of the architecture of the fourteenth century. At Oldbury Hill, in this parish, are very considerable remains of a Roman entrenchment, the area of which is said to contain 137 acres : it is of an oval form, but is overgrown with wood. Two miles from Ightham is Wrotham, situated at the foot of the well-known chalk hills, from the summit of which some magnificent prospects are pre sented. There are remains here of an archiepiscopal palace, which was one of the residences of the Archbishops of Canterbury until the reign of Edward III. Very little of the palace remains beyond a part of the walls forming the the garden-wall of the " Bull Inn," behind which the ruins are situated. At the bottom of Wrotham Hill is the " Pilgrim's road," anciently frequented by devotees to the shrine of Thomas a Becket, at Canterbury. The only place of interest between Tonbridge and the " Spa of Kent," is Southborough, the ancient possession of the Clare family, but which afterwards belonged to the Audleys and Staffords, from whom, by the attainder of Stafford, Duke of Buckingham, for high treason in 1521, it fell to the Crown, and was aiterwards purchased by Smith of Westenhanger, in whose descendants it remained till the commencement of the present century. Southborough was the resort of the Court during the reign of the Merry Monarch, for the purpose of drinking the waters of the neighbouring spa ; and the property commands most extensive views over this part of Kent. Market days : First and third Tuesdays in each month. Area (Tonbridge parish) : 15,275 acres. Population (Tonbridge town) : 8,206. Newspaper .- Tonbridge Free Press (i.), Saturday, Id. Prin cipal Hotels : Bull ; Rose and Crown. Average Train Service : Twenty-two each way on week days ; six each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 8/9/ 6/8 s, express ; 7/6 /, 5/2 s, 2/6| /, ordinary. Return Tickets (4 days), 13/- /, 10/- s, express ; 11/6/ 8/- s, 5/1 /, ordinary. TUNBRIDGE WELLS.—(STA TION.) — A fashionable watering-place, urban sanitary district, and market town of the county of Kent (western division) ; it is comprised partly in the parishes of Tonbridge and SpeldhurBt, in Kent, and Frant, in Sussex, and is the head of a county court district and petty sessional division in the union of Ton bridge. The local government of the town being under the powers of a local Act, a police force separate from the connty is maintained by the inhabitants. Tunbridge Wells has high repute, a large permanent population, and is now of considerable standing as a fixed place of habitation. The valuable properties of the waters were known as early as the beginning of the seventeenth century, and Queen Henrietta availed herself of these healing springs, as well as the Queen and courtiers of the second Charles ; yet even so recently as only sixty years ago it was the custom, at the termination of each season, to close not only the hotels and boarding-houses, but even the Bhops and houses generally, till the approach of the following sum mer, the town being all but deserted during winter. Now all things have changed : rows of houses, estates of crescents, churches and new roads,occupy spots which were a few years since covered only with the heather. The Wells, indeed, is not a single place, but a district, comprising a series of scattered villages, mansions, and villas, within a circuit of three or four miles in diameter ; and the principal parts are named from the surrounding eminences, as Mount Ephraim, Mount Sion, Mount Pleasant, and the Wells proper : but by far the most beautiful quarter of this enchanting

134 district lies to the north-east of the Wells proper and beyond Mount Sion. It is called, from having been formerly a private estate, Calverley Park ; nor can it be denied that the natural beauties derived from the variety of its surface, and the richness of its verdure and foliage, are much enhanced by the im provements of art, aud the erection of the pretty insulated villas that fringe its borders without destroying its park-like appearance. Few towns in the kingdom have increased with such rapidity. From a mere village, which it was a century back, the population, since it Was created a town, in 1835, and especially since the opening of the railway, ten years later, has progressed most remarkably. But the new buildings, numerous as they have been, have not been equal to the demand. The Local Improvement Acts have bad the effect of not only increasing yearly the list of fashionable visitors, but have now rendered Tunbridge Wells, like Brighton, a permanent place of residence to many persons whose daily occupations are in the metropolis, from the facilities of railway communication. The original village forms what is now called the Wells proper, where are the parade, the pump-room and baths, the leading inns, the libraries, and tbe assembly-rooms, with the principal shops, many of which are on a scale of extent and splendour that may vie with those of Bath or Cheltenham. Few places are better supplied with every kind of provisions. The town has several churches ; four tastefully built in the Gothic style, namely, Trinity Church, on Mount Pleasant, St. John's, St. James's, and Christ Chureh on Mount Sion ; and the church of St. Paul, Rusthall, which was built by subscription, and consecrated in August, 1850. The Roman Catholics have a handsome chapel built of stone, in the Grosvenor road ; and there are seven places of worship for different de nominations of dissenters. All the churches and chapels have their respec tive Sunday schools : besides which, the Victoria national schools, a female British school, and an infant school, furnish ample means of instruction for the poorer classes of the inhabitants. There are also religious and medical charities ; the poor, on the whole, being well cared for. There are literary societies, and a mechanics' institute. Good fishing may be obtained in the immediate neighbourhood of the Wells. The undulating character of the ground lends an additional charm, and the views from the several eminences are most beautiful. The old assembly-room on the Parade was pulled down some years ago, and houses erected on the ground. Butter, eggs, poultry and vegetables are brought into Tunbridge Wells daily from the adjacent villages; also fruit during the season. The old theatre was con verted into the corn exchange about fifteen years ago. A public hall was erected in 1870, at a cost of £13,000 Half a mile up the Frant-road, is a largo estate, called Broadwater Down, com manding a most beautiful and extensive view. The commons of Rusthall and Tunbridge Wells are the property of the town. The town is well suppliod both with water and gas. Few country towns, indeed, have a cleaner, neater, and more orderly appearance than the Wells. As respects trade, it has none beyond that maintained by the wants of the district and neighbourhood. The only branch, too, of native industry which may be termed a manufacture, is the formation of boxes, spoons, domino-boards, and a variety of articles in wood of various colours, formed in mosaic, and familiarly known as Tunbridge-ware. " The Grove" was presented to the town in the year 1703, by John, Earl of Buckingham. Queen Anne subsequently gave the Basin, named the Well of the Queen, or Queen's Well. The same monarch gave the tiles for the pavement of the promenade, hence the word Pantiles. Richard Cum berland, the dramatist, resided at Grove House for nearly th irty years ; and at the end of his career the great states man, Lord North, came here to end his days. The precise period when the medicinal qualities of the mineral springs were discovered cannot be ascertained ; but they were, at any rate, greatly in vogue at tho latter pa rt of tho seventeenth century. These springs, which occur in the beds of iron- sand, first rise uorth-west of the town in the obscuro village of Speldhurst, and thence come down to the Wells, surging up at the lowest part of the narrow valley in which the original village was built. In 1664 Lord Mus kerry surrounded the spring with a stone

135 wall; but this has since been wholly covered in by means of a handsome stone building. The water is a light, pure chalybeate, having a temperature of about 50° Fahr. ; and its principal mineral ingredients are protoxide of iron, chloride of sodium, and sulphate of lime, in combination with carbonic acid gas. After all, however, the mineral constituents of these waters are very insignificant ; for Sir Charles Scudamore, who accurately analysed them, discovered little more than a third of a grain of the protoxide of iron, about a sixth of a grain of common salt, and a little more than a fifth of a grain of sulphate of lime, in a pint of water. However much, therefore, these waters may be valued for their virtues in cases of nervousness and dyspepsia, and however really beneficial they may be in female complaints, it is quite obvious that they have no claim to be compared for their active remedial qualities with those of Bath, Cheltenham, and Clifton. Its reputation stands, however, on quite independent grounds; for the beauty of the scenery in and around the Wells, the remarkable salu brity of the air, aud the agreeable society of the place, will ever continue to give it popularity, and make it not only a favourite summer resort, but an eligible spot for permanent residence. In every direction around the Wells are agreeable walks and rides, furnishing most exten sive views of rural and forest scenery. Perhaps the most favourite ramble for pedestrians is across the Common, on which are some curious rocks, known as the Sweeps' Rocks. At Rusthall Common may be seen another very extraordinary looking object, called the Toad Rock, which somewhat resembles in shape the Logan stones of Cornwall, and the form of which, it is evideut, could only have been produced by natural causes. The High Rocks, likewise, about a mile and a half to the west of the Wells, are ex tremely well worth a visit : they range between forty and seventy feet in height, are composed of sandstone, and have several curious caverns near them, which seem to have been rent asunder by some convulsion of nature. There are also several extremely delightful walks across the fields to Fraut Forest, Hall's Hole, Park Wood, (fee. Eight miles south of the Wells is Mayfield, in Sussex, con- taining the ruins of the Archiepiscopal Palace, which is said to have been built by St. Duustan, but there is probably no portion of the budding older than tho fourteenth century. Three miles from Mayfield is Heathfield, ouce noted for its manufacture of cannon. A battle was fought here in 633 or 635, between Cad- walla, a prince of the royal blood of Wessex, and Edwin, king of Northum- berland. Heathfield Park is built on an elevation of 600 feet above the level of the sea. Lamberhurst, eight miles from the Wells, is an interesting village. The church has a beautiful window in the west end, of the Perpendicular order. The pulpit, with the reading-desk, is of carved oak, and bears the date of 1630. A short distance from Lamberhurst are some vestiges of the once celebrated Gloucester Furnace, formerly the largest iron manufactory in Sussex, where the iron balustrade that encloses St. Paul's church-yard was cast. Two miles and a half east of Tunbridge Wells is Pem- bury, the church of which was built in the reign of Edward III. On a very ancient stone in the pavement of the chancel is an inscription in Norman- French, which appears coeval with the above-mentioned reign. Several memo- rials and monuments of the Amherst family are iu this church ; also a brass, dated 1007, near the altar. Goudhurst, twelve mUes from the Wells, contains a handsome church, enriched with several curious monuments to the Colepeper family of Bedgebury ; one in particular of Bethersden marble, on which are placed the recumbent figures of Sir Alexander Colepeper and his lady, carved in wood, habited in the costume of their times, the reign of Henry VIII. The knight's armour is richly carved. Market days ; Mondays (vege- tables) ; Fridays (corn). Population (town) : 19,410. Neiospapcrs : Tunbridge Wells Journal (l.), Thursday, ld. Tun- bridge Wells Gazette (i.), Friday, 2d. Kent and Sussex Courier (a), Wednesday and Friday, ld. Principal Hotels : Calverley Castle ; Mount Ephraim ; Royal Kentish ; Railway ; Royal Sussex ; and Royal Victoria and Sussex. Average Train Service .- Fifteen each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 10/- /, 7/6 s, express ; 8/6 f, 6/- s, 2/8A /, ordinary. Return Tickets 11

136 (4 days), 15/- /, 11/- s, express ; 13/6/ 9/6 s, 5/5 1, ordinary. WADHURST.— (STATION.) — A village and parish of the county of Sussex (eastern division) ; in Ticehurst union, Tunbridge Wells county court district, and Frant petty sessional division. The parish church is of mixed architecture. There are several stone quarries near the railway station. The scenery around Wadhurst is very charm ing. Area : 10,147 acres. Population : 3,191 . Average Train Service : Six each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 11/3 /, 8/9 s, express ; 10/- /, 7/- s, 3/4 /, ordi nary. Return Tickets (4 days), 17/- /, 13/- s, express; 16/- /, 11/3 s, 6/8 /, ordinary. WALMER.— (STATION on the Joint Line.) — A parish and suburb of the borough of Deal (forming part of the parliamentary borough of Sandwich), and county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Eastry union, Deal county court district, and Walmer petty sessional division. The Strand is the main street of Wal mer. At the end are the barracks. Walmer Castle (the official residence of the Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports) is distant about half a mile from the vil lage, and is situated in a commanding and picturesque position. The building is as much modernized as its companion at Deal, and may be styled another of the ugly blockhouses of Henry VIII. ; it has been adapted to the convenience of a modern dwelling, and derives its chief importance from having been the frequent residence of the late illus trious Duke of Wellington, who died here in 1852. The rooms are mostly small and of no very symmetrical form ; abd they are connected by long, narrow, and circuitous passages. A door opens upon the ramparts from the " Duke's Room," where the old warrior never failed, while at the castle and in health, to take his morning exercise at six o'clock. The moat has been converted into a kitchen garden. At the back may be seen Mr. Pitt's (when Lord Warden) plantation of sycamores ; here, too, are two shoots from Napoleon's weeping willow at St. Helena, planted by the Iron Duke. The view from this point is magnificent, being unbroken both north and south, while directly in front it is only bounded by the French coast. The barracks were erected in 1795, and consist of seven commodious brick buildings, covering an area of twenty-two acres. The first or north barracks are for infantry ; tho centre for cavalry ; and the third or south barracks for infantry. They are capable of accommodating 1,100 infantry and a troop of horse, and are considered very superior ouildings of their kind. The village is a very pleasant one, and the parish church has some points of archi tectural interest. It is believed that Walmer was the spot where Julius Cæsar landed, 55 b.c, and again the following year, from the fact that it corresponds very closely with that warrior's descrip tion of the coast, in his " Gallic War." Area: 1,019 acres. Population (includ ing military) : 3,816. WARLINGHAM. —(STATION.) — A village and parish of the county of Surrey (eastern division) ; in Godstone union and Croydon county court district and petty sessional division. The village is situate in the picturesque district known as the Caterham Valley. The parish church is a small building of plain proportions. Area : 1,702 acres. Population ; 773. Average Train Service : Ten each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 3/2 /, 2/6 s, 1/3 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 5/-/, 4/- s, 2/6 /. WATERINGBURY. — (STA TION.) — A village and parish of the county of Kent (mid division); in Mailing union, and Maidstone county court dis trict and petty sessional division. This place is called in the " Textus Roffensis," Woteringaberia. Large building opera tions were carried on here by the late Mr. Alderman Lucas, who owned Water ingbury Place, a structure of the time of Queen Anne. St. John's Church, standing on high ground contains a monument ot Sir Oliver Style, the original owner of the mansion and grounds. Half a mile distant is Nettlestead, whose church and the remains of the splendid castle of the Weutworths are worthy a visit. The church, dedicated to St. Mary, is remarkable for the richness of its stained glass, and the beauty of its architectural decorations. Area ; 1,460 acres. Popu lation : 1,320. Average Train Service: Six each way on week days ; two each way on Sundavs. Fares from London : 10/- /, 6/8 s, 3"/5 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 15/6 /, 10/0 s, 6/6 t.

137 WATERLOO. — (STATION.) — ThiB metropolitan station is in the parish and borough of Lambeth, and adjoins the terminus of the London and South West ern Railway. It is also the ticket collect - ing station for Charing Cross. There is a local train service every five minutes between Charing Cross, Waterloo, and Cannon street, independently of the services beyond the last-named terminus. WELLINGTON COLLEGE.— (STATION.)— This station is in the parish of Sandhurst (see under that head), and county of Berks, and provides for communication with the Sandhurst Military College as well as the institution after which it is named. The Wellington College is the result of voluntary sub scription from all parts of the world, as a monument to the late Duke of Wellington. The subscriptions and interest on sums invested, together with £25,000 from the Patriotic Fund, and £3,000 from Sir J. Bailey, M.P., amounted to £159,000. In the appli cation of this sum, £105,000 were in vested on mortgage at four per cent., producing £4,200 per annum ; the twelve acres of ground upon which the building stands were presented by Mr. Milner Gibson, M.P. ; the cost of the remaining land, 120 acres (since increased to 300 acres) was £1,200 — therefore, the sum left for the building was £52,800. The foundation stone was laid by tbe Queen in 1856, and it was opened by her in January, 1859. Tho College is designed for the education of 300 boys ; 80 orphan sons of officers of tbe Army or Navy being on the foundation. Tho instruction, besides the classics and the modern languages, includes all scientific knowledge bearing upon the arts, com merce, and the industry of the country. The building is in the south-east angle of Berkshire, at the junction of the county with Hampshire and Surrey. The iand is elevated heath ground, with extensive views towards Bagshot on the one side, and over the Hartford-bridge Flats on the other. Wokingham is seen to the north-west, and, beyond, the castle of Windsor. The view over Hampshire extends to Strathfieldsaye, the seat of the late Duke of Wellington. The building, which is in the Louis Quinze style, is flanked by two lofty towers, <nre to each of the two principal blocks of buildings, having a considerable effect of mass and altitude as seen from the surrounding country. _4«cra</e Train Service : Eight each way on week day's ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London ; 5/6 /, 4/- s, 2/9 t. Return Tickets (8 days), 9/- /, 6/6 s, 5/6 /. WESTCOMBE PARK.—(STA TION.) — This station is between Maze Hill, Greenwich, and Charlton, and pro vides accommodation for a thickly popu lated district. The Train Service is nearly the same as for the places named, and the Fares from the London terminii nominal. WESTENHANGER. — (JUNC TION STATION).— This station is in the parish of Stanford and county of Kent (eastern division), and is the junction for the Hythe and Sandgate Branch line. About 300 yards north of the station, and close to the line, are the remains of Osten hanger, or Westenhanger Castle, a mag nificent mansion erected by Sir Edward Poyning (ante Henry VIII.) The manor of Wcstenhanger originally belonged to the Aubervilles, and thence passed by marriage to Nicholas de Criol, from whom it descended to Sir Edward with other property. Henry VIII. greatly enlarged the park and estate, and Queen Elizabeth stayed here in the course of one of her " Progresses." She granted the castle and manor to Thomas Smythe (ancestor of the late Viscount Strangford), who farmed the customs of the Port of London. Mr. Smythe added greatly to the beauty of the mansion, and improved the grounds. The Finch family, who subsequently became the owners of the estate, pulled down a large part of the castle for the sake of the materials, and afterwards sold it to the Champney family. The plan of the building is still observable. The site was moated all round, and had a draw bridge, large gate-house, and portcullis; the outer walls were very high, and enor mously thick, embattled throughout, fortified by nine strong towers, alternately round and square, and having a gallery communicating from tower to tower. The castle is said to have contained — when Elizabeth visited it — 12ii apart ments and 365 windows. Sir. Edward Poyming preserved, and incorporated in his work, one of the towers, which had. belonged to the old mansion of- the Criols. It is called "Fair Rosamond's," from

138 admitted into it by right of inheritance, taking up their freedom at the age of 21, unless disqualified by previous marriage : the freemen of the company share all its property and privileges; non-working members and widows re ceive one-third of a full member's share ; sick members receive within a fraction full pay. The town has a large trade arising both from its fishery and coal trade. The harbour is the property of the South Eastern Railway Company, and the line communicates with Canter bury. Area : 4,075 acres. Population ; 4,881. Newspaper: Whitstable Times (n .), Saturday, ld. Average Train Service ; Four each way on week days ; none on Sundays. Fares from London: 15/- f, 10/6 s, 5/2 /. Return Tickets (8 days), 22/6 f, 16/- s, 10/- /. WINCHELSEA.— (STATION.)- An ancient town and liberty, and one of the two ancient towns of the Cinque Ports, in the eastern division of the county of Sussex. It comprises the parish of St. Thomas the Apostle, and part of the parishes of Pett, Broomhill, and Icklesham, in the poor-law union of Rye. The parishes of St. Thomas and Icklesham form part of the parliamen tary borough of Rye. Winchelsea is distant 8 miles from Hastings. From being one of the most important of the southern ports, Winchelsea has dwindled down to a small coast town. The in roads of the sea have more than once destroyed its harbour. The first sub mersion of the old town occurred during a dreadful storm in 1250. In 1287 occurred the second and final submersion, which necessitated the removal of the inhabitants to a hill called Iham, in the parish of Icklesham, which was divided for building purposes into 40 squares of 2_ acres each, 39 of which can still bo traced. The court liberty is governed by a mayor and twelve jurats, in a like manner to the other old corporate mem bers of the Cinque Ports. The mayor and jurats are the magistrates, and they hold petty and general sessions of the peace. The selection of the mayor takes place annually on Easter Monday. Winchelsea returned two members to Parliament until the passing of the Reform Act of 1832, when it was dis franchised. The town now consists of one parish, viz., St. Thomas the Apostle. a tradition that this unhappy favourite of King Henry II. lived, or was confined Here before her removal to the labyrinth of Woodstock. The parts of the castle now remaining are the walls, and two towers, on the north and east sides, the cliapel, the principal entrance, and a portion of the garden walls ; but nearly all are in a very ruinous condition, and covered with ivy, or overgrown with trees. Westenhanger Castlo has shared the fate of Saltwood, Lympne, and other baronial halls in Kent and Sussex, and from being the gorgeous palace of monarchs, now serves the humble pur poses of a modern farm dwelling. Average Train Service : Six each way on week days; two each way on Sun days. Fares from London: 18/0 /, 13/0 s, express ; 16/- /, 11/6 s, 5/5 t, ordinary. Return Tickets (8 days), 31/- f, 22/6 s, express; 26/6 /, 18/- s, 10/10 /, ordinarv WESTGATE-ON-SEA. — (Sta tion—MARGATE—1 mile.)— A town ship within the civil parish of St. John's, Margate, in the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in isle of Thanet union, and Margate county court district and petty sessional division. The district church of St. James, situated in the hamlet of Garlinge, is a gothic structure, erected in 1872. The locality has at tained a high repute for healthiness, and as a suburb of Margate the place is rapidly extending. Dent-de-lion (some times called Dandelion) hamlet possesses the remains of an ancient castellated mansion. WHIT STAB LE. — (TERMINAL STATION.)— A parish, town, and sea port of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Blean union and Canter bury county court district and petty sessional division. The two parishes of Whitstable and Sea Salter included in former times within their limit a borough jurisdiction known as " Harwich," and remains which have been discovered give reason to the belief that the Romans had a settlement here. The place owes its modern importance to its celebrated oyster fishery, which is under the control aud management of an Incorporated Company of Dredgers, whose affairs are administered by a jury of twelve men chosen from their body. The company numbers about 424 members, who are
WHITSTABLE BAY AND HARBOUR (FROM THE EAST).

140 Thechurchesof St. Giles and St. Leonard have ceased to exist ; that of St. Thomas occupies one of the centre squares, and from its remains seems to have been a large and beautiful building : the chancel, which is spacious and lofty, is now used as the parish church ; the walls on the south and west are covered with ivy. There are stone and marble tombs, cauopied, to Gervase and Stephen Alard, admirals of the Cinque Ports, who died 1310 and 1330, and three altar tombs of the time of Edward I., called Crusaders or Knights Templars, one of whom is supposed to be a member of the family of Oxengridge. The ruins of a convent of Grey Friars aro shown to the public. Area of the liberty : 4,748 acre3 of land and water. Population : 1,115. Area: 1,511 acres of land and water. Population : 679. Average Train Service : Four each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London: 17/-/, 13/6 s, express; 15/-/, 10/6 s, 6/- /, ordinary. Return Tickets (8 days), 25/- /, 20/- s, express ; 24/- /, 17/6 s, 10/6 /, ordinary. WOKINGHAM.-(STATIOi_ .) — Wokingham (or Oakingham) is an ancient chartered market town aud parish of the county of Berks. It is in the poor-law union ofthe same name, the hundred of Sonning rural deanery of Sonning, archdeaconry of Berks, and diocese of Oxford. A portion of this parish was formerly in- cluded in Wiltshire, but by the Acts 2 & 3 William IV., cap 64, and 7 & 8 Viet., cap. 61, was included in Berkshire. The Staines and Wokingham branch of the South Western Railway at Staines gives access to London, and the South Eastern lino affords communication with the coast and all the stations on the Great Western Railway. Elizabeth first gave a charter of incorporation to Woking ham, in wliich she recited and confirmed privileges long enjoyed by the inhabit ants, but the governing charter is one granted by James I., in 1612. The corporate body consists of an alderman, seven capital burgesses, and twelve sec ondary burgesses, with officers. General and patty sessions are held, but the court of record has been discontinued for nearly two centuries. The alderman is elected annually on the Wednesday in Easter week, and he, and his immediate predecessor, the high steward and the recorder, are town magistrates by virtue of their offices. The public health is attended to by a local board appointed in 1874. The town occupies an elevated situation within the ancient limits of Windsor Forest, and consists of several irregularly-built streets, meeting iu a central spot, used as a market place. The parish church of All Saints, an old and handsome structure, was thoroughly restored in 1864. A portion of the parish is constituted a separate district for ecclesiastical purposes, and John Walter, Esq., M.P. (whose estate — Bear- wood — is about two miles distant), has built a church (St. Paul's) for the new district, at his own cost. The church, consecrated July 23, 1864, is in the Dec- orated style of the llth and 15th centuries. There is a National school for boys and girls, also St. Paul's mixed school for boys and girls, and an Infant school. Wokingham contains places of worship for Baptists and Wesleyans. Tn the centre of the town stands a block of buildings, consisting of the Town Hall, Market House, and Police station, erected at a cost of £3,500, on the site of the old Town Hall. Wokingham is endowed with many charities, amongst them being a bequest by Archbishop Laud, of £50 per annum, to be expended every third year in portioning poor maidens, and the other two years in apprenticing boys of the parish. Market Day : Tuesday. Area : 8,1 31 acres. Population : 4,652. Principal Hotels : Bush ; and Railway. Average Train Ser- vice : Eight each way on week days ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 5/6 / 4/- s, 3/- /. Return Tickets (8 days), 9/- /, 6/6 s, 0/- /. WOOLWICH— (Two STATIONS —ARSENAL and DOCKYARD.) — A populous town, urban sanitary district, and parish, forming an important part of the parliamentary borough of Green- wich, in the county of Kent (western division) ; it is in the union of the same name, the Greenwich and Woolwich county court and police court districts, and the jurisdictions of the Metropolitan Police, and Central Criminal Court, and London School Board. The best view of the Dockyard is obtained from North Woolwich. Here can be observed the sea-wall extending from Charlton to the lower part of the town ; in the distance

141 may be seen the numerous shipping in the river. At an early period, the natural capabilities of Woolwich were deemed admirably adapted for tbe con struction of vessels ; tbe river at this part being nearly a mile across, and deep enough to float vessels of large burthen within a very short distance of the shore ; and, accordingly, in the reign of Henry VIII., a royal dockyard was first established here, in which the well-known "Harry Grace-a-Dieu " was built in 1515. It was not, however, until the reign of Elizabeth that the dockyard became cf any importance. It was here tbat most of tho ships cele brated in the victories of Drake and Hawkins, and in the voyages of Drake and Frobisher, were launched. It was in the reign of Charles I., after the dockyard had been greatly enlarged, and the interior economy much im proved, that the " Sovereign of the Seas" was constructed. She was registered for 1,637 tons, and was considered, at that period, of extraordinary dimensions. The dockyard increased as the import ance of the navy became more apparent, and at the present time it is of consid erable extent. It commences at the village of New Charlton on the west, and extends nearly a mile along the banks of the river to the east, at which part it closely approaches the Arsenal. There are docks capable of containing the largest men-of-war. On the side of the basin is a magnificent dock, one of the largest in the kingdom, formed of the finest granite. This dock is used for building or fitting up the largest de scription of war steamers. The ill-fated " Royal George " was built in these docks, and launched in 1751. The foun dry and boiler- maker department is upon the most extensive scale, and engines of the most powerful description are now made and fitted to the largest steamers. Piles of cannon shot are scattered about in immense quantities, with anchors and large pieces of wide-mouthed ordnance ; while the quick puffing of steam blowing off, the vomiting of dense smoke in huge black rolling columns, the glow of furnace fires, and the sound of a thou sand hammers busily at work, tell of those vast triumphs of mechanical in genuity by which bars of iron are twisted with the ease and lightness of a silk ribbon. Each department of the dock yard is under the superintendence of a separate officer, the whole being under the direction of the Board of Admiralty. A commissioner, the master-attendant, the storekeeper, and the principal officers of the other departments, reside on the spot, houses having been erected for their accommodation. The Arsenal is a few steps from the dockyard gates. This building is surrounded by huge brick walls of large circumference, and with a massive entrance, opening on a wide gravelled space, the ranges of buildings and houses within appearing almost like a town in themselves. Right and left of the gateway is a lodge, in one of which visitors are handed over to an official, who enters in a book their names, residences, and designations. The three manufacturing departments into which the Woolwich Arsenal is divided, are as follows : — Tbe Royal Gun Factory, the Royal Carriage Department, and the Royal Laboratory Department. The Shell Factory is entered by folding gates of a remarkably chaste and beau tiful description. They are formed of ornamental cast-iron work and wrought iron bars, the whole fitted into a massive wrought-iron frame. The gates are highly ornamented, and contain, among other devices, admirably executed, the monogram V.R., in a circle, and the royal arms beneath, with the date of manufacture, 1856. Near the foundry is the Pattern Room, a building in which is deposited a pattern or model of every article used in the artillery service. Connected with the pattern room is the Laboratory, in wbich the cartridges, rockets, fireworks, and other articles of chemical construction used in the service are prepared. Proceeding to the north, the extensive range of storehouses of the Royal Artillery is approached. In these repositories there are generally kept complete outfittings for 10,000 horses, and frequently there are sufficient articles for 20,000 cavalry. These objects include saddles (arranged in heaps on tbe sides of a room nearly 300 feet long), horses' bits, pistols, swords, horse-shoes, whips, (fee. From the upper part of these warehouses the whole area ofthe arsenal may be seen, together with the immense tiers of cannon in the field immediately below. The Chapel in Woolwich Ar-

142 school. The whole building is arranged for the accommodation of from 3,000 to 4,000 men. On the Parade in front of the grand entrance to the barracks, stand five large pieces of ordnance, mounted upon handsome bronzed car riages. The centre gun, " a fine speci men of Oriental manufacture," was taken at the siege of Bhurtpoor. Across the road which leads along the west end of the barracks, stands a park of guns, mounted on carriages ; here the recruits of the Royal Artillery are exercised. The Garrison Church contains five apse windows, illustrating the petitions in the Litany. At the Royal Military Repository is a regularly-constructed fort, with guns peeping from the embra sures. Here the gunners and drivers of the Royal Artillery practise the art of defending fortifications ; and on the lake,. floating bridges are thrown upon pon toons ; and other processes of war are carried on in strict exercises. The Rotunda is not improperly termed, the great national military curiosity shop. The singular shape and pictutesque appearance of the building strike the attention ; nor will the eye wander un pleased down the precipitous slope on which it is erected, with the distant view of Woolwich, the river, and the flat lands of Essex. The Rotunda was originally a banqueting room, designed by Nash, and put up in Carlton Gardens for the reception of the Allied Sove reigns; it is now a depository for military and naval models. Its twenty-four sides, the one light, slender pillar in the cen tre, piled all round with curious arms, shields, helmets, and guns, of a rare and ancient description, present a grand vista to the visitor on his entrance. Its form is a regular polygon, having a dia meter of 120 feet, with the roof ascend ing in tho form of a cone to more than 60 feet. In the centre, tastefully ar ranged around the pillar, are old English weapons, as the ancient matchlock, the wheel- lock, two-handed swords, early cannon, shields, bills and partizans, &c, together with many trophies from foreign powers. Above these is a beautiful suit of armour, said to have belonged to the chivalric Bayard, the knight " sans peur et sans reproche." Near the walls are exhibited many other articles of a similar description, consisting of the senal was opened for divine service in February, 1863. From the top of the hill beyond the Ordnance Hospital, a magnificent picture presents itself to our gaze. The noble mass of buildings comprised in the Royal Artillery bar racks nearly a quarter of a mile in length ; their fine elevation ; the splen did level of the parade, in front of the whole range ; the field of guns on the west, and the Royal Military Repository at its end ; as a background, the beauti ful hanging woods of Charlton, and a distant view of London; on the south, inclining to the west, the far outspreading common, stretching to the horizon ; again, on the south, inclining to the east, is the Royal Mihtary Academy, while majestically, to form a background in this direction, lie the romantic and ver dant slopes, tending upwards to the darkly- wooded summit of Shooter's Hill : to the east and north-east extend, like a panorama, the low grounds of Kent and Essex, through which flows the Thames, studded with many a moving sail. It would be difficult to conceive a more magnificent serie3 of views than are here presented. The barracks for the Royal Artillery are situated to the north of Woolwich Common. Tho principal front, extending above 1,200 feet, consists of six ranges, connected by four buildings thrown a little behind, and by as many covered ways or colon nades of the Doric order, surmounted with balustrades. Two cupolas, the one containing a clock, the other a wind dial, ornament the summit of the building and break the uniformity of the line. In the eastern wing i6 a spa ciou3 and elegant chapel. The other principal parts of the building are the library and reading-room, and the mess room, 60 feet in length. This latter room is connected with two others, the drawing and ante-rooms, which together form a handsome suite of apartments, in which balls and entertainments are sometimes given by the officers. From the principal entrance, an avenue, 220 yards in length, terminated by a gate way at the northern portion of the barracks, divides the building into two quadrangles, by the sides of which are the stabling and barracks for the Horse Artillery ; and at the extremity of the east quadrangle is a spacious riding-

143 arms and costumes of the North American Indians, tho South-Sea Island ers, &c. ; rockets of every variety, models of bombs, (fee. There are models of foreign artillery, and a splendid matchlock taken from Tippoo Saib at Seringapatam. In the body of the room are models of forts, cities, and dockyards, including a splendid model of Gibraltar. The Royal Military Academy is situated on the south-eastern edge of Woolwich Common, towards wbich it presents an imposing fapade, and the appearance of its turrets from a distance is extremely picturesque. This Academy was estab lished in the Royal Arsenal as early as 1718; but the accommodation at the commencement of the present cen tury being found insufficient, a new situation was chosen, and the present building erected in 1805. It is a spacious pile, partly in early English and partly in tlie Elizabethan style. A large tower in the centre, surmounted by four cas tellated turrets, with octagonal domes, is the principal feature in the building. This is connected with the wings by a castellated colonnade or arched recess. The main entrance, a simple archway, is approached by a long avenue from tbe north, whence the wooded heights of Shooter's Hill may be perceived, rising in the distance to the left of the building. The town of Woolwich is built in a healthy situation on the north declivity of Shooter's Hill, to the side of the river. A small portion of the town, called North Woolwich, is on the Essex side of the Thames. The houses in that part of Woolwich, whieh may be considered the principal street, are of ancient appearance, occasionally inter spersed with substantial and well-built dwellings. The upper part of the town, towards the Common and the Charlton road, contains several ranges of well built and handsome modern houses. The numerous stirring military displays, and the number of vessels daily passing on the river, give it an animation and permanent interest superior to any other town in the kingdom. The parish church, dedicated to St. Mary Magdalene, situated on an eminence overlooking the dockyard and the river, is a brick building, with a square tower,ornamented with copings aud cornices of stone ; the interior — in which several standards taken in war are deposited — is lofty and well arranged. The galleries are sup ported on Ionic columns of good pro portion ; there are few monumentsof any celebrity. In the churchyard are numerous mortuary records to officers of the Royal Artillery. Besides this church, there aro other sacred edifices : St. John's, situated in Wellington-street, a neat stone structure wish lancet-shaped windows ; St. Thomas's, consecrated in 1850 ; and Holy Trinity, in Beresford Street ; and Mission Chapels. There are also the Garrison and Ordnance Chapels, and several places of worship for Dissenters and Roman Catholics. The means of education are well pro vided ; there are also some excellent charities, Shooter's Hill, on the south side of the Common, has already been alluded to as having been formerly cele brated for the robberies committed there ; and its reputation was so ancient, that Phillpott, who wrote in the time of James I., says, "They continue still to rob here by prescription." The widening of the road, and the great increase of popula tion in the neighbourhood dispersed the " night gentry," and the place is now studded with handsome villas and sub stantial mansions. Area (inclusive of 400 acres for North Woolwich, in Kent) : 1,113 acres. Population : 35,557 (in cluding more than 4,000 military). News paper : Kentish Independent (i.), Satur day, ld. The Train Service is very frequent, and the Fares from the London terminii small. WOODSIDE. — (STATION.) — Woodside is an ecclesiastical district of the civil parish of Croydon (see under that head). The church was built in 1872. Tbe station is on the Addiscombe Branch Line. Average Train Service : Twenty each way on week days ; four each way on Sundays. Fares from Lon don: 1/6 f, 1/2 s, lOd. /. Return Tickets (4 days), 2/6 f, 1/9 s, 1/3 /. WOTTO N.— (Station —GOM SHALL — 3 miles.) — A village and parish of the county of Surrey (western division) ; in Dorking union, county court district, and petty sessional divi sion. Leith Hill, the highest elevation in the south-east of England, is in this parish. Upon one of its points, Mr. Richard Hull, the owner of Leith Hill Place, built a tower in 1766, whence

144 the sea is visible through an opening in the South Downs. Mr. Hull was, by his own particular desire, buried in this tower. For many years after the build ing of the tower it was open to the public; the privilege, however, was thought to be abused, and it was said that the tower had become a harbour for vagrants and smugglers ; so about the years 1795 or 1800 the entrance door was built up, and the whole in terior of the tower filled with stone and cement, and it was in this state a few years ago when the tower and land adjoining were purchased by W. J. Evelyn, Esq. So solid was the cement that it was found impossible to re-open the old entrance and interior staircase, therefore a staircase tower was built by the side of the old tower, iu order to make the building available for its original purpose, of viewing the fine prospect ; the tower commands exten sive views over portions of Surrey, Sussex, Hants, Berks, Oxford, Bucks, Herts, Middlesex, Essex, Kent, and, by the aid of a glass, Wilts. Wotton House, the seat of the Evelyns, is a large and irregular building, chiefly interesting as having been the birth place of John Evelyn, the celebrated author of " Sylva," who was born October 31, 1620. The mansion is pleasantly situated in a valley sur rounded by plantations ; the library was built in 1864 on the site of the west wing (destroyed by fire about 1800). Among the family relics are three por traits of John Evelyn. In the picture gallery are placed tlie most interesting of the pictures of John Evelyn's collec tion ; and here is preserved the prayer book used by King Charles on the scaffold, which was presented by Arch bishop Juxon to Sir Richard Brown, father-in-law to John Evelyn. Area: 4,270 acres. Population 845. WYE.— (STATION.)— A town and parish of the county of Kent (eastern division) ; in Ashford union, county court district, and petty sessional divi sion. Wye is celebrated as having once been a royal manor, and granted by the Conqueror to the Abbey of Battle, to which it belonged till the Dissolution, when it reverted to the Crown ; it was subsequently granted by Queen Eliza beth to Lord Hunsdon, but at the close of the seventeenth century to tho Finches, whose present representative, the Earl of Winchelsea, is lord of the manor. Wye boasted also of a monastic college, founded in the middle of the fifteenth century, by John Kempe, Cardinal Archbishop of Canterbury and Lord Chancellor of England, and which was much frequented by students down to the Reformation, when it was sur rendered to the Crown. The remains of it, which aro sufficients extensive to indicate its former importance, form a large quadrangle, built round an open court ; but though the lower part is of stone, iu the pointed style of architec ture, tbe general effect ha3 been spoiled by modem brick additions in tho upper 3torey. The old hall, a large vaulted apartment, is now a schoolroom, and the ancient commons-room has become a kitchen ; the cloister in the inner court is modern. Some of the windows, how ever, in the southern part of the college show traces of having been richly orna mented with stained glass, which are marked with the arms of the founders, Edward IV. and Edward VI. The college is still used as a grammar-school. The town, which stands close to the river Stour (crossed here by a stone bridge), consists of a couple of well built main streets. Tlie church of St. Gregory aud St. Martin, in its original state, was a large and handsome build ing, and was erected by Cardinal Kempe, when he founded the college above mentioned. It fell into a dilapi dated state until 1701, when it was repaired. The present edifice is a neat stone building, consisting of a nave, aisles, and one circular chancel, which contains numerous memorials, including one to Lady Joanna Thornhill, a liberal contributor to the charities of Wye. In the neighbourhood of Wye aro several family seats. On the banks of the Stour is OUantigh, a fine mansion, sur rounded by a park of about 600 acres. On the same river, also, is Godmersham, a pretty rural village, in a fertile dis trict ; and close to it is Godmersham House and Park. There are also Wye Court, Withersden, Cold Harbour, Wil mington, Marriage, Hermitage, and Pickersdean. Fair ; Annually on Oc tober llth. Area .• 7,282 acres. Popu lation : 1,620. Average Train Service ;

145 Four each way on week dayTs ; two each way on Sundays. Fares from London : 14/6/ 10/- s, 5/1 t. Return Tickets (8 days), 22/-/, 15/- s, 9/- t. YALDI N G.— (STATION.)— A village and parish of tbe county of Kent (mid division) ; in Maidstone union, county court district, and petty sessional division. The parish church, a Gothic structure, situate about one mile on the east side of the station, is dedicated to St. Peter and St. Paul ; the vicarage is about half a mile beyond ; a moat runs round the house and gardens. There is also a district church in this parish. St. Margaret's Church National schools were built in 1857, for boys and girls. There is a free Grammar school for boys, open to the children of any parishioner. There are also six alms houses, the gift of Miss Simmons. A branch of the river Medway runs through this parish. Barges of forty or fifty tons reach here via Rochester and Maidstone. At Yalding Lees Pasture there is a cricket-ground, beautifully surrounded with elm and chestnut trees. On the east side of the line, between Yalding and Watering bury, is the seat called Kenward. A splendid view of the surrounding country may be had from tho hills. Area : 5,843 acres. Population : 2,678. Average Train Service : Six each way on week days ; two each way on Sun days. Fares from London : 10/- /, 6/8 s, 3/3 /. Return Tickets (4 days), 15/6 /, 10/6 s, 6/6 /. THE PRINCIPAL CITIES AND TOWNS ON THE THROUGH ROUTE FROM AND TO CALAIS AND BOULOGNE AND PARIS. ABBEVILLE.— A cathedral town of the department of La Somme aud a principal station on the Northern of France Railway. It is situated in a fer tile valley, about three miles broad, and is well built. The public edifices include a commercial college, a school of design, hospitals, public libraries, &c. The Chateau d'Eau in the neighbourhood was the favourite marine residence of King Louis Philippe. The Somme intersects the town, forming a small island on which the principal part of Abbeville is built. Three small affluents of the Somme likewise flow through the town, so that a large number of bridges aro required to facilitate the communi cation. The ramparts, which are flauked with bastions and surrounded by broad ditches, form an agreeable promenade. There is a considerable commerce in corn, oil, linseed, and hemp, by means of the Somme, which is navigable up to the town at high water, by vessels of 150 tons. There are also extensive manufactories of woollen cloths, &c, cavalry and infantry barracks. The principal attraction of Abbeville is the cathedral, dedicated to St. Wulfran. The building is of ancient date, but was reconstructed in the sixteenth century. The date of 1513, inscribed in the roof of the choir, establish^ the date of this restoration. One of the great charms of the edifice is its picturesque irregularity, and the profusion of beautiful sculptures, also the numberless niches and statues with fretwork and carving which en counter the eye everywhere. A square tower rises on each side of the gateway, each richly ornamented. The interior of the cathedral is very striking, despite the tawdry tinsel which covers the altars. The altar of St. Wulfran was for several centuries the object of peculiar venera tion. It was here that an oath, or probe test, was administered to individuals suspected of having robbed their neigh bours, and to the workmen employed in the Mint, in order to keep them honest. There are few remains of antiquity in Abbeville except this church ; and tho

146 prison, composed of portions of the castle, formerly belongiug to tbe Counts of Ponthieu, which was so splendid as to be the pride of Picardy. The three celebrated geographers of the seven teenth century, Philip Briet, Peter Duval, and Nicholas Sanson, and the poet Millevoye, were natives of Abbe ville. The population is nearly 18,000. The battle-field of Agincourt is distant from Abbeville about seven miles. Both Agincourt and Crecy are reached by diligences. Abbeville was occupied by the Germans ia 1871. Principal Hotels : De France ; Du Commerce ; and Tete de Bœuf. building, such as can bo nowhere ex celled. The stalls in the choir are richly carved, and represent the principal personages and events in the Holy Scriptures ; the stained glass win dows are among the finest that France contains. In one of tho towers, a small chamber is shown where, according to tradition, Henry the Fourth posted himself to watch the movements of the Spanish army. The steeple, which is 201 feet from its base to the summit, and 402 feet from the ground, was the work of a common carpenter. The en tire length of the Cathedral is 442 feet, and its vault is half as high again as the roof of Westminster Abbey. " The interior is one of the most magnificent spectacles that architectural skill can ever have produced. The mind is filled and elevated by its enormous height (140 feet), its lofty and many-coloured clere story, its grand proportions, and its noble simplicity. The proportion of height to breadth is almost double that to which we are accustomed in English cathedrals ; the lofty, solid piers, which bear up this height, are far more massive in their plan than the light and graceful clusters of our English churches, each of them being a cylinder with four engaged columns. The polygonal E apse is a feature which we seldom see, and no where so exhibited and on such a scale ; and the peculiar French arrangement which puts the walls at the outside edge of the buttresses, and thus forms in terior chapels all round, in addition to the aisles, gives a vast multiplicity of perspective below, which fills out the idea produced by the gigantic height of the centre. Such terms will not be con sidered extravagant when it is recol lected that the vault is half ashigh again as the roof of Westminster Abbey.'' — Whewell. The city is situated on the river Somme, at an altitude of 400 feet above sea-level. It is the see of a bishop, who is a suffragan of Rheims, and whose diocese comprises the department of the Somme. It is also the seat of a Court of Assize, a tribunal of commerce, a school of medicine, an imperial college, an academy of science, and possesses several normal schools, a public library, and botanical garden. The weaving of cotton-velvet, and spin ning of cotton and woollen yarns, form AMIENS. — A large city and forti fied town of the department oiLa Somme, and the principal station on the North ern of France Railway in connection with the English mail and tidal routes to and from Paris. Line3 branch off here, from the main road, in every direction. The Cathedral, one of the most magnificent churches in Europe, is raised upon the ruins of an ancient temple which was destroyed by light ning. The present edifice was com menced in 1220, and finished fifty years afterwards. The exterior of the Cathe dral is distinguished by much grandeur and beauty ; the decorations of the en trances, the elaborate sculptures and tracery work, the majestic proportions of the supporting towers, altogether strik ing the eye with marvellous eflect. But it is the interior which commauds the greatest admiration. Three vast and deeply recessed portals lead into it, the arches supported by a long array of statues in niches instead of pillars, while rows of statuettes supply the place of mouldings, so that tbe whole forms one mass of sculpture ; an arrangement of constant occurrence in French Gothic, though rare in English. The sculpture of these porches merits attention ; over the centre door the bas-relief represents tbe Last Judgment, the statues are those of the twelve Apostles. Over the right hand porch are the Death and Assump tion of the Virgin ; over that on tbe left is the legend of St. Firmin, the apostle of Picardy. Above the portals runs a colossal line of French kings, behind which appears a noble wheel-window. The nave is a perfect chef c ' we of Gothic art, and the view of the whole

147 the principal manufactures of the place. Amiens was anciently the capital of Picardy. In the time of Julius Cæsar, it was called Samarobriva, and it was here that Valentinian proclaimed his son Gratian by the title of Augustus. Amiens has been the scene of great his torical events in ancient and modern times. It was taken by the Spaniards in 1597. The stratagem by which the Spanish general gained possession of tbe place is curious and well known. He caused a cartload of nuts to be over turned at one of the gates ; and, while the guard was scrambling for the fruit, he rushed into the town with a chosen body of men which he had placed iu ambush. The fortress was soon after retaken by Henry IV. It was here that the celebrated "Treaty" of 1802 was concluded between Great Britain, France, Spain, and the Batavian re public. The city wears a business aspect, and contains numerous manufac tories of beet-root sugar, soap, tanneries, and paper-mills ; atao dyeing, bleaching, and chemical works. Pates de canards are made here in large quantities. Among the most striking public build ings are the Chateau d'Eau, the Palais de Justice, the Hotel de Ville (built by Henry IV.), the Corn Market, (fee. Leading from the Boulevarde Fontaine is the Grande Rue de Beauvais, answer ing to the once existent gate. Turning down this, the visitor will see a vast building of plain exterior, but covering an immense area of ground. This is the Hospital for Deserted Children. On the Boulevard St. Jacques, is a vista of thickly-planted trees, the pride of the city, and called the PromeiW.de de la Hotoie. In the heart of the town is a handsome Marche aux Herbes, or covered fruit and vegetable market. There is a large Theatre at Amiens, in the principal street, the Rue des Trois Cailloux. Not far from the radway station is the Place St. Denis, a neat little square with a central statue, and bordered by rows of acacias. The Abbey of St. Acheul, on the outskirts of the town, was converted into a Jesuits' college under the Restoration. The. crypt under the church contains some ancient tombs and bas-reliefs. Estimated population: 50,000. After the defeat of the French army of the North in 1871 by General Manteuffel, the Germans occupied Amiens. Princi pal Hotels : De France et d'Angleterre ; Du Rhin ; and De l'Uuivers. BOULOGNE— (generally styled BOULOGNE-SUR-MER, to distinguish it from Boulogne near Paris). — Thi3 town, seaport and tidal packet station, is in the arrondissement of the same name and in the D.partement of the Pas-de- Calais. The harbour is formed in the channel of the Liane, with the addition of a semi-circular basin on the left bank of the river, which was originally dug to contain Napoleon's celebrated flotilla, intended for the invasion of England. The increasing importance of Boulogne required that this basin should be im proved and rendered serviceable for merchant vessels of considerable tonnage. In the year 1860, the works for deepen ing and forming a large floating dock were commenced, and are extremely commodious, being sheltered from tem pestuous gales, the high grounds on each side of the Liane forming a natural protection from the north-east and south, whilst an artificial barrier has been raised to protect the shipping from tho west, on the summit of which is placed a battery. The railway has a branch line alongside the harbour, by which passengers alight from the trains to the boats, and vice versa. The entrance to the harbour is bounded by two jetties : that to the west is solid up to the level of high water, and is thrown out along the lino of the rocky shore a length of 1,970 feet ; the other, to the east, runs directly out to tiie sea ; and the bottom of the intervening channel is 230 feet in width. Spring-tides rise 24 feet, and neap-tides 17 feet ; but when it blows from the west, the springs rise 28 feet, and the neaps 19 feet. The French Government having resolved to construct a deep sea harbour at Boulogne, the necessary works were commenced in 1879. This gigantic undertaking, by which in a quiet and unpretentious way France is securing on her northern coast the possi bility of a naval station that shall be one of the finest in the world, is under taken by the Government of the Re public. Tbat it will, when completed, entirely revolutionise the inter-com municate* 'iof England and France, is a consideration of prime importance to

148 Nelson on the 15th August, 1801, and by Admiral Keith, August 10th, 1804 ; but, on the defeat of the combined French and Spanish fleets in 1805, the camp at Boulogne was broken up, and the troops were marched to the Rhine. The manufactures of Boulogne consist of ropes, fishing -nets, leather, bricks, linen and woollen stuffs, pens, crino lines, and bottles. The town carries on an active trade in fresh and salt fish, of which vast quantities are transported to Paris. Boulogne consists of two towns, au upper and a lower ; the former is the older portion, and occupies the summit of a hill ; it is encircled by ramparts with arched gateways, and has an old castle at the east angle, divided from the town by a fosse ; the ramparts rise from 15 to 20 yards above the level of their base, and are surmounted by two rows of trees, forming a most delightful promenade. The high and low towns are connected by means of a steep street, called La Grand Rue. The favourite locality of the English is in the modern part, called Tintifieries, which lies in a valley towards the north. The Haute Ville, or Upper Town, contains the Hotel de Ville, or Town Hall, built on the site of the ancient palace of the counts, the birthplace of Godfrey de Bouillon, Tbe Belfroi, behind the Hotel de Ville, is one of the most ancient buildings in Boulogne; tbe tower, 140 feet high, affords a magnificent prospect from its summit of the town and the surround ing country. The Palais de Justice, or Court House, is also situated in the upper town, together with the Church of Notre Dame, raised chiefly by the exer tions of the AbbiS Haffreingue. It is built on the site of the ancient Cathedral of Boulogne, covering an extensive crypt, which merit3 the interest and admira tion it universally obtains. On the 1 5th of August, every year, and for 14 subsequent days, pilgrimages to tha shrine of Notre Dame de Boulogne draw together a great number of devotees from all parts of France to this church. The castle, long the residence of the military governors of the Boulonnais, is now au ordnance magazine aud military prison. In the Rue du Chateau is the abode where the immortal author of Gil Bias (L« -Sage) died. Passing out at the Porte Gayole, and continuing to the left the travelling public. But, at the samo time, and without detriment to this object, it is clear tbat France will have here a magnificent harbour in which all her fleet can safely lie at anchor. The harbour will cover an area of 800 acres, and steamers will be able to approach the jetty in 27 feet of wafer at low tide. This enclosure is to be completed by two breakwaters running far out into the sea, tbe longer one being in the shape of an arm bent at the elbow, and so encir cling the harbour on two sides. The works are necessarily of the most massive construction, and, like Rome, the har bour may not be built in a day. It is now, however, in full progress ; and when a certain stage is reached, the English interests (represented by the South Eastern Railway Company) have undertaken to build corresponding works on their side, though, of course, not on the same large scale. The object of the South Eastern Company is to create the possibility of making the journey from London to Paris in eight hours, by a fixed service independent of the tide. These harbours, navigable from either side in any state of the tide, will make this hitherto unapproachable design a matter of course. With deep sea harbours even larger vessels than those now owned by the South Eastern will become possible, and the horrors of the Channel passage will practically be annihilated. Boulogne has considerable claims to antiquity. The name by which it was known to the Romans was Ges soriacum. About the commencement of the Christian era, a fort was built a little to the north of Gessoriacum, on the other side of the Liane, to which the name of Bononia was given, and this name was ultimately identified with the town itself. The Normans sacked Bou logne in 882. Henry III. of England made a fruitless attack upon it in 1347. Henry VIII. made himself master of it in 1544, and Edward VI. restored it to France for 400,000 crowns.
